Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase.  The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death was a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur in horses without underlying health issues.  Although Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling), he displayed no such symptoms after Saturday's race.  While he had a history of overheating, this report concludes the cause of death was the rare haemorrhage.

In 2004, 15-year-old Davina Ayrton raped a teenage girl in a Portsmouth garage while two others slept. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, was found guilty in Portsmouth Crown Court and will be sentenced on March 4th.  The judge remanded Ayrton to a male prison in Winchester. During the trial, Ayrton stated she had not physically transitioned or taken medication and changed her name in 2012. The victim testified she clearly remembered the attack despite only having a small amount of alcohol. Ayrton confessed to the crime in 2014 to a care home worker.

Novak Djokovic and his Serbian tennis partner lost in Rio to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares.  This defeat follows his singles loss to Juan Martin del Potro, and his Wimbledon loss to Sam Querrey.  Djokovic did win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The annual chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Scotland, features 20+ international competitors, who use chainsaws to carve wood into shapes of animals and people. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will return to defend his title.

Rhys Webb, who has been out with a foot injury since September, is nearing a return to rugby.  He is currently in pre-season training and aiming to be fit in time for the Six Nations in February.  His goal is to return earlier than the initial February target.  He recently renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region.

Near Sumas, Washington, border patrol agents interrupted a smuggling attempt of 58lb of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One suspect, Jeffrey Laviolette, was apprehended, while another, Nathan Hall, fired at agents and fled, later being arrested in Canada.  Two more suspects, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were arrested for planning to transport the drugs to San Francisco.  The suspects face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. This area is a known smuggling route, and such prosecutions are common.

Childline counseled over 4,500 children, a substantial increase from 2,400 in 2011-12, regarding online bullying.  Some children as young as seven reported being tormented, abused, and scared to go to school.  Dame Esther Rantzen stresses that adults and schools must intervene as bullying won't stop on its own.  This issue is highlighted during Anti-Bullying Week, with the Anti Bullying Alliance working to combat the problem.  One child shared their experience of being told to kill themselves online, highlighting the emotional impact and difficulty in addressing it.

Israel postponed a vote on authorizing new homes in East Jerusalem settlements.  This followed a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements and rising tensions between the US and Israeli governments.  The postponement came at the request of Prime Minister Netanyahu’s office hours before US Secretary of State John Kerry’s speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.  Israel claims East Jerusalem as part of its capital, while Palestinians claim it as the capital of their future state.  Over 500,000 Jews live in roughly 140 settlements built since Israel’s 1967 occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem.  The settlements are considered illegal under international law.

In a BBC interview, Prince William praised the Queen's example as a monarch on the eve of her 90th birthday.  A picture of the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George has been released for stamps commemorating the occasion.  The Queen visited the Royal Mail delivery office in Windsor and opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens.  Prince William discussed his commitment to royal duty, stating that he takes his responsibilities seriously but is finding his own way at the right time. He also expressed admiration for the Queen's approach to public life.  Ten stamps have been released to celebrate the Queen's birthday, including images of four generations of the Royal Family.  The Queen will participate in several events, including lighting a beacon and having lunch with the Obamas.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup.  Sakho scored his first goal since November from a Byram pass, followed by a goal from Ayew. Cheltenham's best chance came from Pell's volley, but Holman couldn't connect.  West Ham had other opportunities to extend their lead but were denied by Storer and Flatt.  Cheltenham's loss marks the end of League Two representation in the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a motorcycle accident caused by Andreas Werner, 46, who failed to see him while turning right. Werner pled guilty to causing death by careless driving, receiving a £1,000 fine and a two-year UK driving ban.  McNicholl's family believed jail time for Werner wouldn't be worthwhile, accepting it as a momentary lapse.  Werner expressed remorse and couldn't explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist, returned to the UK after fighting in Syria with Rayat al Tawheed, an Islamic State affiliated group.  Khawaja, who called himself Abu Daigham al-Britani, posted propaganda for the group online, including videos and photos of himself and other fighters.  He also participated in gruesome acts, such as posing with a severed head.  Last June, Khawaja attempted to secretly return to the UK with the help of his cousin, Tahir Bhatti.  He faked his own death online before being arrested upon arrival in Dover.  Khawaja is considered a dangerous terrorist and has pleaded guilty to four offenses.  An additional charge of soliciting to murder will lie on file.

Wrexham's Kayden Jackson, 22, will join Barnsley next season.  Jackson scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season.  Barnsley's caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, says Jackson has pace, likes to challenge defenders, and will fit in with their style of play. This is Barnsley’s third signing ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday.  Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham.

Containers of Vanish detergent bottles are washing ashore on Cornish beaches, posing a risk to wildlife.  A ship lost a container of Vanish in May near Land's End, but it's not confirmed that these bottles are from that incident.  National Trust volunteers are clearing the bottles, and authorities advise the public to avoid contact with them.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 2 PM, resulting in several minor injuries.  The road was closed, and diversions were established via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road.  Police are investigating.

Wanderers defender Dorian Dervite, 28, has signed a new contract with the club. Dervite made 14 appearances last season, helping Bolton finish second in League One to secure promotion to the Championship.  He follows Wheater, Madine, and Karacan in signing new Bolton contracts.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour are experiencing tension after their brief alliance concerning Brexit amendments.  The Lib Dems accuse Labour of conceding too much to the government and giving people false hope by voting against the amendments they previously supported. Labour claims the Lib Dems are grandstanding for campaign purposes, knowing the amendments would be rejected by MPs. Despite this, the Lib Dems express a willingness to continue working with Labour on other issues in the future, while a Labour source predicts lingering tension.

Defense is a low-priority issue in the UK election, ranking below the economy, NHS, and immigration in voter concerns.  While the world is perceived as increasingly unstable, UK armed forces have undergone significant cuts, impacting capabilities like maritime patrol. Though the UK was the fourth largest defense spender, it has fallen to sixth, and may soon fall below the NATO 2% GDP guideline.  Maintaining this spending level would require an additional £25bn over five years.  The next government will likely make further defense cuts, with the MoD having the second largest non-protected budget.  Replacing Trident is estimated to cost at least £20bn, impacting conventional forces.  The two new aircraft carriers, while large, may be understaffed and underequipped.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, but with additional fees, the total cost is £106.8m.  Amidst accusations of misappropriated funds and investigations into the transfer, Barcelona made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56, though they maintain their original payment was correct.  The club denies any tax-related crime.

Michael Luciw, 27, died in a car crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman driving the wrong way on a motorway.  Luciw's family believes older drivers should have regular driving tests, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of driving for older people's independence.  The crash occurred when Newman's car hit the van Luciw was in. The van driver, Andy Harrington, sustained serious injuries.  Currently, drivers over 70 self-assess every three years, with no medical or driving tests required. The DVLA has no plans to change this, stating older drivers are not more accident-prone.

An independent review of transvaginal mesh implants, chaired by Tracey Gillies, concluded that the procedure should not be routinely offered to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended mandatory reporting of adverse events.  Two patients and a consultant quit the review group over concerns with the final report,  and two former members, Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, expressed "dismay and disgust" at its publication.  Health Secretary Ms Robison confirmed the recommendations would be implemented despite calls for a ban, citing a lack of government power.  Alison Britton will examine how the review reached its conclusions. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have received implants in the past 20 years, and over 400 are pursuing legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5K record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds.  McColgan expressed concerns about the legitimacy of the race as Muir was the only 5k runner, with others running a 3k.  However, British Athletics confirmed the time is expected to be officially ratified.  McColgan believes Muir is capable of a 14:30 time, putting her among the world's top runners.  Muir also holds the British 1500m record and was an Olympic finalist at Rio 2016.

Michael Jung won gold in equestrian aboard Sam, a late replacement for Fischertakinou. Astier Nicolas of France took silver, and Phillip Dutton of the US took bronze. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt, competing only 10 months after being in an induced coma, finished 12th after a disappointing cross-country performance. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 to advance to the fourth round of Wimbledon.  Fognini had five set points in the fourth set, but Murray won five straight games to secure the victory. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the next round.  Murray’s match was tense, especially at the end as light faded and the roof was a possibility.  Fognini had an ankle injury and was penalized a point for obscene gestures.  Murray felt he could have moved better during the match and will work on that before Monday.

On October 6, 2014, police discovered patrons still at Joe's Bar in Dungiven past permitted hours, with alcohol served as late as 04:49 BST.  The bar's license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours. The judge ordered a three-month closure and fined O'Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000, citing O'Neill's "appalling record" and the severity of the case.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, launched the party's manifesto, 'Real Partnership'.  He stated that he prefers partnership over domination and wants the election to be about how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled.  His recent comments about vote transfers have caused controversy.  Mr. Nesbitt stands by his comments, saying he would not withdraw a word. He stated a preference for working with the SDLP over Sinn Féin, should his party need to form a coalition government.  He believes he has support for his position.  The Ulster Unionist manifesto focuses on issues such as tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and mitigating the negative impacts of Brexit.  It also calls for cleaning up Stormont, addressing incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption.

Northern Ireland will follow England and Wales in enacting “Turing’s Law,” which will provide posthumous pardons for men convicted of abolished sexual offenses.  Living men convicted of such offenses may also apply for a pardon.  Justice Minister Claire Sugden has secured executive agreement to bring the motion before the assembly for approval.  The goal is to provide equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland, mirroring that of England and Wales.

Laura Muir, 23, set a new Scottish record in the mile, finishing second in 4:19.12 behind Faith Kipyegon.  This time places Muir second on the British all-time list and beats Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record.  Muir now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records.  She hopes to qualify for the Rio Olympics at the British trials in Birmingham.
26 Scottish beaches have been ranked as having the "most excellent" water quality. Pictures of these beaches are available.

UK officials suspect Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi poisoned Alexander Litvinenko with polonium-210 in 2006.  Litvinenko, a former KGB agent who defected to the UK in 2000, died three weeks later.  Richard Horwell QC, for the Met Police, said the Russian state likely sponsored the poisoning, citing Litvinenko's accusations against the FSB and Putin.  The suspects deny involvement, remain in Russia, and will likely not be tried for murder.  The inquiry chairman criticized Kovtun for not providing evidence.

Steve Smith, 26, replaces Michael Clarke, 34, as Australia's Test cricket captain.  David Warner, 28, will be vice-captain.  Smith has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs, averaging 54.66.  He captained the team in three Tests against India last summer while Clarke recovered from injury. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test.

Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron refused to answer whether he thought homosexual sex was a sin. He told the BBC he was “passionate about LGBT-plus rights” and that defending and extending equal marriage, including the marital rights of transgender people, would be “at the top of my agenda”.  He voted against the 2007 Equality Bill due to concerns about “protection of individual liberties,” but claims to support equality for all, regardless of sexuality.

Sanofi's drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, which closed in 2015 and resulted in 450 job losses, will be reopened by Accord Healthcare. Accord's investment in the pharmaceutical production plant is hoped to rehire many ex-Sanofi staff, positively impacting the local economy.  Newcastle City Council leader is pleased with Accord's investment, adding to the region's reputation as a hub for science and healthcare.  Accord Healthcare distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to approximately 60 countries.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving their positions at the council.  Ellis's contract is ending, while Monaghan and Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme.  Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition, believes this demonstrates the council's inability to retain senior staff and anticipates further departures. Ellis acted as interim director of corporate governance and deputy chief executive. Monaghan headed the chief executive's office, and Sutherland led human resources and customer services.  Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked them for their service.

Guy Martin crashed at the Isle of Man TT and experienced mechanical issues with his Honda Fireblade. He stated that he is not quitting road racing altogether, but has no plans to continue road racing with Honda this year. He withdrew from the North West 200 after his teammate crashed and will not participate in the Ulster Grand Prix due to the bike's lack of competitiveness. He intends to race classics and other unique events in the future.

Nigeria's All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in the latest election, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP).  The PDP's loss is attributed to voters' desire for change after 16 years of PDP rule, allegations of corruption, and the party's failure to curb the Islamist insurgency in the northeast.  While the APC secured key wins in northern states and Lagos, it failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for incoming president Muhammadu Buhari.  The PDP retained power primarily in the southeast and oil-rich Niger Delta regions.  Although marred by some violence, the elections were deemed more peaceful than previous years.

Mighty, a US environmental lobby group, has accused agricultural commodities trader Olam and its stakeholder Temasek of overlooking unsustainable palm oil practices that contribute to the haze from Indonesian fires. Olam, denying the allegations, says less than 1% of the global market share is theirs and they enforce a “no burn” policy.  While Olam recently disclosed its 14 suppliers, Mighty claims Olam fosters a secretive market for rogue palm oil companies and sources from unknown origins. Temasek also denies the allegations, stating that they support no-burn policies and do not interfere with Olam’s operations.  Palm oil production is worth $88 billion, yet faces criticism for labor practices, deforestation, and burning.  NGOs and palm oil executives clash over environmental practices and their enforcement. Mighty also accuses Olam of deforestation in Gabon for palm oil plantations, a claim Olam denies, citing responsible and transparent private-public partnerships with Gabon’s government.
A restaurant began serving puppy platters outdoors after a new law allowed dogs to eat at outdoor restaurants.

Fernando Forestieri (knee) is doubtful after only featuring from the bench in the last two games. David Nugent (groin) may return after missing Monday's draw, and Jacob Butterfield is hoping to start after scoring a late equalizer as a substitute in that game.

Pakistan lifted its YouTube ban after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version, allowing the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to request removals of content deemed offensive.  While the PTA claims Google agreed to restrict access to flagged material, YouTube maintains that removal requests are not automatically granted and are subject to review based on community guidelines and local laws.  The ban, originally imposed in 2012 due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims," was lifted following Google's localized YouTube launch for Pakistan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, faces pressure from Liberian FA boss Musa Bility to withdraw from the upcoming presidential election due to sharing nationality (Swiss-Italian) with candidate Gianni Infantino. Bility cites a FIFA article requiring committee members with conflicts of interest to be replaced and points to Scala's withdrawal from the 2015 election when he shared nationality with then-president Sepp Blatter.  Scala's spokesman argues that shared nationality with a candidate doesn't constitute a conflict of interest, citing FIFA regulations and emphasizing the difference between this election and 2015, where the shared nationality was with the incumbent president. Bility has threatened to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala doesn't withdraw and questions the differing processes between the two elections.  The Liberian FA emphasizes the importance of fairness and integrity in the election following FIFA's recent turmoil.  Bility, previously an electoral candidate himself, has pledged his support to Prince Ali.  Five candidates, including Infantino and Prince Ali, are vying for the FIFA presidency, with the election taking place on February 26th in Zurich.

Two workers, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday.  The explosion, caused by a buildup of toxic fumes and an ignition, occurred in a paint-spraying area.  A forensic search has been conducted, and witness statements gathered.  The Health and Safety Executive is investigating.

Tunisia and Morocco will participate in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations.  Tunisia had faced expulsion for complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) during the 2015 quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea, but apologized and will now participate.  Morocco’s participation was also in doubt after a ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) related to its refusal to host the 2015 tournament.  Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

Following a fracas in the 95th minute of a match between Manchester City and Chelsea, City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho received four- and three-match bans, respectively.  Aguero's ban results from a high challenge on David Luiz, his second dismissal this season. Fernandinho clashed with Cesc Fabregas following Aguero's challenge.  City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Both clubs must respond to the charge by 18:00 GMT on 8 December.

Wales and other parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world.  A pilot scheme in the Cynon Valley and Neath Port Talbot is focusing on patients whose GPs suspect cancer but who aren't showing any urgent signs or symptoms. This comes a year after doctors visited Denmark to observe their diagnostic systems, where the Cwm Taf Health Board officials saw that Denmark’s health service had improved cancer survival rates. The concern is that a patient in Wales who does not have clear symptoms waits too long for a diagnosis because they do not "easily fit" into any particular treatment pathway. This means that GPs refer the patient back and forth for a number of tests, which takes several weeks. Because of this, the fear is that too many patients begin treatment when their cancer has developed or is incurable. Forty doctors in the Cynon Valley who believe something may be wrong will be able to refer the patient to a diagnostic centre at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant within seven days. The estimate is that about six patients a week will be seen and will have different tests, and the hope is that this will happen on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with "worrying" symptoms

England defeated Pakistan by 330 runs in the second Test at Old Trafford, leveling the four-match series 1-1.  Joe Root was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and unbeaten 71 in the second. Alastair Cook also contributed with scores of 105 and 76 not out.  Pakistan's batting struggles continued, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series so far.  Despite the dominant win, Michael Vaughan predicts a tight series. The third Test begins on August 3rd at Edgbaston.

Warren Gatland will lead the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with Rob Howley as interim coach.  Forwards coach Robin McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales for the third time, leading the summer tour.  The WRU will appoint assistant coaches to help McBryde and expects to finalize the management team soon.  Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the coaches’ involvement with the Lions will benefit the Welsh national team.

Southampton took an early lead with a penalty in the sixth minute. However, Hull City turned the game around with two goals in two minutes during the second half, thanks to Robert Snodgrass's goal and assist. Despite Southampton's efforts and David Marshall's crucial saves, Hull City secured their first league win since August 20th, ending their six-game losing streak.  Injuries to Hull City’s starting strikers ultimately worked in their favor, allowing Snodgrass to return from injury earlier than anticipated and change the momentum of the game.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, around 2:15 pm BST.  The tractor driver was unharmed. Police are seeking witnesses and the B1191 is closed between Woodhall Spa and Horncastle.

Macedonia’s President Ivanov halted an investigation into recordings that allegedly exposed government abuse of power.  Ivanov stated that he wanted to end turmoil ahead of June elections, but the move was criticized by the EU and Macedonian opposition.  The recordings, released by opposition leader Zaev, allegedly revealed vote-rigging, a murder cover-up, and other government corruption.  The government denies the accusations.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth.  Swansea’s first choice for new manager is Paul Clement.  Curtis believes Swansea lost their way after Michael Laudrup left in 2014 due to constant management changes.  He also questions if departing players have been adequately replaced.  Curtis feels the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation, and reminds new signings of the club's history and importance of remaining in the Premier League.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after losing 3-2 to Leyton Orient.  Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, Armand Gnanduillet scored the winner for Orient, keeping their play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who reached the Football League in 2007, return to the National League under manager John Still. They struggled this season with a league-worst goal difference and a weaker attack compared to last season. Still is committed to helping the Daggers return to League Two.  Orient's win comes after removing Kevin Nolan as player-manager. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler acknowledged the difficult week but emphasized the team's need to win to reach the play-offs.

Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, his first job since retiring.  Gerrard's goal is to become a manager.  He played for Liverpool from 1998 until the end of the 2014-2015 season before joining LA Galaxy.  He retired in November after a 19-year career.  Gerrard is also working towards his Uefa A coaching licence.

Morton defeated Alloa 4-1. McManus scored two goals, one in the first 15 minutes and another late in the game, to help secure the win for Morton. Forbes also scored for Morton, while McAusland scored for Alloa. Johnstone added a late goal for Morton.

Ofsted investigations uncovered three illegal schools operating in squalid conditions in Birmingham, prompting their closure.  These schools are part of 18 unregulated institutions, primarily within Muslim communities in the Midlands, currently under investigation.  While some "flexi-schools" legally provide supplementary education for home-schooled children, authorities suspect some operate as illegal schools.  Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, expressed concern over potential child abuse and radicalization, urging quicker government action against these institutions.  The government has allocated funding for six inspectors to investigate illegal schools across all religious groups.  The Education Secretary has requested Ofsted to prepare prosecutions.  Further regulation of institutions teaching over 6-8 hours per week is under consultation until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is the first distillery to open in the Scottish Borders since 1837.  It is one of the smallest production stills in the UK, using local botanicals to create a unique “Borders terroir.” The gin is named after a local legendary figure, Lilliard, a female warrior who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

Gary Green, who was more than two times the legal driving limit, killed Harry Whitlam after reversing a tractor into him at Swithens Farm in August 2013. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. He was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting failing to ensure the safety of others under health and safety legislation, rather than road traffic law, because the incident occurred on private land.  Harry's mother said the family had been "changed forever" and hoped to remember the good times shared with Harry. HSE inspector Julian Franklin described the incident as an "extremely tragic case" and Green's behavior as "reckless".

Luis Suarez's four-month ban from all football activity has been upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), but he is now allowed to train and play in friendly matches for Barcelona.  He can also attend matches and participate in promotional activities.  Suarez's competitive debut for Barcelona will likely be on October 26th.  He will still serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games.  The CAS ruling allows him to partake in "football-related activities" but not "organized" matches.  Suarez's lawyers argued that the FIFA sanctions were too harsh, but CAS largely confirmed them, stating that preventing training would negatively impact Suarez after his suspension ends.  Fifpro expressed disappointment that the ban wasn't reduced and suggested mandatory treatment.  Suarez bit Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. This is the third biting incident for which Suarez has been sanctioned.

Richard Blake-Smith and Anna won the British Wife-Carrying Race, defeating the Lithuanian team.  They trained for a week by running on a track. The 380-meter race included hurdles, a slope, and water pistols.  Competitors included various pairings, and the winners will compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

In October, the paper system for car tax discs will be replaced with an electronic system, allowing payments via monthly direct debit.  This change will likely impact some of the 5,000 DVLA employees in Swansea.  Stephen Hammond assures that job reductions will be managed through redeployment and training for new roles within other growing areas of the DVLA, rather than redundancies.

Hungary's Foreign Minister says the EU should not interfere in its domestic affairs regarding laws passed concerning asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education.  Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary, including the stripping of voting rights, which requires unanimous approval.  The new laws have prompted protests within Hungary and warnings from the EU, with threats of action if changes aren't made.  One of the laws could force the closure of the Central European University in Budapest.

Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens the Beast, and Luke Evans Gaston in a live-action version of Beauty and the Beast.  Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle’s father, and Emma Thompson Mrs. Potts.  Josh Gad will play LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the film, which will be released in the US on March 17, 2017.  Filming begins in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a journalist for the Sunday Times, died from cancer.  Gill was known for his wit, fearless writing, and compassion.  He overcame dyslexia to become a writer, first writing art reviews before moving to the Sunday Times in 1993.  Though popular, his writing was often controversial.  He is survived by his partner, Nicola Formby, and four children.

Rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked while performing in Ulan Bator, Mongolia.  Russian news reported he was hit with a bottle and kicked, while his father stated he suffered brain injuries and a 10-day coma.  Sukhbaatar wears a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol, not affiliated with Nazism. The Russian embassy disputes details in media reports of the attack and is investigating.  The suspect, reportedly a Russian diplomat, has not been arrested, with police citing the injuries as not serious.  Sukhbaatar's lawyer insists the suspect should be investigated under Mongolian law.

Plane Stupid protestors demonstrated against airport expansion plans.  They were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area.  The protest occurred at 03:30 BST Monday on the northern runway.  A security review will follow.

Nick Selman scored 101 runs for Glamorgan, his second first-class century of the season, after a string of low scores.  Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took wickets regularly for Gloucestershire, bowling Glamorgan out for 220.  Gloucestershire struggled in their innings, ending the day evenly balanced with Glamorgan.  Michael Hogan is leading Glamorgan while Jacques Rudolph is out with a neck injury.

33-year-old Craig Hughes from Flint was arrested in August after online chats with a Tennessee crisis center, where he made threats to falsely report a crime, ambush and shoot responding police officers at the Dee Estuary.  He admitted to two charges in Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week.  Hughes had a prior firearm conviction in 2009.  His legal team stated he never intended to harm himself or carry out the threat.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire by 18 runs in the Royal London One-Day Cup semi-final at Headingley.  Davies (95) and Foakes (90) shared a 130-run partnership to help Surrey recover from 8-2 and post 255-7. Despite Bresnan's 68 and Waite's 38, Yorkshire were all out for 236. Meaker's three wickets in nine balls proved crucial for Surrey.  Yorkshire captain Lees admitted their failure to perform in crucial moments, while Surrey captain Batty praised the team's collective effort and the pivotal partnership between Davies and Foakes.

A 56ft converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST reporting their pump couldn't handle incoming water.  An RNLI lifeboat crew added another pump and towed the trawler to Holyhead.

Laura Muir will miss the Commonwealth Games due to veterinary medicine exams.  She plans to compete in the World Indoor Championships in March.  At the World Athletics Championships, Muir placed fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m, achieving a personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the latter.  She is optimistic about competing in future Olympics.

Liverpool are struggling this season due to overachieving last season and the loss of Suarez’s goals.  Rodgers’s signings have not been effective, impacting their intensity and ability to score, especially in the first half.  Defensively, they remain inconsistent despite significant spending.  Gerrard, though aging, is vital to Liverpool’s future.  Chelsea are currently superior to other Premier League teams and are predicted to win against Liverpool at Anfield. While Gerrard’s slip last season against Chelsea significantly impacted Liverpool, he remains a key player and is expected to continue contributing to the team.

A new £45m campus in Kilmarnock, East Ayrshire, will house primary, secondary, and Gaelic schools, and a childcare center.  The council wishes to name it after Kilmarnock-born author William McIlvanney, who died on December 5th.  McIlvanney, initially an English teacher, became a full-time writer in 1975.  His first novel, *Remedy Is None*, and other works like the *Laidlaw* trilogy, *Docherty*, and *The Big Man* earned him the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir".  He also contributed to Scotland's political and sporting life.

A sea mine, likely British and from the mid-20th century, was found near a Gourock swimming pool on Monday.  As a precaution, residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors near walls with open windows, and three streets were evacuated until the early afternoon.  A half-mile sea exclusion zone disrupted some ferries.  The Royal Navy’s Northern Diving Unit moved the deteriorating mine to a safer location due to uncertainty about its explosive content.  Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the evacuation.

Team GB has been allocated £345m in funding across 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo Games.  This is £2m less than funding for the Rio Games.  The funding cuts include archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and cycling, with cycling's funding cut by more than £4m.  Badminton has had all of its funding removed, despite winning a bronze medal in Rio.  Judo, which also won a bronze in Rio, has received a slight funding increase.  UK Sport CEO Liz Nicholl stated that funding cuts were made to prioritize sports with strong medal potential.  Sports Minister Tracey Crouch supports UK Sport's approach, citing its success in past Olympic games.  Basketball, handball, and volleyball, whose funding was previously withdrawn, criticize UK Sport for a lack of investment in team sports.  Funding for new Olympic and Paralympic sports, including baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sports climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo, and Para-badminton, is yet to be determined.  UK Sport has set a target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals for Team GB in Tokyo.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth’s East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (seven and nine storeys, with 122 apartments).  Despite 49 resident objections, English Heritage’s disapproval, and concern over the loss of trees, the council approved the plans, citing the need to boost tourism and improve housing for the elderly.  246 letters of support were received.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, died after being punched and beaten by Jake Vallely, 24, in Brecon, Wales, on 8 May. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December.  Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of manslaughter. Pte Boyd, of the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was attacked while returning to barracks after a night out. CCTV footage showed Vallely punching, beating, and dragging Pte Boyd's body. Vallely had been drinking heavily and claimed to be the "hardest man in Brecon". Pte Boyd's family paid tribute to him, describing the attack as creating "a void in our family that will never be filled". They contrasted the community's outpouring of love with Vallely's claim about being the "hardest man in Brecon".

Andrew Travers, chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by mutual agreement after voters were turned away from all polling stations in the borough due to missing names from the poll list.  An independent investigation will review the incident and the arrangements for the EU Referendum.  Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily replace Travers.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored a free-kick to put Gateshead ahead. Sean Newton tied the game with a free-kick for Wrexham. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead, heading in a cross from Craig Baxter. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half performance and Bowman's goal. Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment, citing his team's second-half performance and missed chances.
The 2014 Global AgeWatch Index, ranking the social and economic well-being of older people in 96 countries, lists Norway as the best and Afghanistan as the worst, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb, in collaboration with Airbus, aims to provide global broadband internet access, particularly to schools, using a constellation of over 2,000 satellites.  To achieve this, they've developed a new high-volume, low-cost satellite production method using assembly lines similar to those in car and plane factories.  The first assembly line is in Toulouse, France, with two more planned for Florida.  They aim to launch the first ten satellites in April 2024, with more launches planned throughout 2024 and 2025 using Soyuz rockets.  While other companies have similar plans, OneWeb believes they have a first-mover advantage, having already raised $1.7 billion in equity.  The project faces regulatory oversight from the UK Space Agency, which will focus on debris mitigation. OneWeb has committed to de-orbiting old satellites within two years and using technology to remove failed satellites.  While this new manufacturing approach may disrupt the satellite industry, Airbus acknowledges that some specialized satellites will still require traditional production methods.

John Swinney, in anticipation of presenting Scotland's 2016-17 spending plans, criticized the UK government's spending review, citing "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure.  He argued that cuts imposed since 2010, including the latest review, will result in a 12.5% reduction in Scotland's discretionary budget by 2019-20, with 4.2% of that decrease occurring between now and 2019-20.  Mr. Swinney asserted that the UK government's cuts were unnecessary and pledged to protect key priorities like schools, hospitals, and police services. The UK government countered by stating that Scotland would have £390m more in spending next year, rising to £750m including Scotland's underspend, and emphasized the stability provided by the UK economy.  Labour's Jackie Baillie urged Mr. Swinney to present a long-term budget with a real alternative to austerity.

Many individuals with severe disabilities and their families face challenges due to the lack of Changing Places toilets, which offer enhanced accessibility features compared to standard accessible toilets.  Campaigners advocate for mandatory inclusion of Changing Places toilets in new building regulations for larger venues. While there are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, the need is much greater, potentially affecting over a quarter of a million people.  The absence of these facilities can lead to distressing situations and limit social participation. Although some venues have successfully incorporated Changing Places toilets, logistical and financial barriers hinder wider implementation.  Making these toilets compulsory in new builds is seen as a crucial step towards greater inclusivity.

Italian consumer groups have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald's of charging franchisees excessive rents and fees, resulting in higher consumer prices and poorer choices.  McDonald's says it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees, creating the best business opportunities for them and the best experience for customers.  The SEIU and European unions support the complaint and urge an investigation.  The European Commission will review the complaint and may launch an investigation. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's European restaurants.  McDonald's 2014 revenue from franchised restaurants worldwide was $9.27 billion.

13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve.  A social media hashtag, #prayforjosh, started by Bangor Elim Church has since gone viral, garnering support from people all over the world.  A mystery donor even paid for a billboard with the hashtag.  The hashtag began as a way for the church congregation to support Josh and his family but quickly spread globally via Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter.

The UK Ministry of Defence is reorganizing its military estate.  Brecon Barracks, in use since 1805, is slated for closure, a move condemned by MP Chris Davies. He cited the barracks' historical significance and the potential impact on the local economy, and launched a petition against the closure.  Approximately 85 civilian and 90 military personnel are stationed at Brecon Barracks, but jobs are not expected to be lost.  The Sennybridge training area and Dering Lines infantry school will remain open. Cawdor Barracks will close in 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot in 2025.  A new light infantry center will be created at St Athan. While supporting the restructuring, Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith expressed concern for the livelihoods of those affected by base closures.

Fishing communities, who largely supported Brexit, risk being marginalized in negotiations. While the UK fishing industry contributes minimally to GDP, the Lords EU Committee emphasizes its importance and the need for continued market access, potentially requiring UK fishing concessions to the EU.  The report advises maintaining some CFP elements, basing catch limits on scientific data, and international cooperation.  Concerns exist about potential fragmentation of fisheries management post-Brexit.  Despite these challenges, industry figures remain optimistic about regaining control over UK waters and improving fishing quotas. The government aims to maximize trade opportunities while ensuring fair quota access and a healthy marine environment.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA employee, leaked classified information revealing the extent of US surveillance programs. The NSA has access to vast amounts of personal data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, and social networking data.  The program, PRISM, allegedly allows backdoor access to servers of major tech companies like Google, Facebook, and Apple, though the companies deny involvement.  The NSA director claims the program is essential for national security, while some experts question its capabilities.  Data protection laws regulate how companies handle customer data but don't typically address government surveillance.  Governments argue that national security outweighs privacy concerns.  Data is often stored in different countries than the users, raising legal and jurisdictional issues.  The US Patriot Act grants US authorities access to European data stored in the US.  It is unknown whether other governments are involved in PRISM, but the EU is seeking clarification from the US.  Privacy advocates are concerned about the implications of these revelations for internet users.

OpenAI, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, is a new venture that aims to develop AI that benefits humanity.  While some, like Musk and Stephen Hawking, warn about the existential threat of AI, OpenAI believes it can be used for good.  The venture, unconstrained by financial obligations, will focus on safely distributing AI as broadly and evenly as possible.  Only a small portion of the pledged $1 billion will be spent initially.

L/Bdr Parkinson, injured in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26th.  His Facebook friend requests exceeded the 5,000 limit.  Despite losing his speech initially, he speaks unaided now, dedicating his time to rehabilitation, fundraising for military charities, and serving as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits.  His mother, Diane, noted the phenomenal response, with thousands joining the Pilgrim Bandits website and Ben's Facebook receiving numerous hits and messages.  Facebook suggests converting his profile to a public page or using the subscribe feature.  8,000 people will carry the Olympic flame on its journey to the opening ceremony.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate remained at 15%, equating to 46.2 million Americans, following three years of increases.  Real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021.  Income inequality rose for the first time since 1993, while the percentage of uninsured Americans dropped slightly to 15.7%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, extended his contract with Lancashire until 2019.  Buttler holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan.  Lancashire's cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent and contribution to the team's T20 Blast win. After playing in the Indian Premier League, Buttler will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates are moored in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting final bids from potential buyers.  While no proposals for preservation have been submitted, Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt hopes one frigate can be used as a reef and diving attraction.  The UK government wants at least one of the ships to be recycled in the UK to test the domestic industry's capacity.  A final decision on the ships' fate will be made in spring 2015.

Fiji has been plagued by racial and political tensions since 1987, leading to multiple coups and international isolation. Coups in 1987 and 2000 overthrew governments and harmed the economy. The 2006 coup resulted in Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth until democratic elections were promised and held in 2014.  Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing between the groups.  The economy relies on sugar and tourism, but trade and budget deficits persist.

Syria has missed the deadline to relinquish its chemical weapons stockpile. Though two shipments were sent to the Syrian coast, the second was attacked by terrorist groups.  The Syrian government denies accusations of bombing civilians in Aleppo, claiming they are defending against terrorist attacks.  They also deny reports that rebels seized Aleppo's central prison.  While roughly 4% of Syria's chemical weapons stockpile has been removed, Syria maintains it is committed to fulfilling its obligations.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize shortlist includes six authors: Howard Jacobson (J), Ali Smith (How To Be Both), Joshua Ferris (To Rise Again at a Decent Hour), Karen Joy Fowler (We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves), Richard Flanagan (The Narrow Road to the Deep North), and Neel Mukherjee (The Lives of Others). Mukherjee's book is favored to win.  This is the first year the prize is open to all authors writing in English. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday.

A celebrity, known as PJS, is appealing to the Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media regarding alleged extra-marital activities.  The Supreme Court will hear arguments and decide if the appeal should be granted, and if so, if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction preventing publication of PJS's identity remains in place until the hearing's conclusion. The Court of Appeal judges previously ruled that due to widespread online publication of the story, PJS was unlikely to obtain a permanent injunction.  The Sun on Sunday, which wants to publish the story, argued that the injunction was ineffective due to publications in other jurisdictions and online.  PJS maintains his right to privacy.

Fosse Park, purchased in August for Â£345.5m, has plans for improvement.  The new owners aim to address parking and traffic congestion, and enhance the overall appearance of the units, focusing on the "common areas" where people walk and park.  Blaby District Council leader, Ernie White, stated the owners view Fosse Park as an investment opportunity and wish to improve the view of the park as visitors enter the city.

Malaysia’s Censorship Board (LPF) approved the release of the live-action Beauty and the Beast film with a minor edit to a “gay moment.”  Although homosexual activity is illegal in the Muslim-majority country, the film was approved for screening with a P13 parental guidance classification.  The film’s release was delayed for a content review and a new release date is pending.  Local cinemas are offering refunds for advance ticket purchases.  The “gay moment” involves LeFou, Gaston’s sidekick, coming to terms with his feelings for Gaston.  The decision to review the film has drawn criticism online.

Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) in the area.  Landlords letting properties to more than three unrelated people need HMO licenses, costing £1,000, but many don't apply despite a potential £20,000 fine.  Shelter receives five or six daily calls about unregulated rented homes. Nationally, mandatory licensing applies to HMOs with three or more stories occupied by five or more unrelated people.  Southampton's licensing affects properties in designated areas introduced in 2013 and 2015.  While most landlords cooperate, some resist, resulting in prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

The Irish political parties Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are attempting to form a government.  Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government.  A major point of contention is water charges.  Fine Gael see a continued role for water charges, while Fianna Fáil want them abolished. Following the election two months prior, no party was able to form a majority government. The seat distribution was: Fine Gael, 50; Fianna Fáil, 44; Sinn Féin, 23; and Labour, 7.

The Italian ferry, The Sorrento, caught fire off the coast of Mallorca, Spain.  All passengers and crew were evacuated and rescued by another ferry. Three people were injured, one seriously, and taken to hospital. The cause of the fire, which started on a car deck, is unknown. The Sorrento may sink. Rescued passengers are returning to Palma de Mallorca.

A record 46.8 million people registered for the 8 June election, exceeding the 2015 election and EU referendum.  68.7% voter turnout was the highest since 1997.  2.9 million applications were received during the six-week period, and some constituencies saw their electorates increase by over 10%.  Duplicate applications, stemming from the lack of a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service, continue to be a concern.  Between December 2016 and May 22, approximately 4.9 million applications were submitted, but the net increase was only 1.4 million.  The Electoral Commission suggests clearer information on registration sites and a verification function.  Although 38 MPs reported potential double voting, which is a criminal offense, the claims lack evidence.  The Electoral Commission recommends cross-checking entries across the 381 electoral registers to reduce double voting risks and asks those registered in two locations to pre-select their voting constituency.  Labour's Cat Smith supports prosecution of double voters but cautions against measures that could hinder young people and students from registering.

40-year-old Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, is believed to have committed suicide early Wednesday morning while serving a 30+ year sentence.  He was facing a trial for the death of his cellmate, Damion Soward.  Phillips had a history of trouble on and off the field, including convictions for assault.  His college coach, Tom Osborne, noted Phillips' intelligence and good qualities, but also his struggles with anger.

Private Derby XXX, the Swaledale ram and mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for good behavior.  He is the 30th ram mascot since the mid-19th century and has served since 2014.  Private Derby has his own army number, gets paid, takes holidays during mating season, and has participated in events such as switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a dramatic Europa League match, overcoming a 2-0 deficit to advance to the semi-finals.  Inspired by the spirit of their 2005 Champions League comeback, Liverpool rallied with goals from Origi, Coutinho, Sakho, and a late winner from Lovren.  Klopp's influence was evident in the team's refusal to give up, embodying his philosophy of "We decide when it's over." While Liverpool's comeback was impressive, defensive vulnerabilities remain.  The victory fuels hopes of a Champions League return, either through a top-four finish or by winning the Europa League.  Klopp has instilled a winning mentality and fostered a strong connection with the fans, creating a special atmosphere at Anfield.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis reiterated the UK government’s commitment to keeping Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit negotiations via monthly meetings.  Scottish Brexit Minister Michael Russell welcomed the commitment but stressed the need for greater transparency regarding the UK’s strategic intentions, particularly concerning single market and customs union membership.  While both sides described the meeting as constructive, the Scottish government will oppose the UK government’s appeal to the Supreme Court regarding the triggering of Article 50.

Thirteen cloned sheep, including four (Debbie, Denise, Diane, and Daisy) cloned from the same ewe as Dolly the sheep (the first cloned mammal), live at a University of Nottingham farm.  Researchers are studying the sheep to determine if cloned animals age normally and remain healthy, addressing concerns about the cloning process potentially transferring “age-memory” and causing premature aging and age-related diseases. Dolly died at six-and-a-half from a virus and also suffered from osteoarthritis.  Researchers are comparing the thirteen sheep, along with nine others cloned from different cell lines, to the general sheep population, focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis.  Results of the study will be released soon, but currently, the sheep, approaching ages nine and ten, appear healthy.

Shutter Speed, the 4-7 favorite, won the Musidora Stakes, bringing a fifth win for trainer John Gosden and jockey Frankie Dettori.  She will race next in the French Oaks rather than the Epsom Oaks. Stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Epsom Oaks.  Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes.  Cracksman may not run in the Dante Stakes due to concerns over the ground.

The British pound initially fell against the dollar and euro before recovering mid-afternoon and falling again due to Brexit fears.  The uncertainty surrounding the referendum vote, with recent polls showing the Leave campaign ahead, has increased market volatility to 2008 financial crisis levels.  Investors are reacting to the polls, with some hedge funds short-selling the pound in anticipation of it falling further. While the Leave campaign argues the pound has strengthened since March, the markets are showing increasing concern, with Asian stock markets falling sharply and the FTSE 100 ending the day down 1.1%. A weaker pound could benefit UK exporters, as evidenced by the narrowing trade deficit in April.

Braintree Town lost to Barrow, extending their losing run to three games. Despite the loss, manager Cowley remained positive, acknowledging the team’s accomplishment as a part-time team facing a tough challenge. Barrow extended their unbeaten run to nine games and sit one spot ahead of Braintree in the National League.

Starting in April 2015, local councils in Northern Ireland will take over responsibility for most planning decisions.  This shift in power from the Planning Service to elected officials is viewed as a potential improvement to the planning system by some, like Michael Corr of PLACE, who believes it offers councils an opportunity to shape their communities. However, concerns exist regarding politicians' skills in urban regeneration and planning, as well as the potential for discrimination and unfairness, reminiscent of past issues with public housing allocation. Friends of the Earth emphasizes the need for a strict code of conduct and transparency, particularly given the history of close relationships between developers and political parties.  The debate also extends to the disclosure of political donations, with some arguing for greater transparency while others resist due to security concerns and the perceived irrelevance of donation limits in Northern Ireland.

In Winchburgh, a one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun, resulting in the amputation of one of her legs.  Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, discovered her injured and is concerned about the safety of children in the area. The Scottish SPCA is urging the public to come forward with any information and advocating for the licensing of air guns, a measure opposed by the majority of respondents in a recent government consultation.

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for an undisclosed fee, making him their second most expensive signing.  Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, is Liverpool's seventh signing this summer.  Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers hopes Benteke will improve the team's goal production following a disappointing prior season.  Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge believe Benteke will be a successful addition to Liverpool.

A study by Tablets for Schools, involving 671 schools, found that tablet use in schools is rising, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools currently using them.  Although there's no clear evidence of academic improvement, head teachers report positive impacts like increased student motivation and family involvement.  The study also highlighted the pervasiveness of technology in young people's lives, with many taking internet-connected devices to bed.  A separate study suggests touch-screen computers are helpful for boys and poorer pupils learning to read. One head teacher advocates for tablets, saying they empower students and reflect the modern world, although their impact on results is difficult to measure.

The Growing Up in the City exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 photographs spanning the 1880s to the 1990s, depicting the evolving lives of children and social history of Liverpool.  Curated by Kay Jones, the photos range from dressed-up children at a mayoral ball in 1887 to a child working as a maid around 1900, reflecting both happy and difficult childhood experiences. The exhibition runs until September 25th.

Myles Anderson, a 27-year-old center-back, left Barrow to join a rival National League team and could play against his former club on February 18th.  Ruairi Keating, a 21-year-old striker, also joined the Gulls.  The Gulls are four points above relegation and have struggled recently.

Bolivia passed a law allowing 12-year-olds to work with parental consent.  This reflects the country's economic realities, as over 500,000 children already work.  The law also increases penalties for violence against children, setting a 30-year sentence for child homicide. While the ILO recommends a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries, Bolivia's Vice-President argues the law addresses the country's specific needs.  The ILO is reviewing the law's compliance with international regulations.

Rosie O'Donnell, 50, experienced nausea, aches, and fever after helping a woman exit a car. Suspecting a heart attack, she took aspirin and saw a cardiologist the next day. The doctor placed a stent in her 99%-blocked artery. O'Donnell's online blog post revealed she'd searched "women's heart attack symptoms" and labeled the attack a "widow maker." Although she didn't call 911, she urged others to do so if experiencing similar symptoms.

Che Labastide-Wellington, 17, was stabbed at a party in Kenton on Saturday evening and died an hour later.  A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition.  Police said Che was invited to the party and was not involved in an earlier altercation with a group of youths denied entry.  A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder. Two boys, 15 and 16, were also arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed.  A 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark revamped its cancer diagnosis system to address alarmingly low survival rates compared to other European countries.  The previous system had long wait times, especially for patients with vague or difficult-to-diagnose symptoms.  The new system has three routes: 1) Fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with clear cancer symptoms; 2) Diagnostic centers for patients with unclear symptoms requiring a range of tests and scans; and 3) "Yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms needing simple tests or scans to rule out serious illness.  This system has improved organization and survival rates without overwhelming resources, demonstrating how collaboration between GPs and specialists can lead to better outcomes.

Powys County Council will take over responsibility from the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) for enforcing the Estate Agents Act.  They will receive £170,000 annually for the service, issuing warnings and bans to agents who violate the Act.  Local trading standards departments will still handle complaints and prosecutions, but will refer potential breaches of the Act to Powys.  Powys hopes this new responsibility will lead to more external contracts in the future.

Nurses are taking on tasks traditionally performed by doctors and pharmacists due to staff shortages.  A Nuffield Trust review, commissioned by NHS Employers, found nurses already filling in for other healthcare professionals.  While the report suggests such changes could improve patient care and offer staff more rewarding roles, unions warn against using this as a cheap fix for shortages and emphasize the need for proper training and funding.  The British Medical Association stresses the importance of doctors' expertise and experience, advocating for more support staff rather than replacements.

The Lower Bristol Road in Bath was closed at 03:00 GMT following a crash outside the First depot. The road reopened at 14:00 GMT.  Bus services and commuters experienced delays.  First bus services are mostly back to normal, but some delays remain.  A full service is expected by the evening commute.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimates that the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon project would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes these figures, claiming they lack scientific basis and that NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's own modeling estimates a 2% loss for all fish species in a worst-case scenario.  The Welsh Government supports the project but awaits the UK government's findings on its viability.  NRW stands by its assessment, citing extensive evidence, expert analysis, and a legal obligation to protect the Welsh environment.

Northern Ireland's Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of a new agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, to provide strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of government and private sector organizations.  Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, acknowledging the industry's need for better coordination of marketing activities, but noted potential implications for other organizations and her own department.

The Woodland Trust is inviting the public to plant trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon.  The project is part of a UK-wide initiative to plant millions of trees in remembrance of those lost in WW1.  40,000 trees will be planted at Brackfield Wood to commemorate the Irish lives lost.  Volunteers are encouraged to wear appropriate footwear and help create this lasting tribute.  The wood is located approximately seven miles outside Derry city, off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking available.

Hilary Mantel's "Someone Else's Skin" won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award.  Judge Alison Graham called the book "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story".  The book is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and tackles domestic violence and honor crime.  US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her work, including the creation of the female private investigator VI Warshawski.  Ann Cleeves, the festival's programming chair, praised both authors.

Mitchell Santner will return to Worcestershire for the 2017 season after his 2016 season was cut short due to a broken finger. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes said that Santner's injury was a major setback for the team.  Worcestershire also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring died in Kiev in 2008 after being hit by a speeding car with stolen plates as he hailed a taxi.  His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was 19 years younger than him and had gone back to a restaurant. The coroner ruled his death unlawful killing. Ziuzina attempted to claim his assets soon after his death, leading his family to suspect her involvement.  The inquest revealed Ziuzina was a lap dancer, not a teacher as she'd claimed, and had been having an affair.  Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry but reopened it as a murder investigation in 2011, though it is not actively pursued.

Charlie, a child from Merseyside, needs to return to Seattle Children's Hospital for experimental T-Cell Therapy not available in the UK. After a failed transplant and a third relapse, his family was left heartbroken. An anonymous donor has paid for his treatment, bringing immense relief to the family.  The hospital confirmed the donation on Wednesday, and treatment will begin as soon as possible, with the date expected next week.

Apple has implemented a new security measure to prevent third-party software from stealing photos from iCloud. This two-factor authentication tool requires users to enter a four-digit code, sent to a trusted device, when logging into a new device. Without the code, access to iCloud and purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store will be denied. A 14-character recovery key is provided if the trusted device is lost.  While previously available, this security feature was not active when using Apple's backup service, which allowed third-party software to bypass it.  One expert suggests Apple should make two-factor authentication the default, rather than optional.  Apple plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Mark Wright may buy 20% of Billericay Town Football Club and become a club director.  Currently, Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division.  Wright previously played non-league football.  The club's new owner, Glenn Tamplin, has stated he is "comfortable" investing £10,000 a week and recently signed Paul Konchesky.

Iain Wright, chair of the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, sent a letter to Mr. Ashley requesting he give evidence about his company's worker treatment following a BBC investigation.  Mr. Ashley has until March 21st to respond and agree to one of the offered dates to meet at Westminster.  Failure to comply may result in the committee seeking the support of the House of Commons regarding contempt. Sports Direct has not commented.

Ilya Yashin, along with colleagues of the murdered Boris Nemtsov, completed Nemtsov’s report, *Putin. War*.  The report alleges Putin initiated war in Ukraine for personal gain, citing evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment playing a key role in rebel victories.  It further claims that Russian generals directed battles and that volunteers were paid.  The report estimates Russia’s spending on the conflict at 53bn roubles.  Despite facing challenges with publishing and distribution, Yashin hopes the report will expose the truth about Russian involvement, which some Russians accept, believing it supports those seeking independence from Kyiv.  However, the opposition accuses Putin of using the war to boost his popularity.

Craig Nelson (also known as Craig Preston), 34, from Wath-Upon-Dearn, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire. A post-mortem determined his death was caused by head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, First Minister of Wales, criticized the UK government's handling of the Article 50 letter, stating Wales wasn't invited to contribute to the drafting process despite previous discussions with Prime Minister May.  While the letter mentions devolving powers back to Wales, Jones expressed concern over funding for these powers after 2020.  Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's approach, emphasizing the Prime Minister's consultations with Wales and the government's commitment to acting in the UK's best interests.  The specific powers to be devolved and their accompanying funding remain unclear.

Two cars were damaged in Newry on Friday night. Police stated they were attacked while “carrying out duties.”  Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin said he was appalled by the attacks on officers and the community.  Police appealed to parents to be aware of their children’s whereabouts and activities.

Dov Charney, founder of American Apparel, was ousted from the company amidst accusations of misuse of company funds and employee complaints, including sexual harassment and racial discrimination.  Mr. Charney is suing the company for defamation, while the company claims the accusations are true and that no company would hire him given the risk.  A restraining order prevents Mr. Charney from making negative statements about American Apparel in the press or attempting to remove board members.

Great Britain's men's basketball team plays Greece at the Copper Box Arena in London in a warm-up game before EuroBasket 2017. Coverage is available on BBC iPlayer, the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30-19:30 BST. It is GB's only home game before the tournament. Greece won the previous encounter 92-64 earlier this month, though three of their players will be absent for the game in London. After the Greece game, GB travel to Poland for a four-team tournament as their final preparation before EuroBasket 2017.

Before the iPhone was available to the public, a producer requested a piece on the new Apple phone.  The author located Apple’s marketing chief, Phil Schiller, and asked to see the iPhone. After filming a piece with the iPhone for the news, some viewers complained about the coverage of the product launch. The author defended the news coverage by stating that some products merit coverage due to their potential impact on how we live. The author now views the iPhone as a key transformative technology due to its powerful computer, disruption of industries, and how it changed photography and other activities.  Although there were camera phones before 2007, Steve Jobs's genius was realizing that an attractive user interface would encourage people to do more with their phones. The author expresses gratitude for witnessing this moment in history and acknowledges other firms, like Amazon and Google, for continuing to innovate.

Several cats have died from antifreeze poisoning near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire.  The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and urges residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, particularly antifreeze.  One cat owner, Adria Pearce, described her cat Meereen's death after consuming antifreeze.

Greece is expected to receive its third bailout of €86bn.  Holidaymakers are still visiting Greece, and there are no protests despite painful VAT increases, pension cuts, and anticipated farm subsidy reductions, privatizations, and increased competition.  Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and worsening the situation with monetary austerity.  Greek businesses are suffering due to the partial closure of banks.  For the bailout to work and lead to recovery, creditors need to ease the burden of Greece's debt.

Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell on EastEnders.  He decided to return after learning of Dame Barbara Windsor’s character Peggy Mitchell’s death.  Producers revealed Peggy Mitchell will die from cancer in the spring.  Kemp’s return will reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother one last time. He played Grant Mitchell from 1990-1999 and again in 2005 and 2006.

Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and murdered Alice Ruggles.  Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, suspected Dhillon immediately when police told them of Alice's death.  Dr. Hills feels guilt for reassuring Alice that she would be safe if she ignored Dhillon. Alice's sister, Emma, warned her mother that Dhillon was dangerous, but Dr. Hills dismissed her concerns.  Alice's parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking dangers and to celebrate Alice's life.  Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant, but the UK government delayed its final decision.  The plant is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity.  Concerns exist regarding environmental damage, escalating costs, foreign involvement (one-third of the cost is covered by Chinese investors), and EDF's financial capacity.  A board member resigned over financial risks, echoing earlier concerns from EDF's former finance director.  Greenpeace criticizes the project's value and calls for renewable energy investment.  The project has been in development since 2006, with construction approved in 2013 and a Chinese investment agreement signed in 2015.

A new divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the spouse committed adultery with.  Family lawyers say including a third party increases conflict, even though the form says it's not normally necessary and there's no obligation to do so.  The previous form had a space for "co-respondents" where appropriate, but the new form directly asks for the third party's name.  Naming the person makes them part of the court case, and if they don't respond, it can cause delays and increase costs.  Although many petitioners want to involve the third party, judges disapprove of this.  The Ministry of Justice says it's always been possible to name the person and there's no obligation to do so.

The forestry industry in Wales faces challenges balancing environmental goals with commercial timber production.  While the industry contributes significantly to the Welsh economy, there's been a substantial loss of commercial forest area since 2001.  The Welsh government promotes native broadleaf species and recreational access, while Confor, a forestry industry promoter, highlights the need for increased planting of commercial forests to meet demand and industry growth targets.  Confor argues that current environmental policies hinder commercial forestry, citing bureaucratic processes and insufficient planting rates.  The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social considerations in its forestry strategy.
A boy was seriously injured after being struck by a vehicle in Coatbridge around 4:40 pm near Langloan Primary School. He was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow.

Arctic Convoy veterans were awarded the Ushakov Medal by Russia for their service during WWII.
