The 2014 Global AgeWatch Index, ranking the social and economic well-being of older people in 96 countries, lists Norway as the best and Afghanistan as the worst, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb, in collaboration with Airbus, aims to provide global broadband internet access, particularly to schools, using a constellation of over 2,000 satellites.  To achieve this, they've developed a new high-volume, low-cost satellite production method using assembly lines similar to those in car and plane factories.  The first assembly line is in Toulouse, France, with two more planned for Florida.  They aim to launch the first ten satellites in April 2024, with more launches planned throughout 2024 and 2025 using Soyuz rockets.  While other companies have similar plans, OneWeb believes they have a first-mover advantage, having already raised $1.7 billion in equity.  The project faces regulatory oversight from the UK Space Agency, which will focus on debris mitigation. OneWeb has committed to de-orbiting old satellites within two years and using technology to remove failed satellites.  While this new manufacturing approach may disrupt the satellite industry, Airbus acknowledges that some specialized satellites will still require traditional production methods.

John Swinney, in anticipation of presenting Scotland's 2016-17 spending plans, criticized the UK government's spending review, citing "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure.  He argued that cuts imposed since 2010, including the latest review, will result in a 12.5% reduction in Scotland's discretionary budget by 2019-20, with 4.2% of that decrease occurring between now and 2019-20.  Mr. Swinney asserted that the UK government's cuts were unnecessary and pledged to protect key priorities like schools, hospitals, and police services. The UK government countered by stating that Scotland would have £390m more in spending next year, rising to £750m including Scotland's underspend, and emphasized the stability provided by the UK economy.  Labour's Jackie Baillie urged Mr. Swinney to present a long-term budget with a real alternative to austerity.

Many individuals with severe disabilities and their families face challenges due to the lack of Changing Places toilets, which offer enhanced accessibility features compared to standard accessible toilets.  Campaigners advocate for mandatory inclusion of Changing Places toilets in new building regulations for larger venues. While there are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, the need is much greater, potentially affecting over a quarter of a million people.  The absence of these facilities can lead to distressing situations and limit social participation. Although some venues have successfully incorporated Changing Places toilets, logistical and financial barriers hinder wider implementation.  Making these toilets compulsory in new builds is seen as a crucial step towards greater inclusivity.

Italian consumer groups have filed a formal complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald's of charging franchisees excessive rents and fees, resulting in higher consumer prices and poorer choices.  McDonald's says it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees, creating the best business opportunities for them and the best experience for customers.  The SEIU and European unions support the complaint and urge an investigation.  The European Commission will review the complaint and may launch an investigation. Franchisees operate 73% of McDonald's European restaurants.  McDonald's 2014 revenue from franchised restaurants worldwide was $9.27 billion.

13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve.  A social media hashtag, #prayforjosh, started by Bangor Elim Church has since gone viral, garnering support from people all over the world.  A mystery donor even paid for a billboard with the hashtag.  The hashtag began as a way for the church congregation to support Josh and his family but quickly spread globally via Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter.

The UK Ministry of Defence is reorganizing its military estate.  Brecon Barracks, in use since 1805, is slated for closure, a move condemned by MP Chris Davies. He cited the barracks' historical significance and the potential impact on the local economy, and launched a petition against the closure.  Approximately 85 civilian and 90 military personnel are stationed at Brecon Barracks, but jobs are not expected to be lost.  The Sennybridge training area and Dering Lines infantry school will remain open. Cawdor Barracks will close in 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot in 2025.  A new light infantry center will be created at St Athan. While supporting the restructuring, Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith expressed concern for the livelihoods of those affected by base closures.

Fishing communities, who largely supported Brexit, risk being marginalized in negotiations. While the UK fishing industry contributes minimally to GDP, the Lords EU Committee emphasizes its importance and the need for continued market access, potentially requiring UK fishing concessions to the EU.  The report advises maintaining some CFP elements, basing catch limits on scientific data, and international cooperation.  Concerns exist about potential fragmentation of fisheries management post-Brexit.  Despite these challenges, industry figures remain optimistic about regaining control over UK waters and improving fishing quotas. The government aims to maximize trade opportunities while ensuring fair quota access and a healthy marine environment.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA employee, leaked classified information revealing the extent of US surveillance programs. The NSA has access to vast amounts of personal data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, and social networking data.  The program, PRISM, allegedly allows backdoor access to servers of major tech companies like Google, Facebook, and Apple, though the companies deny involvement.  The NSA director claims the program is essential for national security, while some experts question its capabilities.  Data protection laws regulate how companies handle customer data but don't typically address government surveillance.  Governments argue that national security outweighs privacy concerns.  Data is often stored in different countries than the users, raising legal and jurisdictional issues.  The US Patriot Act grants US authorities access to European data stored in the US.  It is unknown whether other governments are involved in PRISM, but the EU is seeking clarification from the US.  Privacy advocates are concerned about the implications of these revelations for internet users.

OpenAI, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, is a new venture that aims to develop AI that benefits humanity.  While some, like Musk and Stephen Hawking, warn about the existential threat of AI, OpenAI believes it can be used for good.  The venture, unconstrained by financial obligations, will focus on safely distributing AI as broadly and evenly as possible.  Only a small portion of the pledged $1 billion will be spent initially.

L/Bdr Parkinson, injured in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26th.  His Facebook friend requests exceeded the 5,000 limit.  Despite losing his speech initially, he speaks unaided now, dedicating his time to rehabilitation, fundraising for military charities, and serving as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits.  His mother, Diane, noted the phenomenal response, with thousands joining the Pilgrim Bandits website and Ben's Facebook receiving numerous hits and messages.  Facebook suggests converting his profile to a public page or using the subscribe feature.  8,000 people will carry the Olympic flame on its journey to the opening ceremony.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate remained at 15%, equating to 46.2 million Americans, following three years of increases.  Real median household income decreased by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021.  Income inequality rose for the first time since 1993, while the percentage of uninsured Americans dropped slightly to 15.7%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, extended his contract with Lancashire until 2019.  Buttler holds the record for England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball century against Pakistan.  Lancashire's cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent and contribution to the team's T20 Blast win. After playing in the Indian Premier League, Buttler will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast game against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates are moored in Portsmouth Harbour awaiting final bids from potential buyers.  While no proposals for preservation have been submitted, Portsmouth North MP Penny Mordaunt hopes one frigate can be used as a reef and diving attraction.  The UK government wants at least one of the ships to be recycled in the UK to test the domestic industry's capacity.  A final decision on the ships' fate will be made in spring 2015.

Fiji has been plagued by racial and political tensions since 1987, leading to multiple coups and international isolation. Coups in 1987 and 2000 overthrew governments and harmed the economy. The 2006 coup resulted in Fiji's suspension from the Commonwealth until democratic elections were promised and held in 2014.  Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with minimal mixing between the groups.  The economy relies on sugar and tourism, but trade and budget deficits persist.

Syria has missed the deadline to relinquish its chemical weapons stockpile. Though two shipments were sent to the Syrian coast, the second was attacked by terrorist groups.  The Syrian government denies accusations of bombing civilians in Aleppo, claiming they are defending against terrorist attacks.  They also deny reports that rebels seized Aleppo's central prison.  While roughly 4% of Syria's chemical weapons stockpile has been removed, Syria maintains it is committed to fulfilling its obligations.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize shortlist includes six authors: Howard Jacobson (J), Ali Smith (How To Be Both), Joshua Ferris (To Rise Again at a Decent Hour), Karen Joy Fowler (We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves), Richard Flanagan (The Narrow Road to the Deep North), and Neel Mukherjee (The Lives of Others). Mukherjee's book is favored to win.  This is the first year the prize is open to all authors writing in English. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday.

A celebrity, known as PJS, is appealing to the Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media regarding alleged extra-marital activities.  The Supreme Court will hear arguments and decide if the appeal should be granted, and if so, if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction preventing publication of PJS's identity remains in place until the hearing's conclusion. The Court of Appeal judges previously ruled that due to widespread online publication of the story, PJS was unlikely to obtain a permanent injunction.  The Sun on Sunday, which wants to publish the story, argued that the injunction was ineffective due to publications in other jurisdictions and online.  PJS maintains his right to privacy.

Fosse Park, purchased in August for Â£345.5m, has plans for improvement.  The new owners aim to address parking and traffic congestion, and enhance the overall appearance of the units, focusing on the "common areas" where people walk and park.  Blaby District Council leader, Ernie White, stated the owners view Fosse Park as an investment opportunity and wish to improve the view of the park as visitors enter the city.

Malaysia’s Censorship Board (LPF) approved the release of the live-action Beauty and the Beast film with a minor edit to a “gay moment.”  Although homosexual activity is illegal in the Muslim-majority country, the film was approved for screening with a P13 parental guidance classification.  The film’s release was delayed for a content review and a new release date is pending.  Local cinemas are offering refunds for advance ticket purchases.  The “gay moment” involves LeFou, Gaston’s sidekick, coming to terms with his feelings for Gaston.  The decision to review the film has drawn criticism online.

Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMOs) in the area.  Landlords letting properties to more than three unrelated people need HMO licenses, costing £1,000, but many don't apply despite a potential £20,000 fine.  Shelter receives five or six daily calls about unregulated rented homes. Nationally, mandatory licensing applies to HMOs with three or more stories occupied by five or more unrelated people.  Southampton's licensing affects properties in designated areas introduced in 2013 and 2015.  While most landlords cooperate, some resist, resulting in prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

The Irish political parties Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are attempting to form a government.  Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government.  A major point of contention is water charges.  Fine Gael see a continued role for water charges, while Fianna Fáil want them abolished. Following the election two months prior, no party was able to form a majority government. The seat distribution was: Fine Gael, 50; Fianna Fáil, 44; Sinn Féin, 23; and Labour, 7.

The Italian ferry, The Sorrento, caught fire off the coast of Mallorca, Spain.  All passengers and crew were evacuated and rescued by another ferry. Three people were injured, one seriously, and taken to hospital. The cause of the fire, which started on a car deck, is unknown. The Sorrento may sink. Rescued passengers are returning to Palma de Mallorca.

A record 46.8 million people registered for the 8 June election, exceeding the 2015 election and EU referendum.  68.7% voter turnout was the highest since 1997.  2.9 million applications were received during the six-week period, and some constituencies saw their electorates increase by over 10%.  Duplicate applications, stemming from the lack of a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service, continue to be a concern.  Between December 2016 and May 22, approximately 4.9 million applications were submitted, but the net increase was only 1.4 million.  The Electoral Commission suggests clearer information on registration sites and a verification function.  Although 38 MPs reported potential double voting, which is a criminal offense, the claims lack evidence.  The Electoral Commission recommends cross-checking entries across the 381 electoral registers to reduce double voting risks and asks those registered in two locations to pre-select their voting constituency.  Labour's Cat Smith supports prosecution of double voters but cautions against measures that could hinder young people and students from registering.

40-year-old Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, is believed to have committed suicide early Wednesday morning while serving a 30+ year sentence.  He was facing a trial for the death of his cellmate, Damion Soward.  Phillips had a history of trouble on and off the field, including convictions for assault.  His college coach, Tom Osborne, noted Phillips' intelligence and good qualities, but also his struggles with anger.

Private Derby XXX, the Swaledale ram and mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for good behavior.  He is the 30th ram mascot since the mid-19th century and has served since 2014.  Private Derby has his own army number, gets paid, takes holidays during mating season, and has participated in events such as switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a dramatic Europa League match, overcoming a 2-0 deficit to advance to the semi-finals.  Inspired by the spirit of their 2005 Champions League comeback, Liverpool rallied with goals from Origi, Coutinho, Sakho, and a late winner from Lovren.  Klopp's influence was evident in the team's refusal to give up, embodying his philosophy of "We decide when it's over." While Liverpool's comeback was impressive, defensive vulnerabilities remain.  The victory fuels hopes of a Champions League return, either through a top-four finish or by winning the Europa League.  Klopp has instilled a winning mentality and fostered a strong connection with the fans, creating a special atmosphere at Anfield.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Brexit Secretary David Davis reiterated the UK government’s commitment to keeping Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit negotiations via monthly meetings.  Scottish Brexit Minister Michael Russell welcomed the commitment but stressed the need for greater transparency regarding the UK’s strategic intentions, particularly concerning single market and customs union membership.  While both sides described the meeting as constructive, the Scottish government will oppose the UK government’s appeal to the Supreme Court regarding the triggering of Article 50.

Thirteen cloned sheep, including four (Debbie, Denise, Diane, and Daisy) cloned from the same ewe as Dolly the sheep (the first cloned mammal), live at a University of Nottingham farm.  Researchers are studying the sheep to determine if cloned animals age normally and remain healthy, addressing concerns about the cloning process potentially transferring “age-memory” and causing premature aging and age-related diseases. Dolly died at six-and-a-half from a virus and also suffered from osteoarthritis.  Researchers are comparing the thirteen sheep, along with nine others cloned from different cell lines, to the general sheep population, focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis.  Results of the study will be released soon, but currently, the sheep, approaching ages nine and ten, appear healthy.

Shutter Speed, the 4-7 favorite, won the Musidora Stakes, bringing a fifth win for trainer John Gosden and jockey Frankie Dettori.  She will race next in the French Oaks rather than the Epsom Oaks. Stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Epsom Oaks.  Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes.  Cracksman may not run in the Dante Stakes due to concerns over the ground.

The British pound initially fell against the dollar and euro before recovering mid-afternoon and falling again due to Brexit fears.  The uncertainty surrounding the referendum vote, with recent polls showing the Leave campaign ahead, has increased market volatility to 2008 financial crisis levels.  Investors are reacting to the polls, with some hedge funds short-selling the pound in anticipation of it falling further. While the Leave campaign argues the pound has strengthened since March, the markets are showing increasing concern, with Asian stock markets falling sharply and the FTSE 100 ending the day down 1.1%. A weaker pound could benefit UK exporters, as evidenced by the narrowing trade deficit in April.

Braintree Town lost to Barrow, extending their losing run to three games. Despite the loss, manager Cowley remained positive, acknowledging the team’s accomplishment as a part-time team facing a tough challenge. Barrow extended their unbeaten run to nine games and sit one spot ahead of Braintree in the National League.

Starting in April 2015, local councils in Northern Ireland will take over responsibility for most planning decisions.  This shift in power from the Planning Service to elected officials is viewed as a potential improvement to the planning system by some, like Michael Corr of PLACE, who believes it offers councils an opportunity to shape their communities. However, concerns exist regarding politicians' skills in urban regeneration and planning, as well as the potential for discrimination and unfairness, reminiscent of past issues with public housing allocation. Friends of the Earth emphasizes the need for a strict code of conduct and transparency, particularly given the history of close relationships between developers and political parties.  The debate also extends to the disclosure of political donations, with some arguing for greater transparency while others resist due to security concerns and the perceived irrelevance of donation limits in Northern Ireland.

In Winchburgh, a one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times with an air gun, resulting in the amputation of one of her legs.  Her owner, Sarah Nisbett, discovered her injured and is concerned about the safety of children in the area. The Scottish SPCA is urging the public to come forward with any information and advocating for the licensing of air guns, a measure opposed by the majority of respondents in a recent government consultation.

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for an undisclosed fee, making him their second most expensive signing.  Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, is Liverpool's seventh signing this summer.  Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers hopes Benteke will improve the team's goal production following a disappointing prior season.  Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge believe Benteke will be a successful addition to Liverpool.

A study by Tablets for Schools, involving 671 schools, found that tablet use in schools is rising, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools currently using them.  Although there's no clear evidence of academic improvement, head teachers report positive impacts like increased student motivation and family involvement.  The study also highlighted the pervasiveness of technology in young people's lives, with many taking internet-connected devices to bed.  A separate study suggests touch-screen computers are helpful for boys and poorer pupils learning to read. One head teacher advocates for tablets, saying they empower students and reflect the modern world, although their impact on results is difficult to measure.

The Growing Up in the City exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 photographs spanning the 1880s to the 1990s, depicting the evolving lives of children and social history of Liverpool.  Curated by Kay Jones, the photos range from dressed-up children at a mayoral ball in 1887 to a child working as a maid around 1900, reflecting both happy and difficult childhood experiences. The exhibition runs until September 25th.

Myles Anderson, a 27-year-old center-back, left Barrow to join a rival National League team and could play against his former club on February 18th.  Ruairi Keating, a 21-year-old striker, also joined the Gulls.  The Gulls are four points above relegation and have struggled recently.

Bolivia passed a law allowing 12-year-olds to work with parental consent.  This reflects the country's economic realities, as over 500,000 children already work.  The law also increases penalties for violence against children, setting a 30-year sentence for child homicide. While the ILO recommends a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries, Bolivia's Vice-President argues the law addresses the country's specific needs.  The ILO is reviewing the law's compliance with international regulations.

Rosie O'Donnell, 50, experienced nausea, aches, and fever after helping a woman exit a car. Suspecting a heart attack, she took aspirin and saw a cardiologist the next day. The doctor placed a stent in her 99%-blocked artery. O'Donnell's online blog post revealed she'd searched "women's heart attack symptoms" and labeled the attack a "widow maker." Although she didn't call 911, she urged others to do so if experiencing similar symptoms.

Che Labastide-Wellington, 17, was stabbed at a party in Kenton on Saturday evening and died an hour later.  A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition.  Police said Che was invited to the party and was not involved in an earlier altercation with a group of youths denied entry.  A 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder. Two boys, 15 and 16, were also arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed.  A 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark revamped its cancer diagnosis system to address alarmingly low survival rates compared to other European countries.  The previous system had long wait times, especially for patients with vague or difficult-to-diagnose symptoms.  The new system has three routes: 1) Fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with clear cancer symptoms; 2) Diagnostic centers for patients with unclear symptoms requiring a range of tests and scans; and 3) "Yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms needing simple tests or scans to rule out serious illness.  This system has improved organization and survival rates without overwhelming resources, demonstrating how collaboration between GPs and specialists can lead to better outcomes.

Powys County Council will take over responsibility from the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) for enforcing the Estate Agents Act.  They will receive £170,000 annually for the service, issuing warnings and bans to agents who violate the Act.  Local trading standards departments will still handle complaints and prosecutions, but will refer potential breaches of the Act to Powys.  Powys hopes this new responsibility will lead to more external contracts in the future.

Nurses are taking on tasks traditionally performed by doctors and pharmacists due to staff shortages.  A Nuffield Trust review, commissioned by NHS Employers, found nurses already filling in for other healthcare professionals.  While the report suggests such changes could improve patient care and offer staff more rewarding roles, unions warn against using this as a cheap fix for shortages and emphasize the need for proper training and funding.  The British Medical Association stresses the importance of doctors' expertise and experience, advocating for more support staff rather than replacements.

The Lower Bristol Road in Bath was closed at 03:00 GMT following a crash outside the First depot. The road reopened at 14:00 GMT.  Bus services and commuters experienced delays.  First bus services are mostly back to normal, but some delays remain.  A full service is expected by the evening commute.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimates that the proposed Swansea tidal lagoon project would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes these figures, claiming they lack scientific basis and that NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's own modeling estimates a 2% loss for all fish species in a worst-case scenario.  The Welsh Government supports the project but awaits the UK government's findings on its viability.  NRW stands by its assessment, citing extensive evidence, expert analysis, and a legal obligation to protect the Welsh environment.

Northern Ireland's Enterprise Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of a new agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, to provide strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of government and private sector organizations.  Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement, acknowledging the industry's need for better coordination of marketing activities, but noted potential implications for other organizations and her own department.

The Woodland Trust is inviting the public to plant trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon.  The project is part of a UK-wide initiative to plant millions of trees in remembrance of those lost in WW1.  40,000 trees will be planted at Brackfield Wood to commemorate the Irish lives lost.  Volunteers are encouraged to wear appropriate footwear and help create this lasting tribute.  The wood is located approximately seven miles outside Derry city, off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking available.

Hilary Mantel's "Someone Else's Skin" won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award.  Judge Alison Graham called the book "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story".  The book is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and tackles domestic violence and honor crime.  US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her work, including the creation of the female private investigator VI Warshawski.  Ann Cleeves, the festival's programming chair, praised both authors.

Mitchell Santner will return to Worcestershire for the 2017 season after his 2016 season was cut short due to a broken finger. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes said that Santner's injury was a major setback for the team.  Worcestershire also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring died in Kiev in 2008 after being hit by a speeding car with stolen plates as he hailed a taxi.  His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was 19 years younger than him and had gone back to a restaurant. The coroner ruled his death unlawful killing. Ziuzina attempted to claim his assets soon after his death, leading his family to suspect her involvement.  The inquest revealed Ziuzina was a lap dancer, not a teacher as she'd claimed, and had been having an affair.  Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry but reopened it as a murder investigation in 2011, though it is not actively pursued.

Charlie, a child from Merseyside, needs to return to Seattle Children's Hospital for experimental T-Cell Therapy not available in the UK. After a failed transplant and a third relapse, his family was left heartbroken. An anonymous donor has paid for his treatment, bringing immense relief to the family.  The hospital confirmed the donation on Wednesday, and treatment will begin as soon as possible, with the date expected next week.

Apple has implemented a new security measure to prevent third-party software from stealing photos from iCloud. This two-factor authentication tool requires users to enter a four-digit code, sent to a trusted device, when logging into a new device. Without the code, access to iCloud and purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store will be denied. A 14-character recovery key is provided if the trusted device is lost.  While previously available, this security feature was not active when using Apple's backup service, which allowed third-party software to bypass it.  One expert suggests Apple should make two-factor authentication the default, rather than optional.  Apple plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Mark Wright may buy 20% of Billericay Town Football Club and become a club director.  Currently, Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division.  Wright previously played non-league football.  The club's new owner, Glenn Tamplin, has stated he is "comfortable" investing £10,000 a week and recently signed Paul Konchesky.

Iain Wright, chair of the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, sent a letter to Mr. Ashley requesting he give evidence about his company's worker treatment following a BBC investigation.  Mr. Ashley has until March 21st to respond and agree to one of the offered dates to meet at Westminster.  Failure to comply may result in the committee seeking the support of the House of Commons regarding contempt. Sports Direct has not commented.

Ilya Yashin, along with colleagues of the murdered Boris Nemtsov, completed Nemtsov’s report, *Putin. War*.  The report alleges Putin initiated war in Ukraine for personal gain, citing evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment playing a key role in rebel victories.  It further claims that Russian generals directed battles and that volunteers were paid.  The report estimates Russia’s spending on the conflict at 53bn roubles.  Despite facing challenges with publishing and distribution, Yashin hopes the report will expose the truth about Russian involvement, which some Russians accept, believing it supports those seeking independence from Kyiv.  However, the opposition accuses Putin of using the war to boost his popularity.

Craig Nelson (also known as Craig Preston), 34, from Wath-Upon-Dearn, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire. A post-mortem determined his death was caused by head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones, First Minister of Wales, criticized the UK government's handling of the Article 50 letter, stating Wales wasn't invited to contribute to the drafting process despite previous discussions with Prime Minister May.  While the letter mentions devolving powers back to Wales, Jones expressed concern over funding for these powers after 2020.  Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's approach, emphasizing the Prime Minister's consultations with Wales and the government's commitment to acting in the UK's best interests.  The specific powers to be devolved and their accompanying funding remain unclear.

Two cars were damaged in Newry on Friday night. Police stated they were attacked while “carrying out duties.”  Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin said he was appalled by the attacks on officers and the community.  Police appealed to parents to be aware of their children’s whereabouts and activities.

Dov Charney, founder of American Apparel, was ousted from the company amidst accusations of misuse of company funds and employee complaints, including sexual harassment and racial discrimination.  Mr. Charney is suing the company for defamation, while the company claims the accusations are true and that no company would hire him given the risk.  A restraining order prevents Mr. Charney from making negative statements about American Apparel in the press or attempting to remove board members.

Great Britain's men's basketball team plays Greece at the Copper Box Arena in London in a warm-up game before EuroBasket 2017. Coverage is available on BBC iPlayer, the BBC Sport website and app from 17:30-19:30 BST. It is GB's only home game before the tournament. Greece won the previous encounter 92-64 earlier this month, though three of their players will be absent for the game in London. After the Greece game, GB travel to Poland for a four-team tournament as their final preparation before EuroBasket 2017.

Before the iPhone was available to the public, a producer requested a piece on the new Apple phone.  The author located Apple’s marketing chief, Phil Schiller, and asked to see the iPhone. After filming a piece with the iPhone for the news, some viewers complained about the coverage of the product launch. The author defended the news coverage by stating that some products merit coverage due to their potential impact on how we live. The author now views the iPhone as a key transformative technology due to its powerful computer, disruption of industries, and how it changed photography and other activities.  Although there were camera phones before 2007, Steve Jobs's genius was realizing that an attractive user interface would encourage people to do more with their phones. The author expresses gratitude for witnessing this moment in history and acknowledges other firms, like Amazon and Google, for continuing to innovate.

Several cats have died from antifreeze poisoning near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire.  The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and urges residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, particularly antifreeze.  One cat owner, Adria Pearce, described her cat Meereen's death after consuming antifreeze.

Greece is expected to receive its third bailout of €86bn.  Holidaymakers are still visiting Greece, and there are no protests despite painful VAT increases, pension cuts, and anticipated farm subsidy reductions, privatizations, and increased competition.  Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and worsening the situation with monetary austerity.  Greek businesses are suffering due to the partial closure of banks.  For the bailout to work and lead to recovery, creditors need to ease the burden of Greece's debt.

Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell on EastEnders.  He decided to return after learning of Dame Barbara Windsor’s character Peggy Mitchell’s death.  Producers revealed Peggy Mitchell will die from cancer in the spring.  Kemp’s return will reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother one last time. He played Grant Mitchell from 1990-1999 and again in 2005 and 2006.

Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and murdered Alice Ruggles.  Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, suspected Dhillon immediately when police told them of Alice's death.  Dr. Hills feels guilt for reassuring Alice that she would be safe if she ignored Dhillon. Alice's sister, Emma, warned her mother that Dhillon was dangerous, but Dr. Hills dismissed her concerns.  Alice's parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking dangers and to celebrate Alice's life.  Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.

EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant, but the UK government delayed its final decision.  The plant is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity.  Concerns exist regarding environmental damage, escalating costs, foreign involvement (one-third of the cost is covered by Chinese investors), and EDF's financial capacity.  A board member resigned over financial risks, echoing earlier concerns from EDF's former finance director.  Greenpeace criticizes the project's value and calls for renewable energy investment.  The project has been in development since 2006, with construction approved in 2013 and a Chinese investment agreement signed in 2015.

A new divorce form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the spouse committed adultery with.  Family lawyers say including a third party increases conflict, even though the form says it's not normally necessary and there's no obligation to do so.  The previous form had a space for "co-respondents" where appropriate, but the new form directly asks for the third party's name.  Naming the person makes them part of the court case, and if they don't respond, it can cause delays and increase costs.  Although many petitioners want to involve the third party, judges disapprove of this.  The Ministry of Justice says it's always been possible to name the person and there's no obligation to do so.

The forestry industry in Wales faces challenges balancing environmental goals with commercial timber production.  While the industry contributes significantly to the Welsh economy, there's been a substantial loss of commercial forest area since 2001.  The Welsh government promotes native broadleaf species and recreational access, while Confor, a forestry industry promoter, highlights the need for increased planting of commercial forests to meet demand and industry growth targets.  Confor argues that current environmental policies hinder commercial forestry, citing bureaucratic processes and insufficient planting rates.  The Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social considerations in its forestry strategy.
A boy was seriously injured after being struck by a vehicle in Coatbridge around 4:40 pm near Langloan Primary School. He was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow.

Arctic Convoy veterans were awarded the Ushakov Medal by Russia for their service during WWII.  The convoys delivered supplies to the Soviet Union via a dangerous route, facing German attacks and harsh weather.  Over 3,000 men died during the campaign. Though initially blocked by the Foreign Office due to rules regarding foreign medals, an exception was made in 2013, allowing the veterans to receive the Russian honor.

HM Inspectorate of Probation found that offenders sentenced to community payback often started work late or failed to attend, and many faced no consequences.  Inspectors reviewed 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders, finding that some completed very few of their required hours. While some high-quality work and positive offender experiences were noted, the report issued 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing instances where offenders are turned away and better matching work to offender circumstances.  The chief inspector called for urgent action, criticizing the system's focus on punishment over rehabilitation.  The Ministry of Justice accepted the recommendations and stated their commitment to ensuring offenders attend and face consequences for non-compliance.

Comedian Russell Brand, known for advocating for economic and political "revolution" to aid the poor, faces accusations of hypocrisy due to his luxurious London home.  When confronted by a reporter about high London rents and his own housing costs, Brand dismissed the reporter as "snide."  He later tweeted about the accusations using #TheSunLogic.  Brand has addressed such criticism before, acknowledging his wealth and past mistakes, while emphasizing the need for both personal and systemic change. He argues that his wealth doesn't invalidate his concerns about economic inequality and ecological disaster.

Dr. J. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the mapping of the human genome, though his methods were criticized by some scientists.  After the human genome’s publication, he focused on creating synthetic life, culminating in Synthia, detailed in the journal *Science*.  Venter's Vietnam War experience instilled in him a sense of urgency. While at the National Institute of Health (NIH), he pioneered faster gene decoding methods, though his work was initially dismissed by some.  After leaving NIH due to funding issues, he founded The Institute for Genomic Research and later Celera Genomics, which raced the public project to map the human genome, publishing results simultaneously in 2001.  Though criticized for his approach to data access, Venter's financial success allowed him to pursue independent research, including creating the J. Craig Venter Institute and collecting marine life forms to study their genomes.  His creation of synthetic life has been controversial, but Venter believes it could revolutionize industry and help address environmental damage.

A survey of approximately 1,000 parents in England, commissioned by the School Food Trust, found 80% of children who ate school lunches had tried foods they hadn't eaten at home, and 50% of parents said their children requested foods from school meals to be made at home.  The research, in response to a Mumsnet survey about packed lunches, suggests school meals encourage children to try new foods.  Carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were less so.  Strict nutritional guidelines are now in place for English school meals.  About 40% of English primary school children eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools, and 46% in Scotland.

Álvaro Morata, 23, played for Real Madrid for four seasons before joining Juventus in 2014.  Real Madrid has a buy-back option, rumored to be €30m, for the striker, who scored 27 goals in two years with Juventus.  He also scored three times for Spain during Euro 2016.  Morata debuted with Real Madrid at 18, scoring 10 goals for them. He played in two Champions League finals — winning in 2014 with Real Madrid and scoring in Juventus’s 2015 loss.  He won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias with Juventus.

Kelvin Wilson, age 30, transferred from Celtic to Nottingham Forest for £2.5m in August 2013.  He was released in May and is currently without a team.  This was his second stint with Forest, having previously played there for four seasons before joining Celtic.  He has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third-largest retailer, is selling its unprofitable US chain Fresh & Easy to Yucaipa, saving approximately 4,000 jobs.  Tesco will loan the new business £80m and incur a £150m cost, part of which is a repayable loan.  Of the 200 Fresh & Easy stores, 50 will close.  Tesco retains the option to buy back a stake if the business becomes profitable.
Facing initial racial abuse, a martial artist, who briefly considered representing France, now aims for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.  A guide to getting into martial arts is available.

Glaciers in the French Alps have shrunk by about 26% over the last 40 years, decreasing from roughly 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to about 275 sq km in the late 2000s.  A new inventory, comparing maps, satellite images, and aerial photographs, shows the southern Alps experienced the greatest loss, with near-total disappearance in the Belledonne Massif.  Retreat is less significant in the northern Alps, likely due to higher elevation, more precipitation, and increased cloud cover. This information, presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting, reflects similar findings in other areas of the Alps.

Scotland’s women’s soccer team, undefeated in five World Cup qualifying matches, plays Iceland, also undefeated, in a two-leg series to determine the group winner.  Scotland is in a strong position to qualify for the 2017 finals in the Netherlands, even if they don’t win the group.  Lisa Evans, a forward for Bayern Munich, acknowledges the team is focused on qualifying for their first major tournament after two close calls.  Evans’ experience playing professionally in Germany has benefited her and, in turn, the national team.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint from a woman in her 30s regarding online harassment over a two-year period.  Campbell stated the allegations relate to some tweets from his account, which remain publicly visible and are not threatening.  He was released on bail and is due back in mid-September.

Peta proposed replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish and the slogan “Skegness - A Happy Plaice,” claiming the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty.  Skegness’s mayor stated the mascot is beloved and doesn’t portray animal cruelty, but the suggestion would be brought before the council.

Scotland defeated Georgia 43-16 in a rugby match.  Georgia scored first with a try by Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland quickly responded with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, and Sean Maitland. Stuart Hogg added another try before halftime, and Hamish Watson scored soon after the break.  Lobzhanidze got his second try for Georgia, but Hogg also scored his second, securing Scotland's victory.  Scotland's coach Vern Cotter praised his team's performance, particularly their first-half dominance and ability to counter-attack effectively.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38-30. Tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge gave Widnes a 14-6 halftime lead. Though Castleford scored early in the second half, Widnes pulled away with tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor, making it 38-12.  Castleford then scored three tries in four minutes, two by Larne Patrick and Luke Gale, and one by Paddy Flynn (his third). Widnes held on for the win.  Widnes moved to seventh place, one point behind Castleford, who remain in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from Guantanamo Bay after 12 years of detention.  A US review board concluded he was not a threat.  He was arrested in Pakistan in 2002, suspected of al-Qaeda/Taliban links, a charge he denies.  He will spend at least a year in a Kuwaiti rehabilitation center.  He is the first inmate freed since the May exchange of five Taliban detainees for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, reducing the Guantanamo population to 148.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One.  Thousands attended the dawn service at Hyde Park Corner and 400 people paraded to the Cenotaph for a wreath-laying ceremony. Services were also held at Westminster Abbey which included the singing of the Australian and New Zealand national anthems.  The Gallipoli campaign, the inspiration for Anzac Day, was an eight-month battle in Turkey resulting in heavy casualties. Afterward, King George V attended a service at Westminster Abbey in 1916.  Since then, Anzac Day services in London have become important for expatriates and visitors from Australia and New Zealand.

Leigh Clarkson, age 30, rejoined Premiership Well for his second spell in July.  He may make his debut playing for St Mirren in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday.  Clarkson scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has mainly been a substitute this term.  He has been training, playing games, and keeping his match fitness up so he is ready to play.  Clarkson has two Scotland caps from 2008 with one international goal and has made almost 400 senior appearances.  His previous teams include Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren are currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of last place Alloa.  Clarkson states that every game is a big game, and winning more games will boost confidence and push St Mirren up in the standings.

Bernard Matthews was sold to Ranjit Boparan.  Existing worker agreements and pension schemes will be honored.  The final salary pension scheme closed in 2004 and current members have an alternative scheme unaffected by the takeover.  Boparan plans to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability through investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken.

The Cowes chain ferry has been beset with problems since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency.  The council has ordered an audit of the project and is offering free crossings until 2 July.  Local businesses have raised concerns about the impact of the ferry’s troubles on their trade and requested compensation, a matter currently under consideration by the council.  While acknowledging the "frustrating and disappointing start", Councillor Ian Ward characterized the situation as "teething problems" with a prototype, citing electrical issues and groundings as examples of problems that have been resolved.

Fishing communities, who largely supported Brexit, are concerned about being marginalized in negotiations. While the UK fishing industry contributes minimally to the GDP, its future hinges on Brexit negotiations.  The industry wants control over UK waters and to increase fish exports, but continued access to EU markets is crucial.  This access may require concessions, such as allowing EU boats into UK waters.  The report recommends maintaining elements of the CFP, including science-based quotas and catch limits.  Concerns exist about potential fragmentation of fisheries management across the UK. Despite these challenges, the industry remains optimistic about a future outside the EU, citing recent quota increases as a positive sign. The government aims to maximize trade opportunities for British companies while ensuring fair quota access and sustainable fishing practices.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, was removed from the teaching register for possessing indecent images of children.  The images, collected over a decade, depicted young boys in erotic poses. Geaney was sentenced to a community payback order, participation in a sex offender program, and placed on the sex offender registry.  The General Teaching Council Scotland panel deemed his behavior incompatible with the teaching profession, citing the volume of images, duration of the offense, and lack of remedial action as indicators of potential recurrence.  Geaney is prohibited from reapplying for registration for two years.

A large fire at a waste recycling site run by Asset and Land Group for Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited in Duncan Street on March 2nd caused travel disruptions.  Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) found the site operators to be generally compliant with fire safety laws, despite raising concerns to the Environment Agency (EA) in February. Following the fire, the EA suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s permit to accept waste and revoked their environmental permit, effective August 7th, pending appeal.  The company must remove all waste. The fire's cause is unknown.

Syria, despite setbacks, maintains its commitment to eliminating its chemical weapons stockpile, citing attacks on shipments to Latakia.  While denying the use of barrel bombs against civilians in Aleppo, Syria claims it's defending against terrorists, accusing the US of supporting these groups.  Disputing reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, Syrian state media says forces repelled the attack, while other sources claim rebel control.  Although behind schedule, with only 4% of the chemical stockpile removed, Syria insists it will fulfill its obligations.

England defeated Pakistan by an innings and 120 runs in the second Test at Old Trafford to level the four-match series 1-1.  Joe Root was named man of the match, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second.  Root's performance, described by Alastair Cook as "as good an innings as I've seen," followed two poor dismissals in the first Test.  Pakistan's batting struggled throughout the match, failing to pass 234 in either innings, with captain Misbah-ul-Haq admitting their shot selection cost them. While England celebrated their dominant victory, Michael Vaughan predicted a tight series.  Pakistan will play a two-day tour game against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August.

The Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is reviewing the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales.  She is gathering evidence from pensioners and their families to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies.  The review will highlight both good and poor care while examining factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment.  Care Forum Wales supports the review’s aims but notes the advisory panel lacks a care provider expert.

Paul Sheerin, former Dons midfielder, has been appointed as the new manager at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper.  Sheerin became player-manager at Arbroath in 2010, leading them to their first national trophy and promotion in 2011.  Arbroath were relegated to League Two after finishing bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season.  Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated that Derek McInnes selected Sheerin after a thorough search.  Arbroath chairman, John Christison, understood Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen.  Sheerin played for various Scottish clubs, Östersunds in Sweden, and also earned a Scotland Under-21 cap.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth.  Swansea’s first choice for new manager is Paul Clement.  Curtis believes Swansea lost their way after Michael Laudrup left in 2014 due to constant management changes. He also questions whether departing players have been adequately replaced.  Curtis believes the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation and reminds new signings of the club's history and the importance of staying in the Premier League.

Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, sped up the mapping of the human genome, though his methods were criticized by some scientists.  After publishing the human genome, he focused on creating synthetic life, culminating in Synthia, after over a decade of work.  Venter's experience in the Vietnam War instilled in him a sense of urgency. While at the NIH, he pioneered faster gene decoding methods, though his work was initially dismissed by some.  Due to criticism and lack of funding, he left the NIH to found The Institute for Genomic Research and later Celera Genomics, where he unveiled the first complete genome of a free-living organism and worked on cracking the entire human genetic code.  Though his methods were controversial, the financial rewards allowed him to pursue independent research, including creating the world's first synthetic life form and collecting marine life forms to further understand gene and protein function.  Venter believes synthetic microbes could revolutionize industry and help address environmental damage.

In England, the quality of apprenticeships is low and their numbers are too few compared to other European countries like Germany, which has a better vocational education system.  A report by the Sutton Trust, based on research by the Boston Consulting Group, suggests that England has too many short, low-level apprenticeships for those over 25, while Germany has more high-level apprenticeships geared towards younger people.  The report recommends increasing the number of higher-level apprenticeships to boost the economy and youth job prospects, focusing on level three apprenticeships lasting at least three years. While the Association of Colleges agrees with some points, they caution that increasing apprenticeships significantly would be challenging and some respected level two apprenticeships should remain.  The Department for Education states that reforms are underway to raise apprenticeship standards.

Sarah Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, won the UCI Para-cycling Road World Cup time trial in Nottwil, Switzerland, her 21st world title across cycling and swimming.  She finished over two minutes ahead of second place and will compete for her 17th cycling world title in Saturday’s road race.  Storey has 22 Paralympic medals (11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze) across six Paralympic Games.  She began her career as a swimmer, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, and switched to cycling in 2005.  She is aiming for further Paralympic success at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Games.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference for failing to pay football creditors £148,000.  Several extensions were granted, the final deadline being June 12th.  Chester FC, relegated on the final day of the season by a late Hereford goal, has been reinstated.  Hereford fans, players, and former manager Martin Foyle are significantly impacted.  The club's financial troubles stem from falling attendance and debts of approximately £225,000, including an outstanding £70,000 owed to HMRC.  A takeover bid from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust was rejected in favor of businessman Tommy Agombar, but ultimately failed to resolve the financial issues.

James Milner, age 30, retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England, participating in two World Cups and two European Championships, and scoring one goal during his career.  He debuted in 2009, played briefly in Euro 2016, and also holds the record for most England Under-21 caps (46).

Christopher Hogwood, a leading figure in the early-music movement, died at home in Cambridge after a months-long illness.  He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it for 30 years and producing over 200 CDs, including Mozart’s symphonies on period instruments and a renowned 1980 recording of Handel’s Messiah.  Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and worked with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields. He held several artistic director and academic positions.  Tributes praised his generosity, influence on historically informed music, and legacy.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream school in June because he was not coping.  His family requested a place for him at a special school, but all the schools are full.  The Education Authority is reviewing the need for special school places and working to ensure places are available closer to where children live. They could not comment on individual cases.

Newport County’s lease at Rodney Parade runs until 2023, and the club expects the terms to be honored should the Welsh Rugby Union’s takeover bid of fellow tenants Newport Gwent Dragons be successful.  The WRU plan to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules.  Relegation to the National League would be a massive blow to Newport County, who can secure League Two survival this weekend with a win and Hartlepool loss.

A Sierra Leonean man recounts his experience as a child soldier during the civil war, his rehabilitation, and his work during the Ebola crisis.  Abducted at 15 by RUF rebels, he was forced into violence and drug use.  He eventually escaped, found help through a preacher and the Lifeline Nehemiah project, and dedicated himself to rebuilding the nation. During the 2014 Ebola crisis, he and other volunteers educated communities, provided food, and established an Ebola treatment unit, saving many lives.  Now, he focuses on investing in young people to create positive change in Sierra Leone and the world.  Sierra Leone experienced 3,955 probable, confirmed, and suspected Ebola deaths.

The Wedgwood Museum's collection of 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs was at risk of being auctioned to cover the pottery firm's pension debt. However, a public fundraising campaign reached its target in a month, saving the collection.  The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will loan it to the Wedgwood Museum.  This ensures the collection, deemed historically significant to Britain's cultural development, will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire.

Mark Wright may buy 20% of Billericay Town Football Club and become a club director.  Currently, Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division.  Wright previously played non-league football.  The club's new owner, Glenn Tamplin, said he was "comfortable" investing  £10,000 a week in the club and recently signed Paul Konchesky.

Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool in the 12th minute. Kurtis Guthrie tied the game for Colchester United after 17 minutes. Colchester's Sean Murray received a red card for a bad tackle in injury time. The match ended 1-1.

The Fawley Power Station chimney, decommissioned in 2013 after over 40 years of operation, will become the tallest structure south of London's Shard as part of a £1bn “merchant city” development.  The project will include a petal-shaped glass structure around the chimney, housing, restaurants, a marina, and fast ferry connections to Southampton and Portsmouth.  Building is expected to commence in 2018.

Great Britain’s Mark Latham won bronze in the men’s scratch race at the UCI Track Cycling World Championships in Hong Kong. Latham finished behind Poland’s Adrian Teklinski, who won gold, and Germany’s Lucass Liss, who took silver.  In other events, Britain's Joe Truman was eliminated in the men's keirin semi-final, the women's team pursuit finished fifth, and Katy Marchant was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round.  Elinor Barker earned a silver medal in the women's scratch race. The British men’s team pursuit squad was beaten by Italy for the bronze medal.

Ross Kemp will briefly reprise his role as Grant Mitchell in EastEnders.  He decided to return after learning of Dame Barbara Windsor’s final episodes as Peggy Mitchell, who will die from cancer in the spring.  Kemp’s return will reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother one last time. He played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005 and 2006.

Sadio Mané scored two goals in under three minutes for Liverpool, defeating Tottenham.  Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino stated that the team’s lack of desire to win, especially in the first half, made it difficult to compete for the Premier League title.  Pochettino further emphasized the difficulty of challenging for the title if they cannot handle the pressure, especially given that a Chelsea win would put them 12 points ahead.  Former Liverpool and Tottenham midfielder, Danny Murphy, commented on Tottenham’s surprising defensive performance, noting their usual strong record but uncharacteristic disorganization in this match. He suggested they should have used their usual back three against top-tier teams, citing their contrasting home and away performances and a lack of pace and different mindset as contributing factors to their away struggles.

Nigeria's All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in the latest election, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP).  The PDP's loss is attributed to voters' desire for change after 16 years of PDP rule, allegations of corruption, and the party's failure to curb the Islamist insurgency in the northeast.  While the APC secured key wins in northern states and Lagos, it failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for incoming president Muhammadu Buhari.  Although marred by some violence, the elections were deemed more peaceful than previous years.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), held in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from July 19-22, will feature acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean.  A new augmented reality app will allow attendees and fans worldwide to access online content such as videos and band interviews, buy tickets, and experience the festival's atmosphere.

Ofsted rated Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary as inadequate and will terminate their funding agreements.  Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were also rated inadequate and warned of potential funding loss.  Park View Educational Trust may lose control of these schools.  A head teacher at one of the schools reported parent interference and pressure.  Ofsted published 21 reports on schools allegedly targeted for hardline Muslim takeover, five of which were rated inadequate.  The education minister cited concerns about Park View's management and failure to promote pupils' development.  Park View will challenge the Ofsted report.  Oldknow and Golden Hillock must address issues like unfavorable treatment of non-Muslims and curriculum imbalance.  Ofsted's chief noted a culture of fear and intimidation in Birmingham schools.  Park View allowed a guest speaker with extremist views to address students. Parents criticized Ofsted's reports and accused inspectors of bias.

In Ipswich Crown Court, Honey Rose, a 35-year-old eye specialist, pleaded not guilty to a charge of gross negligence manslaughter.  The prosecution argues that Rose failed to detect swollen optic discs and refer Vinnie Barker for further investigation during a routine eye test in February 2012.  This failure, the prosecution says, led to a preventable death five months later because the undetected condition caused fluid build-up and increased pressure in Barker's skull.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he found via an adult website and filming them.  He also sent a sexually explicit clip of the victim to her sister and father.  He was placed on the sex offenders register and the case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing.  Weatherhogg, a first offender, was assessed as posing "a moderate risk" of sexual re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 against Afghanistan in the first T20 match in Greater Noida. Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) led Afghanistan to victory at 171-4 with two overs remaining.  Ireland captain William Porterfield believed they were 15 runs short of a winning score.  Paceman Boyd Rankin missed the match due to a back injury but is expected to return for the ODI series.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, but with additional fees, the cost is £106.8m.  Amidst accusations of misappropriated funds and investigations into the transfer, Barcelona made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to defend their reputation, while maintaining their original tax payment was correct.  The case's status remains unclear.  This season, Neymar has 7 goals in 18 league appearances and 3 goals in 7 Champions League matches.

David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found dead on a Koh Tao beach on September 15.  Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are being held by Thai police, and allegedly confessed to the killings.  UK detectives traveled to Thailand to review the investigation and will be returning to the UK to compile a report for the families.  The suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery.  DNA found on Ms. Witheridge matched samples from the suspects.  The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns regarding the investigation, specifically about DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of the suspects.  Mr. Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Miss Witheridge died from head wounds.

Scotland’s women’s soccer team, undefeated in five World Cup qualifying matches, plays Iceland, also undefeated, in a home match that could secure their spot in the 2017 finals in the Netherlands.  Forward Lisa Evans, playing for Bayern Munich in Germany, believes that having more Scottish players in competitive leagues abroad strengthens the national team.  She cites the German league as being one of the most competitive and believes it has improved her play.  Evans, along with other teammates playing outside of Scotland, hope to qualify for a major final for the first time.

Apple has implemented a new security measure to prevent third-party software from stealing photos from iCloud. This two-factor authentication tool requires users to enter a four-digit code, sent to a trusted device, when logging into a new device.  A 14-character recovery key is provided if the trusted device is lost. While previously available, this security feature was not active when using Apple’s backup service, which allowed third-party software to bypass it. One expert suggests Apple should make two-factor authentication the default, rather than optional.  Apple CEO Tim Cook says the company plans to encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

In the 2014 European Parliament elections, UKIP spent £2,956,737, Conservatives spent £2,980,815, Lib Dems spent £1,580,575, and Labour spent £1,027,339.  The figures cover January 23rd to May 22nd.  Per vote, spending was: UKIP 68p, Labour 26p, Conservatives 79p, Lib Dems £1.45, and Green Party 43p.  The top six parties spent a total of £9,347,087.  All but Labour spent more than in the 2009 election.

Kyle Anderson, a 27-year-old center-back, left Barrow to join a rival National League team and could play against his former club on February 18th.  Ruairi Keating, a 21-year-old striker, joins the Gulls, pending international clearance.  The Gulls’ manager, Kevin Nicholson, describes Anderson as a needed leader and Keating as a raw but hungry young player.  The Gulls are four points above relegation, having won only one of their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old racehorse, died after winning the Cotswold Chase.  He collapsed and was pronounced dead after receiving veterinary care. The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed the cause of death was a severe pulmonary hemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur in horses without underlying health issues. Although Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling), he exhibited no such symptoms after Saturday's race.  The BHA is determined to further investigate the causes and prevention of such incidents.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick, Alex Salmond, and Duncan McNeil are stepping down as MSPs.  Mr. Salmond believes that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse” and that the parliament should assume greater responsibility for Scotland's governance.  Mr. McNeil warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster’s committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny.  Annabel Goldie joked that she would miss her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens the Beast, and Luke Evans will play Gaston in the live action version of Beauty and the Beast.  Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle’s father, and Emma Thompson will play Mrs. Potts.  Josh Gad will play LeFou, Gaston’s sidekick. The film will be directed by Bill Condon and released in the US on March 17, 2017. Filming begins in May at Shepperton Studios.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision regarding potential charges related to the Hillsborough disaster at a meeting with victims' families.  Ninety-six fans died in the 1989 tragedy.  Files relating to 23 suspects, 15 from the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and eight from an inquiry into police conduct, were submitted to the CPS.  Families hope for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison residents were informed of “numerous incidents” of packages being thrown over the prison walls.  A resident living near the prison stated she had witnessed this occurring four times in two weeks.  A former inmate claimed drones were used to fly contraband into the prison; however, the Ministry of Justice reported no evidence of drone use at the Chelmsford site.  The Ministry of Justice acknowledged more work was needed to prevent contraband from entering prisons and stated new laws allow for a two-year prison sentence for smuggling packages over prison walls.

72-year-old Sylvia Blackburn, a lollipop lady for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December.  Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving.  He acknowledged hitting Blackburn and expressed remorse for his actions.  The jury heard that Wright ran a red light, hitting Blackburn as she escorted a woman and child across the road.  Wright stated he did not see the lights due to the sun and only heard the impact. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to veterinary medicine exams.  She plans to compete in the 2018 World Indoor Championships in March.  At the 2017 World Athletics Championships, Muir placed fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m, achieving a personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the latter.  She believes she has at least two or three more Olympics in her future.

In December 2000, 22-year-old Trevor Deely disappeared after a Christmas party.  A renewed search effort began Saturday in a wooded area beside the R112 near the River Liffey in Chapelizod, Dublin.  Enhanced CCTV footage shows Deely speaking to a man in black outside his workplace at the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he had returned to retrieve an umbrella.  Police believe this same man was later seen following Deely on Haddington Road and have appealed for him to come forward.

Juan Martín del Potro defeated Stan Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 in the second round of Wimbledon.  Del Potro, returning after a two year absence due to injury, is ranked 165th and will play Lucas Pouille or Donald Young in the next round.  Nick Kyrgios also advanced, defeating Dustin Brown in five sets, and will face Feliciano Lopez in the third round.  Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also secured victories.

Tunisia and Morocco will participate in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations.  Tunisia had faced expulsion for complaints about the officiating in the 2015 quarter-final, but apologized to the Confederation of African Football (Caf).  Morocco’s participation was reinstated by the Court of Arbitration for Sport after Caf banned them for refusing to host the 2015 tournament.  The two teams learned their qualifying group opponents after the draw in Cairo.

McLaren, a historically dominant Formula 1 team with 182 grand prix wins and numerous championships, has struggled since 2013.  Initially, chassis design was the issue, but now the Honda power-unit is the problem.  This is ironic, as McLaren achieved its greatest successes, including a 15-win season in 1988, with Honda.  After several years of decline, McLaren saw a resurgence with Mika Hakkinen in 1998-99, winning their last constructors' title in 1998.  Despite scoring the most points in 2007, they were disqualified from the constructors' championship due to a scandal involving Ferrari technical information.  Another scandal, "lie-gate," followed in 2009.  Victories continued until 2012, but titles remained elusive.  McLaren's history has been cyclical, with periods of dominance and decline.  Ron Dennis, who has overseen both successful and challenging periods, returned to the team after the 2013 season.  Dennis believes McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and Alonso rejoined the team in 2015, hoping for a third title.

On October 6, 2014, police discovered patrons still at Joe's Bar in Dungiven past legal serving hours, with receipts indicating alcohol sales as late as 04:49 BST.  License holder Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours.  The judge, noting O'Neill's "appalling record," ordered a three-month closure of the bar and issued fines of £3,000 for O'Neill and £1,000 for Thomas.

Stephen Curry set a new NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season (276), scoring 45 points in the Golden State Warriors' 116-105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers.  Klay Thompson added 26 points for the Warriors.  For Portland, LaMarcus Aldridge scored 27 points and Damian Lillard had 20.  Elsewhere, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78. Pau Gasol had 16 points and 15 rebounds for Chicago, while Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds for Miami.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were tricked into believing that YouTube free-kick specialist Bas Van Velzen was a competition winner.  Van Velzen pretended to be an amateur, but then impressed the players with his skills.  He enjoyed surprising the players and seeing their reactions.  The experience was a dream come true for Van Velzen.

A study of 676 breast cancer patients with the BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation indicates that having an oophorectomy (ovary removal) after a breast cancer diagnosis significantly reduces the risk of death.  Specifically, BRCA1 carriers who had the procedure saw a 62% drop in breast cancer death and a 73% reduction in death if the ovaries were removed within two years of diagnosis. The 20-year survival rate for the entire group was 77.4%. While the study showed no benefit for BRCA2 carriers, oophorectomy was associated with a 65% reduction in death from all causes.  The protective effect lasted for 15 years. More research is needed on the impact of oophorectomy performed within a year of diagnosis and for BRCA2 carriers.

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were struck and killed by a northbound Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina, on Easter Sunday.  The train, carrying 166 passengers, was delayed for nearly three hours.  No passengers were injured, though one received treatment after falling ill.  A man who knew the couple said they may have been homeless.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia. He was promised US citizenship in exchange for his service, during which he helped take down cartel leaders and dictators.
