A hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land for development of a racetrack, with developers offering 320 hectares of replacement land.  Experts disagree on whether the project will damage habitats.  Natural Resources Wales hasn't opposed development, but noted difficulty in comparing land value.  Developers claim a net biodiversity gain, while the Gwent wildlife trust disagrees.  The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation to Welsh government ministers for a final decision.

Following a report in Novaya Gazeta that over 100 suspected homosexual men were detained and at least three killed in Chechnya, Chechen Muslim clerics called for retribution against those who insult their faith and the dignity of Chechen men.  Novaya Gazeta urged Russian authorities to prevent actions inciting hatred and enmity towards journalists.  Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, stating there are no gay people in Chechnya.  The Chechen spiritual leader confirmed the call for retribution.  Novaya Gazeta's editor stated they did not intend to insult the Chechen people and will continue investigating human rights abuses.  The LGBT Network is helping people flee persecution and may file a case with the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to act.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, operate from the same location and are run by the same individual.  Fresh Start refers homeless clients to Investing Solutions, which houses them in properties, often with subpar conditions. Investing Solutions receives housing benefits for each tenant, totaling more than the rent paid to landlords, generating substantial profit.  One tenant, after working for Investing Solutions, noted their focus on profit over tenant well-being.  A homeless charity criticizes this agency-charity relationship.  While Investing Solutions claims they pass most rent to landlords and are concerned about property conditions, Fresh Start avoids disclosing how many clients are housed through Investing Solutions.  Wandsworth Council, a significant contributor to Investing Solutions' income, states they have teams ensuring safe and affordable housing.  The Department for Communities and Local Government emphasizes local authorities' responsibility for safeguarding taxpayer money.

Great Britain lost to the Netherlands 78-72 in their final warm-up game before the Eurobasket qualifying tournament.  Ben Gordon scored 13 points, including three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter.  Andrew Lawrence added 14 points.  GB led for most of the first three quarters but the Netherlands went on a 10-0 run in the fourth quarter to take the lead and secure the win. Coach Joe Prunty was pleased with Gordon's performance and emphasized the importance of consistent effort throughout the qualifying games.

Conor McGregor submitted a waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to wear 8oz gloves instead of the required 10oz gloves for his 154 lbs fight against Floyd Mayweather.  The NAC will publicly debate the matter on August 16th.  Mayweather had previously stated he would wear 8oz gloves, but had not filed the required waiver.  NAC rules mandate 10oz gloves for fights above 135 lbs, with an exception for fights between 135-147 lbs if both fighters agree and the commission approves.  The NAC executive director cited McGregor's youth, reach advantage, power, and Diaz's assessment of McGregor's boxing skills as justification for approving the fight.  He also noted Mayweather's decade-long lack of a knockout victory. McGregor hired Hall of Fame referee Joe Cortez, who described McGregor's sparring as "out of control."

The final two journalists working on Fleet Street, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith of the Sunday Post, are leaving as the paper closes its London office.  Fleet Street, once the center of British journalism and home to nearly every national paper, began its decline in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to Wapping.  The street was known for its lively pub scene and old-fashioned newsrooms, a stark contrast to its current state.  Though the era of Fleet Street has ended, its legacy continues to impact former journalists like Sherriff and Smith.

J.K. Rowling donated £1 million to the No campaign during the Scottish independence referendum and the same amount to the Labour party in 2008. Following criticism and abusive comments from people she believed to be SNP supporters, she stated that she felt no responsibility to protect the image of any political party by hushing up such behavior.  Rowling also noted that she had interacted with other SNP supporters and found common political ground.

Children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action than more affluent children who commit the same crime.  Poverty also increases the likelihood of violence among both genders, with boys being three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts.  Poorer youth are five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision.  Those living in extreme poverty are much more likely to be both victims and perpetrators of crime.  A history of trouble with the police is the strongest predictor of a young person not being in education, employment, or training by age 18.  Despite an overall fall in crime rates, the most deprived communities continue to experience the highest crime rates, often coinciding with areas experiencing chronic health problems and unemployment.

25-year-old Karl Haugh was stabbed to death in Kilkee, Ireland on Sunday. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm and remanded in custody. Two other men were arrested and released without charge. Police allege Walsh was one of three men who entered the Marian Estate looking for Haugh. A fight ensued involving weapons, during which Haugh was stabbed in the back.  He later died in hospital.  A knife handle and blade were recovered at the scene.  Due to tensions in Kilkee following the killing, Walsh was remanded in custody.

MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted about UDR veteran and MP Tom Elliott in 2014, alleging harassment and shootings of people.  Elliott, who has a clear MoD record, sued Flanagan.  Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and issued an apology admitting the tweet was untrue.  He must also tweet the apology.  The judge has not yet determined compensation.  Flanagan’s insurance company refused coverage, leading to a separate court action. Elliott stated he felt vindicated.

Hawick Knitwear, purchased in November by managing director Benny Hartop, has increased production from 7,500 to 9,500 sweaters per week due to increased demand for both private label products and their own brand launched in January.  The company, established in 1874 and employing over 230 staff, sells to various markets in Europe, the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan.  Mr. Hartop is optimistic about the company's future, attributing success to dedicated staff.

72-year-old Sylvia Blackburn, a lollipop lady for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, last December.  Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun, and while admitting he hit Blackburn, denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving.  The jury heard that Wright's car failed to stop for a red light as Blackburn escorted a woman and child across the road.  Blackburn is now in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

NATO is conducting anti-submarine warfare exercises in response to increased Russian submarine activity.  A German U-boat, U33, is playing the role of the enemy in the exercise, which involves 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland.  The exercise highlights the difficulty of detecting submarines and the growing concern over Russia's advanced submarine technology. Russia has a fleet of approximately 60 submarines, considered the quietest and most challenging in the world.  The exercise, named "Dynamic Mongoose," utilizes various methods for detection, including helicopters, underwater drones, and a French Atlantique maritime patrol aircraft.  The exercise underscores a vulnerability for the UK, which lacks its own maritime patrol aircraft and relies on NATO allies for support in detecting Russian submarines in its waters. This vulnerability is considered a serious concern, particularly regarding the security of the UK's nuclear deterrent.

Due to ongoing violence in South Sudan, 340,000 South Sudanese refugees have fled to Uganda in 2016—more than any other country, including Syria.  Refugees report killings, rapes, and ethnic targeting.  The violence, originally between the Dinka and Nuer tribes, has spread to the Equatorians.  Uganda is struggling to support the massive influx of refugees, particularly supplying water and providing enough land.  Despite the hardships, refugees are planting crops, attending school, and trying to rebuild their lives.  The international community is urged to intervene in the South Sudanese conflict.

Liam McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle on November 12th at York Hall for the English super-middleweight title.  McKenzie, son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and trained by three-time world champion Duke McKenzie, turned pro in 2013 after quitting football.  His record is 8-0-1.

Bridgwater Community Hospital, built in 1813, will be replaced by a new £33m facility.  The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray, and space for mobile scanners. Funding comes from a £330m national investment, NHS Somerset, and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust.  The current hospital is outdated, with temperature control and maintenance issues.  The new hospital is expected to be completed by autumn 2014, pending planning permission for the Bowers Lane location.

A man was fatally shot in the chest while in or near his black Mercedes on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, Sheffield, around 1:35 GMT.  He was taken to Northern General Hospital, but later died. The victim was reportedly a member of a local family and relatives had gathered for a celebration when the shooting occurred. Though there have been other recent shootings in Sheffield, they have all been located in the north of the city, unlike this incident.

Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International are the most recognized virtual warriors in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine.  Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are pro-Ukraine and use DDoS attacks to disrupt rebel websites and funding.  They also monitor CCTV systems and hijack network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, disrupts Ukrainian military plans by hacking government websites and electronic billboards.  They also leak confidential documents and claim to have disrupted electronic vote-counting systems.  Anonymous International publishes leaked Kremlin documents, sometimes covering Ukraine, and is currently blocked in Russia.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, Alex Salmond, and Duncan McNeil delivered their farewell speeches to the Scottish Parliament. Mr. Salmond reflected on Scotland's journey, emphasizing the country's diversity and the parliament's growing responsibility. He also reiterated his belief that the Scotland Bill didn't fulfill referendum campaign promises. Mr. McNeil cautioned Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system, while Ms. Goldie humorously mentioned she would miss her interactions with John Swinney.  Ms. Marwick became emotional during both Mr. McNeil's and Mr. Salmond's speeches.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is reviewing the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales.  She is gathering evidence from pensioners and their families to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies.  While she has observed positive impacts of high-quality care, she has also received correspondence concerning unacceptable variations in care quality.  The review will assess factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment.  Care providers, social care staff, and public bodies will also be consulted. The Chair of Care Forum Wales, while supporting the review's aims, expressed disappointment at the lack of a care provider expert on the advisory panel.

Harbro Group's pre-tax profit increased by £800,000 to £3.5m in the year ending June 2016, despite a £1m drop in turnover to just over £100m. International sales grew in Europe and new markets.  While the agricultural outlook is difficult to predict and the last 12-18 months have been challenging, Harbro's board is confident about the group's positioning post-Brexit.

A man in his 70s was found dead in Little Gaddesden on Saturday. Police are treating the death as murder and are searching for 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) in connection with the crime.  Another man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Police have warned the public not to approach McLoughlin but to contact them with any information regarding his whereabouts.

The IMF's latest assessment of the global economy reveals a weakening baseline, according to David Lipton.  Weaker than anticipated trade figures from China, showing a 25% drop in exports, contribute to this analysis.  The IMF will likely downgrade its current global growth forecast of 3.4% in April.  This has ramifications for businesses and industries reliant on China's growth.

The Cowes chain ferry has been beset with problems since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency.  The council has ordered an audit of the project and is offering free crossings until 2 July.  Local businesses have raised concerns about the impact of the ferry’s troubles on their trade and requested compensation, a matter currently under consideration by the council.  While acknowledging the "frustrating and disappointing start", the council maintains the issues are typical teething problems with a new prototype and are being addressed.

A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene of a multi-vehicle crash on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at approximately 7:30 GMT on Thursday.  A 33-year-old Waterlooville man was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The Thursley to Liphook section of the road was closed until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, a London temp agency, advertised for a personal assistant with specific physical attributes, sparking outrage and accusations of sexism and unlawful discrimination. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) plans to contact the agency, while women's equality campaigners criticize the ads as outdated and discriminatory.  The agency's founder defends the practice, citing client preferences, while an employment lawyer confirms the illegality of such ads.  The EHRC asserts that prioritizing physical attributes over qualifications is unacceptable and discriminatory.  The agency's website states the importance of "right people representing your company", while also claiming it's "almost politically incorrect" to request attractive and skilled workers.  The 2010 Equality Act prohibits discrimination based on various attributes, including age, sexual orientation, and physical characteristics unless essential for the job.  The agency's founder explains a client's specific cup size request as relating to a designer outfit, and mentions another client's preference for blonde, blue-eyed Greek women.  Matching Models boasts clients such as MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods, highlighting MTV's preference for models with tattoos and piercings.

An office assistant at a Bangalore school, Mahesh, is accused of shooting two 18-year-old students, Gautami (fatally) and Sirisha (injured).  He was arrested Wednesday after a manhunt and remanded until April 12th.  While gun crime in Indian schools is rare, a similar incident occurred in Delhi in 2007.

Glaad’s study counted 278 LGBT regular and recurring characters on broadcast, cable, and streaming series shown or to be shown between June 2016 and May 2017.  While the number of transgender characters increased from 7 to 16, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off.  There was also a record high percentage of black characters.  While Glaad’s president was encouraged by this progress, she noted that numbers are “only part of the story”.

Conservative MP David Mackintosh will not seek re-election following accusations of wrongdoing related to a loan of public money to Northampton Town Football Club.  While leader of the borough council, Mackintosh oversaw the loan for stadium redevelopment, of which £10.25m is now missing and under police investigation.  Facing a likely deselection vote by his local party, Mackintosh stated it was time for new representation.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old ex-policeman, shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards as he drove away from a party. Oliver was fired and indicted for murder, as well as four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon for the other teens in the car.  He faces 5 to 99 years in prison, but no trial date is set.  While the police initially claimed the car reversed aggressively, video footage showed it driving away.  A conviction would be the first for murder of a police officer in Dallas County since 1973.

Melania and Barron Trump will move into the White House after he finishes the school year.  This has drawn criticism, as most First Ladies reside in the White House, with Martha Washington and Anna Harrison being the only exceptions.  However, some support the decision, citing Barron's age.  This isn't unusual; Frances Folsom Cleveland primarily lived in a separate house, and children often stayed behind to finish school.  The Obamas moved to Washington early so their daughters could start school before the inauguration.  Melania's decision suggests she may not take on the full First Lady role.  The role is largely ceremonial, but recent First Ladies have supported various causes.  There is precedent for other family members taking on First Lady duties, such as Martha Jefferson Randolph and Angelica van Buren.  Chelsea Clinton also performed some duties while Hillary Clinton focused on her political career.  Life in the White House can be surprisingly normal, with families like the Obamas and Clintons prioritizing family dinners and time together.

A 72-year-old man died on October 27th in Inverness, at a sheltered housing complex.  The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) is investigating the police response to the man's call prior to his death.  Police Scotland awaits the findings.

A yellow wind warning was issued for seven counties in Wales, including Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys, with gusts of up to 75 mph (120kmph) possible, especially west of the mountains.  Disruption to road and sea travel is likely.  A fallen tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey closed Telford Road for most of Monday.

The Giants and Panthers tied 2-2 after the first period with goals from Walser (Giants), Dimmen (Panthers), Forney (Giants), and Bohmback (Panthers).  Radja and Desmarais scored for the Giants in the second period, and Ling scored one for Nottingham, making it 4-3.  The teams play again on Saturday.  Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield with 27 and Belfast with 25.

Lewis Hamilton, starting from the back, suffered a broken front wing, multiple pit stops, and damage to his car, hindering his performance in the Chinese Grand Prix. He finished seventh.  Sebastian Vettel and Kimi Raikkonen collided, but recovered to finish second and fifth, respectively.  Nico Rosberg won the race, extending his lead over Hamilton in the championship.  Daniel Ricciardo led initially but a puncture forced him to pit, ultimately finishing fourth.  Kvyat's aggressive first-lap maneuver, which Vettel criticized, resulted in a podium finish for Kvyat.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, the most prominent footballer to publicly reveal his homosexuality, announced he was gay to advance discussion of the topic, which has been ignored in German football.  His former teammates, Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, praised his decision.  Support also came from German football administration, including Theo Zwanziger, former president of the German Football Association, and Reinhard Rauball, Bundesliga president.  Gary Lineker, Joseph Barton, John Amaechi, and Bayern Munich also tweeted support.  Hitzlsperger's announcement is a watershed moment in Germany, where homophobia in football is a problem.  Zwanziger admitted that open discourse about homosexuality isn't a given in football.  German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman, Steffen Seibert, praised Hitzlsperger, stating that "nobody should be worried about making his sexuality known."  Openly gay German politician Volker Beck hopes this encourages others to come out, and Zwanziger is optimistic about greater openness in German football.

Steve Sidwell, 34, has played 32 Championship games this season, helping Brighton get promoted to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years.  His contract expires at the end of the season, but he hopes to sign a new deal to play in the Premier League next year.  He played for Brighton on loan from Stoke in 2015-16 before signing a one-year deal in June 2016.  He believes his performance warrants a new deal.

Blackpool and Colchester United tied 1-1.  Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool in the 12th minute, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Kurtis Guthrie tied the game for Colchester United, scoring after a corner kick in the 17th minute.  Colchester’s Sean Murray received a red card for violent conduct in injury time.

Colchester United signed 29-year-old midfielder Alex Reid.  He made 37 appearances last season for Coventry City.  Reid could make his Colchester debut against Aston Villa in the EFL Cup. Colchester lost their first match of the season 3-1 against Accrington.

A permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum is planned to honor fallen police officers and staff, spurred by PC Keith Palmer's death.  The memorial will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff and provide a place for remembrance.  A brass screen with leaf shapes will offer personal memorials for families.  The project needs £4m, with £1m coming from the government and £1.5m sought by the UK Police Memorial Trust. It is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United beat Sunderland 1-0, leaving them 15 points ahead of Manchester City with eight games left.  They are focused on winning the next game, especially the upcoming derby against City.  Manager Alex Ferguson is pleased with the team's performance, particularly their 25 wins in 30 matches.  He plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea.  Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley will likely return to the lineup.

Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011.  Google Chairman Eric Schmidt insists Google’s tax payments are legal and comply with current UK tax law.  He stated that it is up to the UK government to change the laws if they want companies to pay more taxes.  Margaret Hodge suggested a new committee oversee the tax arrangements of major firms.  Google routes most of its UK sales through Ireland and has been criticized for minimizing the taxes it pays in the UK.  EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through information exchange between tax authorities.  Schmidt argues that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity takes place, not where products are consumed, and has called for international tax reform.

NHS Improvement aims to reduce agency staff spending by £1bn by the end of the financial year.  A cap limiting hourly rates to 55% above normal shift rates (excluding senior managers) has saved £600m. While progress is promising, NHS trusts are still 10% behind target.  Concerns remain about spending on bank staff, overtime, and exceptionally high agency worker earnings.  "League tables" of agency spending by trusts and data on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust will be published to address these issues.

Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland's economic boom, now represents its crash.  Local businesses, like Matt O'Brien's menswear shop, have suffered but are finding ways to adapt and see signs of improvement.  The opposition party, Fianna FÃ¡il, criticizes the government's investment in water meters instead of broadband and the lack of Industrial Development Authority's engagement with Longford.  The government highlights the planned Center Parcs tourism development, expected to create 1,000 jobs, as a sign of progress.  However, local traders suggest further action, such as eliminating parking charges, to stimulate the local economy. While there are signs of recovery in the Midlands, more needs to be done.

Eight teams will compete until May 29th.  The top four teams will qualify for the play-offs.  Warner leads in runs scored (294) and tied for most sixes (12).  De Kock has the highest score in an innings (108).  McClenaghan has taken the most wickets (9).  Four English players will participate.  See the provided schedule for fixtures and results.

Due to a large increase in plastic carrier bag usage, and the subsequent environmental problems this causes, people in England will have to pay 5p for each plastic bag they use.  Similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland have already proven effective. Campaigners hope this will encourage reuse and help the environment.

High winds across Wales on Friday, December 23, 2022, caused school roof damage, power outages for hundreds of homes, train and ferry cancellations and delays, speed restrictions on bridges, and the closure of two National Trust sites. The winds eased by Friday evening, allowing bridge restrictions to be lifted. Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip has been postponed until Tuesday, December 27, 2022.
Michael B. Jordan will star in the film *Black Panther*, directed by Ryan Coogler, alongside Lupita Nyong’o and Chadwick Boseman.  The film will be released in February 2018.

Alexandra Palace, including its theatre and BBC studios, is undergoing a £26.6m restoration project, funded by a £18.8m Heritage Lottery Fund grant, £6.8m from Haringey Council, and £1m from the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust.  The project aims to reopen the theatre in 2018 for diverse performances and transform the Palace into a cultural destination, with the glazed east court becoming a public and exhibition space.  The theatre, unused for decades, retains much of its original decor and stage machinery.

James Milner, 30, retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England, playing in two World Cups and two European Championships.  He debuted in 2009 and scored one goal during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers against Moldova.  He also holds the record for most England Under-21 caps, with 46.

The Smith family’s house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador burned down after some rubbish in the wood stove caught fire. The fire alarm did not go off. David Smith, the son, was awake and saw the flames, waking up his mother and sister. The family escaped with only their pyjamas, losing their pets in the fire.  The community has been supporting the family with donations of clothes, shoes, and a bike for David.  Mrs. Smith credits her son with saving her and her daughter’s lives.

Energy drinks giant considers £200m offer for West Ham United. Current owners Sullivan and Gold bought the club in 2010 for £105m and now own over 85%.  West Ham has also been linked with Qatari and Chinese takeover bids. Sullivan previously stated that a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, but he and Gold intend to pass ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards, held in Los Angeles, celebrated fan-voted awards such as best kiss and best shirtless performance (won by Efron). *The Fault in Our Stars* won best movie, with Shailene Woodley winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss (with Ansel Elgort). Other winners included Bradley Cooper (best male performance), Channing Tatum (best comedic performance), and Meryl Streep (best villain). The ceremony also promoted upcoming summer blockbusters, including *Pitch Perfect 2*, *Trainwreck*, and Marvel's *Ultron*.

St Mirren obtained 21-year-old Cammy Smith on loan from Dundee United. Smith, who debuted for Aberdeen in 2012, has also played for Scotland's Under-21 team.  St Mirren manager Jack Ross expressed his excitement about the acquisition.

Northumberland County Council will use Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months, now that the weather is warmer.  Additional staff will repair drainage systems and clear gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework.  Although the exposure was below the level requiring reporting to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), EnQuest notified them.  A subsequent investigation led to additional precautionary measures.  One contractor, Steve Innes, expressed concern over long-term health effects and criticized EnQuest's handling of the incident.  Wood Group affirmed their commitment to employee safety and cooperated in the investigation.  Unite union representative John Boland criticized the treatment of the workers, while the HSE confirmed awareness of the incident but stated it didn't warrant an investigation under existing regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a statue of Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 in 2007 from Art of the Past, whose manager later confessed to selling stolen Indian antiquities.  Although there is no definitive proof the statue was stolen, ACM is returning it to India after their government requested it.  ACM bought 30 objects from the dealer, but the others are not believed to be stolen, though the Archaeological Survey of India was allowed to view them. ACM plans to take legal action to recoup their losses.

A 4.8 magnitude earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, with tremors felt as far as Milan and Florence.  No injuries or damage were immediately reported. The quake's epicenter was in Garfagnana, causing power outages and downed phone lines, prompting school evacuations.  While deemed a "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow," classic quake for the area by the INGV, it follows two deadly quakes in the same area last May and the 2009 L'Aquila quake, for which officials were convicted of manslaughter for providing falsely reassuring statements prior.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, has successfully grown bananas in South Yorkshire, despite his initial doubts about the climate's suitability. The fruit is not yet ripe enough to eat.

Grand Theft Auto V’s PC release has been delayed from January 27th to March 24th, 2015 for additional testing and polish.  However, online heists are coming to consoles before the PC release.  The PC version will support resolutions up to 4K, frame rates of 60fps, and triple monitor setups. Minimum PC specifications have been released.

76-year-old artist, Simpson, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his painting, Squint (19).  Simpson, previously shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, described the win as "very nice indeed". Judge Ansel Krut called the painting "quite extraordinary" and "a little bit like a tone poem".  The painting depicts a leper squint, a hole in medieval churches for the undesirable to observe services.  Simpson will use the prize money for art supplies.

In Istanbul, the offices of two pro-government newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked almost simultaneously.  Four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building and started a fire which was quickly extinguished.  Gunfire shattered windows at both locations, and police found numerous bullet casings. No casualties were reported.  Police are investigating, but no group has claimed responsibility yet.

24-year-old joins the Mariners on a free transfer from the Stags. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances.  This is Bignot's first signing for the team, official January 1st.

Arsène Wenger, whose contract expires in the summer, has been linked to the England manager position, but says he is focused on his job at Arsenal.  Gareth Southgate, England's interim manager, will have two more matches to prove he deserves the job permanently. Wenger believes Southgate has the experience and skills required, and that competency is more important than a “big name.”  Wenger also confirmed that Arsenal will offer Hector Bellerin a new contract amidst transfer rumors, stating that Bellerin’s future is at Arsenal.  Finally, Wenger stated that Aaron Ramsey will be out for another one or two games with a hamstring injury.

A man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 1:45 pm GMT on Thursday.  Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are jointly investigating the incident, and the company is cooperating.

A new charter arrangement will end the dispute over low pay for some seafarers working on two Northern Isles freight boats.  The vessels will return to operator Serco Northlink from next month, resolving the issue of some workers being paid less than £4 an hour.  The change will ensure all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink was awarded the six-year £243m Northern Isles contract in 2012.

64-year-old Ken Dickie died six days after an altercation with his partner's son, 35-year-old Jamie Mitchell, at Rockley Park in Poole. Mitchell admitted intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother.  He and his mother, 57-year-old Samantha Mitchell, also admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying to the police about the incident.  Initially, they claimed Mr. Dickie pushed Mrs. Mitchell, and she pushed him back. Later, Jamie Mitchell admitted to pushing the couple apart, causing what he called a "tragic accident."  Jamie Mitchell was found guilty of manslaughter, while both he and his mother await sentencing.

Rod Temperton, songwriter of Michael Jackson hits including Thriller and Rock With You, died in London at age 66 after a brief battle with cancer.  Temperton also wrote Boogie Nights for his own band, Heatwave, and songs for artists such as Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson.  His private funeral has already taken place.  He was known as "The Invisible Man" for his low profile.  Inspired by listening to Radio Luxembourg as a child, Temperton began his career after answering an ad in Melody Maker magazine. He joined Heatwave, and after leaving the band in 1978, was recruited by Quincy Jones to write for Michael Jackson's breakthrough album, *Off The Wall*.  He also wrote for the album *Thriller*, which became the best-selling album of all time in the US.  Temperton won a Grammy in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986.

A team of researchers, including Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott of Swansea University, discovered 2,000-year-old earthworks—over 450 geometrical "geoglyphs"—in the western Brazilian Amazon. The function of the geoglyphs is unclear, as few artifacts have been found, and their layout doesn't suggest a defensive purpose.  Soil analysis suggests they were built amongst tall vegetation, unlike similar ritual sites like Mayan pyramids or Stonehenge.  Prior to European arrival, Amazonian forests were thought to be pristine, but this research indicates humans cultivated diverse plant species over 6,000 years, concentrating on valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket," and potentially influencing the biodiversity of Acre's forests today.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, beat Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes in the first round of the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios said he was "bored" and "tired" during the match, citing his recent win at the Japan Open, poor sleep, and the long commute to the stadium as contributing factors. Last year, Kyrgios was fined at the same tournament for inappropriate language.

HPV is sexually transmitted and causes 5% of the global cancer burden.  The HPV vaccine protects against cervical cancer and head and neck cancers. Currently, girls aged 12 and 13 in Wales receive the vaccine. Charities and medical organizations are urging the Welsh government to extend the vaccine to boys.  While 85% of girls in Wales have been vaccinated, the Welsh government is awaiting recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.  Head and neck cancer cases are increasing, especially in younger men (average age 55) who are non-smokers.

15-year-old Jak Trueman, who suffered from a rare blood cancer, passed away.  He documented his treatment and life on social media via “Jak’s Journey”.  He briefly attended a prom held in his honor, where his family accepted awards on his behalf.  Despite his illness, Jak remained positive, inspiring many.  After doctors decided to stop treatment, Jak and his family encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.  A charity football match will be held in his honor.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 with a late goal from Abdallah El Said, assisted by Mohamed Salah, securing their advancement to the next round against Ghana. Uganda, failing to score and having a goal disallowed for offside, is eliminated from the tournament.  Ghana also advanced to the quarter-finals after defeating Mali 1-0.

Lancashire County Council has chosen the site of the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station in Skelmersdale.  The chosen location offers ample space, good highway access, and connectivity to the town and surrounding areas.  This decision follows a comparative study by Network Rail and allows for the possibility of future expansion.  The council will now begin acquiring the necessary land.
Police found plants in an elaborate grow house in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning and arrested a man in his late 40s.

A 28-year-old woman was found lying on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, Germany, with serious injuries late on Sunday.  Police say her 38-year-old ex-partner, who later turned himself in, dragged her by the neck through several streets. Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin.  The woman underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic.  The motive is unclear, and police are seeking witnesses.

A study of Australian workers found that women are as likely as men to ask for raises, but 25% less likely to receive them.  This debunks the theory that women are reluctant to request raises. While younger men and women (under 40) ask for and receive raises at the same rate, pure discrimination against women may be a factor in the disparity for older workers.

Oxford City Council has been searching for new burial grounds for years but has been unable to find suitable land within the city.  Existing cemeteries are nearly full, and once they are full, only reopening family plots, using reserved plots, or interring ashes will be possible.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, will feature acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Lucy Spraggan.  A new augmented reality app will allow attendees and fans worldwide to access online information, videos, band interviews, and purchase tickets.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase.  The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death was a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur in horses without underlying health issues.  Although Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia (overheating and wobbling), he displayed no such symptoms after Saturday's race.  While he had a history of overheating, this report concludes the cause of death was the rare haemorrhage.

In 2004, 15-year-old Davina Ayrton raped a teenage girl in a Portsmouth garage while two others slept. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, was found guilty in Portsmouth Crown Court and will be sentenced on March 4th.  The judge remanded Ayrton to a male prison in Winchester. During the trial, Ayrton stated she had not physically transitioned or taken medication and changed her name in 2012. The victim testified she clearly remembered the attack despite only having a small amount of alcohol. Ayrton confessed to the crime in 2014 to a care home worker.

Novak Djokovic and his Serbian tennis partner lost in Rio to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares.  This defeat follows his singles loss to Juan Martin del Potro, and his Wimbledon loss to Sam Querrey.  Djokovic did win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The annual chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Scotland, features 20+ international competitors, who use chainsaws to carve wood into shapes of animals and people. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will return to defend his title.

Rhys Webb, who has been out with a foot injury since September, is nearing a return to rugby.  He is currently in pre-season training and aiming to be fit in time for the Six Nations in February.  His goal is to return earlier than the initial February target.  He recently renewed his dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region.

Near Sumas, Washington, border patrol agents interrupted a smuggling attempt of 58lb of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One suspect, Jeffrey Laviolette, was apprehended, while another, Nathan Hall, fired at agents and fled, later being arrested in Canada.  Two more suspects, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were arrested for planning to transport the drugs to San Francisco.  The suspects face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. This area is a known smuggling route, and such prosecutions are common.

Childline counseled over 4,500 children, a substantial increase from 2,400 in 2011-12, regarding online bullying.  Some children as young as seven reported being tormented, abused, and scared to go to school.  Dame Esther Rantzen stresses that adults and schools must intervene as bullying won't stop on its own.  This issue is highlighted during Anti-Bullying Week, with the Anti Bullying Alliance working to combat the problem.  One child shared their experience of being told to kill themselves online, highlighting the emotional impact and difficulty in addressing it.

Israel postponed a vote on authorizing new homes in East Jerusalem settlements.  This followed a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements and rising tensions between the US and Israeli governments.  The postponement came at the request of Prime Minister Netanyahu’s office hours before US Secretary of State John Kerry’s speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.  Israel claims East Jerusalem as part of its capital, while Palestinians claim it as the capital of their future state.  Over 500,000 Jews live in roughly 140 settlements built since Israel’s 1967 occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem.  The settlements are considered illegal under international law.

In a BBC interview, Prince William praised the Queen's example as a monarch on the eve of her 90th birthday.  A picture of the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George has been released for stamps commemorating the occasion.  The Queen visited the Royal Mail delivery office in Windsor and opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens.  Prince William discussed his commitment to royal duty, stating that he takes his responsibilities seriously but is finding his own way at the right time. He also expressed admiration for the Queen's approach to public life.  Ten stamps have been released to celebrate the Queen's birthday, including images of four generations of the Royal Family.  The Queen will participate in several events, including lighting a beacon and having lunch with the Obamas.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup.  Sakho scored his first goal since November from a Byram pass, followed by a goal from Ayew. Cheltenham's best chance came from Pell's volley, but Holman couldn't connect.  West Ham had other opportunities to extend their lead but were denied by Storer and Flatt.  Cheltenham's loss marks the end of League Two representation in the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a motorcycle accident caused by Andreas Werner, 46, who failed to see him while turning right. Werner pled guilty to causing death by careless driving, receiving a £1,000 fine and a two-year UK driving ban.  McNicholl's family believed jail time for Werner wouldn't be worthwhile, accepting it as a momentary lapse.  Werner expressed remorse and couldn't explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist, returned to the UK after fighting in Syria with Rayat al Tawheed, an Islamic State affiliated group.  Khawaja, who called himself Abu Daigham al-Britani, posted propaganda for the group online, including videos and photos of himself and other fighters.  He also participated in gruesome acts, such as posing with a severed head.  Last June, Khawaja attempted to secretly return to the UK with the help of his cousin, Tahir Bhatti.  He faked his own death online before being arrested upon arrival in Dover.  Khawaja is considered a dangerous terrorist and has pleaded guilty to four offenses.  An additional charge of soliciting to murder will lie on file.

Wrexham's Kayden Jackson, 22, will join Barnsley next season.  Jackson scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season.  Barnsley's caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, says Jackson has pace, likes to challenge defenders, and will fit in with their style of play. This is Barnsley’s third signing ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday.  Jackson turned down a contract offer from Wrexham.

Containers of Vanish detergent bottles are washing ashore on Cornish beaches, posing a risk to wildlife.  A ship lost a container of Vanish in May near Land's End, but it's not confirmed that these bottles are from that incident.  National Trust volunteers are clearing the bottles, and authorities advise the public to avoid contact with them.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 2 PM, resulting in several minor injuries.  The road was closed, and diversions were established via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road.  Police are investigating.

Wanderers defender Dorian Dervite, 28, has signed a new contract with the club. Dervite made 14 appearances last season, helping Bolton finish second in League One to secure promotion to the Championship.  He follows Wheater, Madine, and Karacan in signing new Bolton contracts.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour are experiencing tension after their brief alliance concerning Brexit amendments.  The Lib Dems accuse Labour of conceding too much to the government and giving people false hope by voting against the amendments they previously supported. Labour claims the Lib Dems are grandstanding for campaign purposes, knowing the amendments would be rejected by MPs. Despite this, the Lib Dems express a willingness to continue working with Labour on other issues in the future, while a Labour source predicts lingering tension.

Defense is a low-priority issue in the UK election, ranking below the economy, NHS, and immigration in voter concerns.  While the world is perceived as increasingly unstable, UK armed forces have undergone significant cuts, impacting capabilities like maritime patrol. Though the UK was the fourth largest defense spender, it has fallen to sixth, and may soon fall below the NATO 2% GDP guideline.  Maintaining this spending level would require an additional £25bn over five years.  The next government will likely make further defense cuts, with the MoD having the second largest non-protected budget.  Replacing Trident is estimated to cost at least £20bn, impacting conventional forces.  The two new aircraft carriers, while large, may be understaffed and underequipped.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, but with additional fees, the total cost is £106.8m.  Amidst accusations of misappropriated funds and investigations into the transfer, Barcelona made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56, though they maintain their original payment was correct.  The club denies any tax-related crime.

Michael Luciw, 27, died in a car crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman driving the wrong way on a motorway.  Luciw's family believes older drivers should have regular driving tests, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of driving for older people's independence.  The crash occurred when Newman's car hit the van Luciw was in. The van driver, Andy Harrington, sustained serious injuries.  Currently, drivers over 70 self-assess every three years, with no medical or driving tests required. The DVLA has no plans to change this, stating older drivers are not more accident-prone.

An independent review of transvaginal mesh implants, chaired by Tracey Gillies, concluded that the procedure should not be routinely offered to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended mandatory reporting of adverse events.  Two patients and a consultant quit the review group over concerns with the final report,  and two former members, Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, expressed "dismay and disgust" at its publication.  Health Secretary Ms Robison confirmed the recommendations would be implemented despite calls for a ban, citing a lack of government power.  Alison Britton will examine how the review reached its conclusions. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have received implants in the past 20 years, and over 400 are pursuing legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5K record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds.  McColgan expressed concerns about the legitimacy of the race as Muir was the only 5k runner, with others running a 3k.  However, British Athletics confirmed the time is expected to be officially ratified.  McColgan believes Muir is capable of a 14:30 time, putting her among the world's top runners.  Muir also holds the British 1500m record and was an Olympic finalist at Rio 2016.

Michael Jung won gold in equestrian aboard Sam, a late replacement for Fischertakinou. Astier Nicolas of France took silver, and Phillip Dutton of the US took bronze. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt, competing only 10 months after being in an induced coma, finished 12th after a disappointing cross-country performance. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth.

Andy Murray defeated Fabio Fognini 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5 to advance to the fourth round of Wimbledon.  Fognini had five set points in the fourth set, but Murray won five straight games to secure the victory. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the next round.  Murray’s match was tense, especially at the end as light faded and the roof was a possibility.  Fognini had an ankle injury and was penalized a point for obscene gestures.  Murray felt he could have moved better during the match and will work on that before Monday.

On October 6, 2014, police discovered patrons still at Joe's Bar in Dungiven past permitted hours, with alcohol served as late as 04:49 BST.  The bar's license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours. The judge ordered a three-month closure and fined O'Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000, citing O'Neill's "appalling record" and the severity of the case.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, launched the party's manifesto, 'Real Partnership'.  He stated that he prefers partnership over domination and wants the election to be about how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled.  His recent comments about vote transfers have caused controversy.  Mr. Nesbitt stands by his comments, saying he would not withdraw a word. He stated a preference for working with the SDLP over Sinn Féin, should his party need to form a coalition government.  He believes he has support for his position.  The Ulster Unionist manifesto focuses on issues such as tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and mitigating the negative impacts of Brexit.  It also calls for cleaning up Stormont, addressing incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption.

Northern Ireland will follow England and Wales in enacting “Turing’s Law,” which will provide posthumous pardons for men convicted of abolished sexual offenses.  Living men convicted of such offenses may also apply for a pardon.  Justice Minister Claire Sugden has secured executive agreement to bring the motion before the assembly for approval.  The goal is to provide equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland, mirroring that of England and Wales.

Laura Muir, 23, set a new Scottish record in the mile, finishing second in 4:19.12 behind Faith Kipyegon.  This time places Muir second on the British all-time list and beats Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record.  Muir now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records.  She hopes to qualify for the Rio Olympics at the British trials in Birmingham.
26 Scottish beaches have been ranked as having the "most excellent" water quality. Pictures of these beaches are available.

UK officials suspect Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi poisoned Alexander Litvinenko with polonium-210 in 2006.  Litvinenko, a former KGB agent who defected to the UK in 2000, died three weeks later.  Richard Horwell QC, for the Met Police, said the Russian state likely sponsored the poisoning, citing Litvinenko's accusations against the FSB and Putin.  The suspects deny involvement, remain in Russia, and will likely not be tried for murder.  The inquiry chairman criticized Kovtun for not providing evidence.

Steve Smith, 26, replaces Michael Clarke, 34, as Australia's Test cricket captain.  David Warner, 28, will be vice-captain.  Smith has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs, averaging 54.66.  He captained the team in three Tests against India last summer while Clarke recovered from injury. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test.

Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron refused to answer whether he thought homosexual sex was a sin. He told the BBC he was “passionate about LGBT-plus rights” and that defending and extending equal marriage, including the marital rights of transgender people, would be “at the top of my agenda”.  He voted against the 2007 Equality Bill due to concerns about “protection of individual liberties,” but claims to support equality for all, regardless of sexuality.

Sanofi's drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, which closed in 2015 and resulted in 450 job losses, will be reopened by Accord Healthcare. Accord's investment in the pharmaceutical production plant is hoped to rehire many ex-Sanofi staff, positively impacting the local economy.  Newcastle City Council leader is pleased with Accord's investment, adding to the region's reputation as a hub for science and healthcare.  Accord Healthcare distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to approximately 60 countries.

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving their positions at the council.  Ellis's contract is ending, while Monaghan and Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme.  Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition, believes this demonstrates the council's inability to retain senior staff and anticipates further departures. Ellis acted as interim director of corporate governance and deputy chief executive. Monaghan headed the chief executive's office, and Sutherland led human resources and customer services.  Council chief executive Angela Scott thanked them for their service.

Guy Martin crashed at the Isle of Man TT and experienced mechanical issues with his Honda Fireblade. He stated that he is not quitting road racing altogether, but has no plans to continue road racing with Honda this year. He withdrew from the North West 200 after his teammate crashed and will not participate in the Ulster Grand Prix due to the bike's lack of competitiveness. He intends to race classics and other unique events in the future.

Nigeria's All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in the latest election, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP).  The PDP's loss is attributed to voters' desire for change after 16 years of PDP rule, allegations of corruption, and the party's failure to curb the Islamist insurgency in the northeast.  While the APC secured key wins in northern states and Lagos, it failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for incoming president Muhammadu Buhari.  The PDP retained power primarily in the southeast and oil-rich Niger Delta regions.  Although marred by some violence, the elections were deemed more peaceful than previous years.

Mighty, a US environmental lobby group, has accused agricultural commodities trader Olam and its stakeholder Temasek of overlooking unsustainable palm oil practices that contribute to the haze from Indonesian fires. Olam, denying the allegations, says less than 1% of the global market share is theirs and they enforce a “no burn” policy.  While Olam recently disclosed its 14 suppliers, Mighty claims Olam fosters a secretive market for rogue palm oil companies and sources from unknown origins. Temasek also denies the allegations, stating that they support no-burn policies and do not interfere with Olam’s operations.  Palm oil production is worth $88 billion, yet faces criticism for labor practices, deforestation, and burning.  NGOs and palm oil executives clash over environmental practices and their enforcement. Mighty also accuses Olam of deforestation in Gabon for palm oil plantations, a claim Olam denies, citing responsible and transparent private-public partnerships with Gabon’s government.
A restaurant began serving puppy platters outdoors after a new law allowed dogs to eat at outdoor restaurants.

Fernando Forestieri (knee) is doubtful after only featuring from the bench in the last two games. David Nugent (groin) may return after missing Monday's draw, and Jacob Butterfield is hoping to start after scoring a late equalizer as a substitute in that game.

Pakistan lifted its YouTube ban after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version, allowing the Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) to request removals of content deemed offensive.  While the PTA claims Google agreed to restrict access to flagged material, YouTube maintains that removal requests are not automatically granted and are subject to review based on community guidelines and local laws.  The ban, originally imposed in 2012 due to the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims," was lifted following Google's localized YouTube launch for Pakistan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, faces pressure from Liberian FA boss Musa Bility to withdraw from the upcoming presidential election due to sharing nationality (Swiss-Italian) with candidate Gianni Infantino. Bility cites a FIFA article requiring committee members with conflicts of interest to be replaced and points to Scala's withdrawal from the 2015 election when he shared nationality with then-president Sepp Blatter.  Scala's spokesman argues that shared nationality with a candidate doesn't constitute a conflict of interest, citing FIFA regulations and emphasizing the difference between this election and 2015, where the shared nationality was with the incumbent president. Bility has threatened to appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala doesn't withdraw and questions the differing processes between the two elections.  The Liberian FA emphasizes the importance of fairness and integrity in the election following FIFA's recent turmoil.  Bility, previously an electoral candidate himself, has pledged his support to Prince Ali.  Five candidates, including Infantino and Prince Ali, are vying for the FIFA presidency, with the election taking place on February 26th in Zurich.

Two workers, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died in a flashover explosion at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday.  The explosion, caused by a buildup of toxic fumes and an ignition, occurred in a paint-spraying area.  A forensic search has been conducted, and witness statements gathered.  The Health and Safety Executive is investigating.

Tunisia and Morocco will participate in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations.  Tunisia had faced expulsion for complaints lodged against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) during the 2015 quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea, but apologized and will now participate.  Morocco’s participation was also in doubt after a ban was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) related to its refusal to host the 2015 tournament.  Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.

Following a fracas in the 95th minute of a match between Manchester City and Chelsea, City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho received four- and three-match bans, respectively.  Aguero's ban results from a high challenge on David Luiz, his second dismissal this season. Fernandinho clashed with Cesc Fabregas following Aguero's challenge.  City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Both clubs must respond to the charge by 18:00 GMT on 8 December.

Wales and other parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world.  A pilot scheme in the Cynon Valley and Neath Port Talbot is focusing on patients whose GPs suspect cancer but who aren't showing any urgent signs or symptoms. This comes a year after doctors visited Denmark to observe their diagnostic systems, where the Cwm Taf Health Board officials saw that Denmark’s health service had improved cancer survival rates. The concern is that a patient in Wales who does not have clear symptoms waits too long for a diagnosis because they do not "easily fit" into any particular treatment pathway. This means that GPs refer the patient back and forth for a number of tests, which takes several weeks. Because of this, the fear is that too many patients begin treatment when their cancer has developed or is incurable. Forty doctors in the Cynon Valley who believe something may be wrong will be able to refer the patient to a diagnostic centre at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant within seven days. The estimate is that about six patients a week will be seen and will have different tests, and the hope is that this will happen on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with "worrying" symptoms

England defeated Pakistan by 330 runs in the second Test at Old Trafford, leveling the four-match series 1-1.  Joe Root was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and unbeaten 71 in the second. Alastair Cook also contributed with scores of 105 and 76 not out.  Pakistan's batting struggles continued, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series so far.  Despite the dominant win, Michael Vaughan predicts a tight series. The third Test begins on August 3rd at Edgbaston.

Warren Gatland will lead the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with Rob Howley as interim coach.  Forwards coach Robin McBryde will assume head coach responsibilities for Wales for the third time, leading the summer tour.  The WRU will appoint assistant coaches to help McBryde and expects to finalize the management team soon.  Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the coaches’ involvement with the Lions will benefit the Welsh national team.

Southampton took an early lead with a penalty in the sixth minute. However, Hull City turned the game around with two goals in two minutes during the second half, thanks to Robert Snodgrass's goal and assist. Despite Southampton's efforts and David Marshall's crucial saves, Hull City secured their first league win since August 20th, ending their six-game losing streak.  Injuries to Hull City’s starting strikers ultimately worked in their favor, allowing Snodgrass to return from injury earlier than anticipated and change the momentum of the game.

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, around 2:15 pm BST.  The tractor driver was unharmed. Police are seeking witnesses and the B1191 is closed between Woodhall Spa and Horncastle.

Macedonia’s President Ivanov halted an investigation into recordings that allegedly exposed government abuse of power.  Ivanov stated that he wanted to end turmoil ahead of June elections, but the move was criticized by the EU and Macedonian opposition.  The recordings, released by opposition leader Zaev, allegedly revealed vote-rigging, a murder cover-up, and other government corruption.  The government denies the accusations.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth.  Swansea’s first choice for new manager is Paul Clement.  Curtis believes Swansea lost their way after Michael Laudrup left in 2014 due to constant management changes.  He also questions if departing players have been adequately replaced.  Curtis feels the current squad is capable of avoiding relegation, and reminds new signings of the club's history and importance of remaining in the Premier League.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two after losing 3-2 to Leyton Orient.  Despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, Armand Gnanduillet scored the winner for Orient, keeping their play-off hopes alive. Dagenham, who reached the Football League in 2007, return to the National League under manager John Still. They struggled this season with a league-worst goal difference and a weaker attack compared to last season. Still is committed to helping the Daggers return to League Two.  Orient's win comes after removing Kevin Nolan as player-manager. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler acknowledged the difficult week but emphasized the team's need to win to reach the play-offs.

Steven Gerrard, 36, will return to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, his first job since retiring.  Gerrard's goal is to become a manager.  He played for Liverpool from 1998 until the end of the 2014-2015 season before joining LA Galaxy.  He retired in November after a 19-year career.  Gerrard is also working towards his Uefa A coaching licence.

Morton defeated Alloa 4-1. McManus scored two goals, one in the first 15 minutes and another late in the game, to help secure the win for Morton. Forbes also scored for Morton, while McAusland scored for Alloa. Johnstone added a late goal for Morton.

Ofsted investigations uncovered three illegal schools operating in squalid conditions in Birmingham, prompting their closure.  These schools are part of 18 unregulated institutions, primarily within Muslim communities in the Midlands, currently under investigation.  While some "flexi-schools" legally provide supplementary education for home-schooled children, authorities suspect some operate as illegal schools.  Sir Michael Wilshaw, Chief Inspector of Schools, expressed concern over potential child abuse and radicalization, urging quicker government action against these institutions.  The government has allocated funding for six inspectors to investigate illegal schools across all religious groups.  The Education Secretary has requested Ofsted to prepare prosecutions.  Further regulation of institutions teaching over 6-8 hours per week is under consultation until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is the first distillery to open in the Scottish Borders since 1837.  It is one of the smallest production stills in the UK, using local botanicals to create a unique “Borders terroir.” The gin is named after a local legendary figure, Lilliard, a female warrior who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

Gary Green, who was more than two times the legal driving limit, killed Harry Whitlam after reversing a tractor into him at Swithens Farm in August 2013. Green had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 02:00 BST. He was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting failing to ensure the safety of others under health and safety legislation, rather than road traffic law, because the incident occurred on private land.  Harry's mother said the family had been "changed forever" and hoped to remember the good times shared with Harry. HSE inspector Julian Franklin described the incident as an "extremely tragic case" and Green's behavior as "reckless".

Luis Suarez's four-month ban from all football activity has been upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), but he is now allowed to train and play in friendly matches for Barcelona.  He can also attend matches and participate in promotional activities.  Suarez's competitive debut for Barcelona will likely be on October 26th.  He will still serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games.  The CAS ruling allows him to partake in "football-related activities" but not "organized" matches.  Suarez's lawyers argued that the FIFA sanctions were too harsh, but CAS largely confirmed them, stating that preventing training would negatively impact Suarez after his suspension ends.  Fifpro expressed disappointment that the ban wasn't reduced and suggested mandatory treatment.  Suarez bit Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. This is the third biting incident for which Suarez has been sanctioned.

Richard Blake-Smith and Anna won the British Wife-Carrying Race, defeating the Lithuanian team.  They trained for a week by running on a track. The 380-meter race included hurdles, a slope, and water pistols.  Competitors included various pairings, and the winners will compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

In October, the paper system for car tax discs will be replaced with an electronic system, allowing payments via monthly direct debit.  This change will likely impact some of the 5,000 DVLA employees in Swansea.  Stephen Hammond assures that job reductions will be managed through redeployment and training for new roles within other growing areas of the DVLA, rather than redundancies.

Hungary's Foreign Minister says the EU should not interfere in its domestic affairs regarding laws passed concerning asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education.  Poland has pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary, including the stripping of voting rights, which requires unanimous approval.  The new laws have prompted protests within Hungary and warnings from the EU, with threats of action if changes aren't made.  One of the laws could force the closure of the Central European University in Budapest.

Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens the Beast, and Luke Evans Gaston in a live-action version of Beauty and the Beast.  Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle’s father, and Emma Thompson Mrs. Potts.  Josh Gad will play LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the film, which will be released in the US on March 17, 2017.  Filming begins in May at Shepperton Studios.

Adrian Gill, a journalist for the Sunday Times, died from cancer.  Gill was known for his wit, fearless writing, and compassion.  He overcame dyslexia to become a writer, first writing art reviews before moving to the Sunday Times in 1993.  Though popular, his writing was often controversial.  He is survived by his partner, Nicola Formby, and four children.

Rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, lead singer of the band Khar Sarnai, was allegedly attacked while performing in Ulan Bator, Mongolia.  Russian news reported he was hit with a bottle and kicked, while his father stated he suffered brain injuries and a 10-day coma.  Sukhbaatar wears a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol, not affiliated with Nazism. The Russian embassy disputes details in media reports of the attack and is investigating.  The suspect, reportedly a Russian diplomat, has not been arrested, with police citing the injuries as not serious.  Sukhbaatar's lawyer insists the suspect should be investigated under Mongolian law.

Plane Stupid protestors demonstrated against airport expansion plans.  They were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area.  The protest occurred at 03:30 BST Monday on the northern runway.  A security review will follow.

Nick Selman scored 101 runs for Glamorgan, his second first-class century of the season, after a string of low scores.  Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took wickets regularly for Gloucestershire, bowling Glamorgan out for 220.  Gloucestershire struggled in their innings, ending the day evenly balanced with Glamorgan.  Michael Hogan is leading Glamorgan while Jacques Rudolph is out with a neck injury.

33-year-old Craig Hughes from Flint was arrested in August after online chats with a Tennessee crisis center, where he made threats to falsely report a crime, ambush and shoot responding police officers at the Dee Estuary.  He admitted to two charges in Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week.  Hughes had a prior firearm conviction in 2009.  His legal team stated he never intended to harm himself or carry out the threat.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire by 18 runs in the Royal London One-Day Cup semi-final at Headingley.  Davies (95) and Foakes (90) shared a 130-run partnership to help Surrey recover from 8-2 and post 255-7. Despite Bresnan's 68 and Waite's 38, Yorkshire were all out for 236. Meaker's three wickets in nine balls proved crucial for Surrey.  Yorkshire captain Lees admitted their failure to perform in crucial moments, while Surrey captain Batty praised the team's collective effort and the pivotal partnership between Davies and Foakes.

A 56ft converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST reporting their pump couldn't handle incoming water.  An RNLI lifeboat crew added another pump and towed the trawler to Holyhead.

Laura Muir will miss the Commonwealth Games due to veterinary medicine exams.  She plans to compete in the World Indoor Championships in March.  At the World Athletics Championships, Muir placed fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m, achieving a personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the latter.  She is optimistic about competing in future Olympics.

Liverpool are struggling this season due to overachieving last season and the loss of Suarez’s goals.  Rodgers’s signings have not been effective, impacting their intensity and ability to score, especially in the first half.  Defensively, they remain inconsistent despite significant spending.  Gerrard, though aging, is vital to Liverpool’s future.  Chelsea are currently superior to other Premier League teams and are predicted to win against Liverpool at Anfield. While Gerrard’s slip last season against Chelsea significantly impacted Liverpool, he remains a key player and is expected to continue contributing to the team.

A new £45m campus in Kilmarnock, East Ayrshire, will house primary, secondary, and Gaelic schools, and a childcare center.  The council wishes to name it after Kilmarnock-born author William McIlvanney, who died on December 5th.  McIlvanney, initially an English teacher, became a full-time writer in 1975.  His first novel, *Remedy Is None*, and other works like the *Laidlaw* trilogy, *Docherty*, and *The Big Man* earned him the title "Godfather of Tartan Noir".  He also contributed to Scotland's political and sporting life.

A sea mine, likely British and from the mid-20th century, was found near a Gourock swimming pool on Monday.  As a precaution, residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors near walls with open windows, and three streets were evacuated until the early afternoon.  A half-mile sea exclusion zone disrupted some ferries.  The Royal Navy’s Northern Diving Unit moved the deteriorating mine to a safer location due to uncertainty about its explosive content.  Inverclyde Council thanked residents and businesses for their patience during the evacuation.

Team GB has been allocated £345m in funding across 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo Games.  This is £2m less than funding for the Rio Games.  The funding cuts include archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and cycling, with cycling's funding cut by more than £4m.  Badminton has had all of its funding removed, despite winning a bronze medal in Rio.  Judo, which also won a bronze in Rio, has received a slight funding increase.  UK Sport CEO Liz Nicholl stated that funding cuts were made to prioritize sports with strong medal potential.  Sports Minister Tracey Crouch supports UK Sport's approach, citing its success in past Olympic games.  Basketball, handball, and volleyball, whose funding was previously withdrawn, criticize UK Sport for a lack of investment in team sports.  Funding for new Olympic and Paralympic sports, including baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sports climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo, and Para-badminton, is yet to be determined.  UK Sport has set a target of 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals for Team GB in Tokyo.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth’s East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks (seven and nine storeys, with 122 apartments).  Despite 49 resident objections, English Heritage’s disapproval, and concern over the loss of trees, the council approved the plans, citing the need to boost tourism and improve housing for the elderly.  246 letters of support were received.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, died after being punched and beaten by Jake Vallely, 24, in Brecon, Wales, on 8 May. Vallely will be sentenced on 8 December.  Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of manslaughter. Pte Boyd, of the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was attacked while returning to barracks after a night out. CCTV footage showed Vallely punching, beating, and dragging Pte Boyd's body. Vallely had been drinking heavily and claimed to be the "hardest man in Brecon". Pte Boyd's family paid tribute to him, describing the attack as creating "a void in our family that will never be filled". They contrasted the community's outpouring of love with Vallely's claim about being the "hardest man in Brecon".

Andrew Travers, chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by mutual agreement after voters were turned away from all polling stations in the borough due to missing names from the poll list.  An independent investigation will review the incident and the arrangements for the EU Referendum.  Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily replace Travers.
