The train, carrying 166 passengers, was delayed for nearly three hours.  No passengers were injured, though one received treatment after falling ill.  A man who knew the couple said they may have been homeless.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia. He was promised US citizenship in exchange for his service, during which he helped take down cartel leaders and dictators. Now retired, Toro faces deportation and fears for his life if sent back to Colombia.  The DEA refused to help with his citizenship after he publicized his situation.  A former colleague gave Toro $5,000 for an operation after the DEA declined assistance. Toro's visa expired January 1st, and he is now in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits.

ICANN, the internet address regulator, is investigating Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal practices regarding the '.sucks' domain.  Vox Populi is charging high prices, around $2,499 a year,  for '.sucks' domains related to major brands and celebrities like Kevin Spacey, who reportedly paid to have his removed.  While Vox Populi claims this practice is legal, an advisory panel calls it a "shakedown scheme," citing the much lower cost of other domain names and the threat of public registration later as coercive.  ICANN has contacted US and Canadian regulators and is exploring remedies within its agreement with Vox Populi.

27 years after a baby boy's body was found in a pond, his mother was found through DNA testing.  She explained that the baby was stillborn, and she hid the pregnancy and birth. Though initially arrested for infanticide, the charge was dropped. She remains on bail while a decision is made whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby, originally buried without a name, was reburied as Peter, the same name as the local church.  The mother's identity has not been released.

Kristopher Hicks, 23, suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from a moving taxi driven by Michael Young, 56.  Young mistakenly believed Hicks wouldn't pay his fare and began driving him back to the taxi rank. Hicks jumped from the taxi traveling at over 20mph, resulting in permanent injuries requiring round-the-clock care.  The High Court ruled Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, making him liable for damages. While the final amount is pending, it's estimated to be half of what Hicks' family requested, anticipated to be hundreds of thousands of pounds, plus £250 for unlawful imprisonment.  Both parties can appeal the decision.

Wednesday night, Kansas faced several tornado-producing storms. One near Goddard, and three near Aetna, Kansas.  Missouri also experienced a potential tornado in Potosi, with reports of wind damage and flooding. More storms are expected Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes. Nighttime tornadoes are considered the most dangerous.

Luke Rockhold plans to aggressively pursue Lyoto Machida in their upcoming middleweight fight, using a "bull" versus "matador" tactic to dominate and force Machida into his fighting style. Rockhold acknowledges Machida's skill and experience but is confident in his own mixed martial arts abilities and superior speed, believing he has more avenues to victory.  A win for either fighter could lead to a title shot. Machida is equally confident, believing that by implementing his strategy and capitalizing on Rockhold's weaknesses, he can secure a win and a title shot. He feels well-prepared after eight weeks of training.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light aircraft landed without its landing gear deployed, skidding along the runway on its belly.  The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, re-engaged the engines and took off again, despite damage to the propellers.  He then flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely.  Mr. Georgaklis, an experienced pilot with almost 50 years of experience, had his dog, Buddy, onboard. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini expressed disappointment with Yaya Touré’s performance this season, but will support him until the end of the season.  Although City is open to offers for Touré, the midfielder wants to stay.  Pellegrini also noted that Vincent Kompany will be out for the rest of the season due to injury.  Joe Hart, City’s goalkeeper, said that the players, not just Pellegrini, should shoulder the blame for the team’s performance.  West Ham manager Sam Allardyce cautioned Aaron Cresswell against making the same mistake as Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who joined City but did not play much.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive residing in the UK for over 20 years, will not be extradited to Italy.  His seven-year sentence for being a member of Cosa Nostra, issued by an Italian court in 1999, expired in October 2014 under Italian law.  Although his conviction stands, the sentence is extinguished after a period of more than double the sentence time has passed.  Rancadore's European arrest warrant will be withdrawn, subject to a hearing by the Italian Supreme Court and approval by a UK judge.  Rancadore was arrested in 2013 and fought extradition based on human rights concerns related to his heart condition.  He lived under the alias Marc Skinner with his family in Uxbridge.  Legal experts cited wasted time and money due to the expiration of the sentence before the extradition process concluded.  The CPS admitted to an administrative error that delayed the appeal process.

AP McCoy's mount, Mr Mole, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the seven-runner Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday.  This will be McCoy's final Grade One race.  His rivals include Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre (ridden by Nico de Boinville), and Somersby. McCoy's full book of rides for his final day will be released Friday.  McCoy announced his retirement after winning with Mr Mole at Newbury in February.

Forty years after her daughter Marcia's murder, Virginia Trimble Ritter viewed crime scene photos, a decision her late husband advised against.  The photos revealed Marcia's badly decomposed state.  Ritter, upon seeing the photos, expressed a desire for revenge against Jerome Barrett, who was convicted of the murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years.  Marcia's body was found 33 days after her disappearance, strangled and sexually assaulted, near her home.  Barrett was arrested in 2006 after a DNA match connected him to Marcia's murder and the 1975 murder of Sarah Des Prez.  He had previously been imprisoned on sex charges, with a brief release around the time of Marcia's disappearance.

Rory McIlroy believes winning the Masters to complete the career grand slam is a career-long goal and something he must achieve.  He feels confident about his chances at Augusta, noting the course suits his game and he can envision multiple wins there.  McIlroy views his 2011 Masters final round collapse as a pivotal learning experience that propelled him to subsequent major victories.  Last year's success, despite off-course distractions, reinforces his view of the golf course as a sanctuary, and he anticipates the same at Augusta amidst the hype.

Trending this week: A quadruple rainbow over New York, the crackdown on exotic dancers at funerals in China, Robert Downey Jr.’s interview, the #kyliejennerchallenge, a 102-year-old’s trip back in time, a controversial prom-posal, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere, Johnny Depp in the “Black Mass” trailer, a pregnancy announcement referencing “The Fresh Prince,” and a photobombing military dad.

272 children disabled by fetal alcohol syndrome were hospitalized in England in the past year, according to the health and social care information center.  Experts warn the actual number affected by maternal alcohol consumption could be much higher.  The World Health Organization estimates at least 1 in 100 UK babies are affected, approximately 7,500 annually.  These children may experience learning, behavioral, and physical problems.  One case highlighted a 15-year-old with fetal alcohol syndrome requiring assistance with daily tasks and unable to live independently.  The government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol consumption, but some experts recommend complete abstinence.

31-year-old Shaun Andrew McKerry attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores on March 15th.  Shopkeeper Sab Dhillon tackled McKerry, and his wife, Sam, hit the would-be robber with a baseball bat, disarming him.  McKerry, nicknamed "Boomerang Boy" for his frequent returns home after committing crimes, has a history of offenses dating back to age 12.  He pled guilty to attempted robbery and received a six-year jail sentence.

Four Royal Navy sailors, charged with gang raping a woman at a Canadian barracks, were granted bail set at over £2,000 each.  They surrendered their passports and will reside at the Stadacona Naval Base in Halifax, Nova Scotia, while awaiting trial.  The accused, Joshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalley, who played for the Royal Navy ice hockey team, must remain employed by the navy and cannot leave Nova Scotia.  The alleged assault occurred on April 10th after a hockey game, with the victim in her early 20s.  The sailors are forbidden from contacting the victim and six witnesses.  They will appear in court again on May 27th.  The investigation is ongoing, and further charges may be filed.

Four-year-old RJ Jackson suffers from Netherton's Syndrome, an extremely rare genetic skin disease causing red, scaly, inflamed skin.  His mother, Valerie Jackson, constantly applies creams to alleviate his symptoms.  However, RJ's appearance has led to public accusations of child abuse against Valerie, including one incident involving armed police.  The family also faces bullying and stares, and has even been denied entry to a play center due to RJ's condition.  Despite the challenges, Valerie remains positive, describing RJ as a beautiful and happy boy.  There is no cure for Netherton's Syndrome, but symptoms may improve with age.

Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” advertisement campaign featuring a bikini-clad model sparked controversy and was subsequently removed from the London Underground after its three-week run.  Although Transport for London (TfL) stated the removal was scheduled, the campaign had faced significant backlash.  Over 50,000 people signed a petition for its removal, and over 200 complaints were filed with the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA), citing the promotion of an unhealthy body image.  The advert was defaced by protestors, and sparked outrage on social media. Protein World responded defiantly to online criticism.  While the company maintains the campaign was aimed at promoting health and fitness, critics like TV presenter Susanna Reid found the advertisement “anxiety inducing.”  The ASA is reviewing the complaints.  Despite the controversy, Protein World considers the campaign a success and has no plans to change its advertising methods.

Ten days after UK general election, rail firms face criticism for planned fare increases up to 87%, despite party leaders' price freeze pledges.  Prime Minister Cameron, whose constituency is affected, requested First Great Western (FGW) review its near doubling of London-Cotswolds fares.  FGW's changes affect off-peak returns to London from Charlbury, increasing from £33.30 to £62.40. FGW says the change aligns the North Cotswolds route with other services, offering cheaper advance single tickets. Other increases include Crewe-Northampton off-peak first-class singles (London Midlands) rising from £30 to £37, Stafford-Liverpool anytime returns (Virgin) from £26.50 to £33, and Manchester-Stoke anytime first-class day returns (Virgin) from £29 to £35.30. Virgin claims most increases affect their own fares, 20% cheaper than rivals, with an overall 1.65% West Coast increase. Trainsplit.com highlights these increases despite price freeze discussions, noting 40% rises in anytime and off-peak returns in January, particularly

66-year-old John Young was blinded in his left eye after being struck by a brick thrown by vandals at his Oldham home.  The newlyweds were writing thank you notes when the attack occurred.  Mr. Young opened the door to confront the vandals after they threw stones at his window, and was then hit with a brick. Despite surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight.  Police are investigating the seemingly random attack.  The couple has since moved out of the neighborhood, fearing for their safety.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension.  Poynton missed the 2014 season due to injuries from a road accident in which his father died.  He returned to playing during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and is available for the start of the 2016 season.  Graeme Welch, Derbyshire's elite performance director, praised Poynton's character and tireless work, expressing delight at his return.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw is cancer-free after a year-long battle with neuroblastoma.  A superhero mask, decorated like a Ninja Turtle, helped him through radiotherapy.  His story garnered international attention, even receiving gifts from Nickelodeon.  He underwent chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester.  Harley's recovery is celebrated by his parents and he is expected to return to school full-time. He is also the face of a Cancer Research UK kids and teens campaign.

Tim Sherwood believes Jack Grealish should focus on Aston Villa and securing a first team spot before deciding on his international future between England and the Republic of Ireland.  Sherwood feels that continued impressive performances, like the one against Liverpool, will make Grealish's decision more impactful. Grealish's dad agrees, stating club performance should be prioritized over international duty.  Grealish is expected to make a decision at the end of the season.

Private jet travel, a growing trend among the wealthy, involves hefty landing fees, sometimes reaching thousands of dollars.  Popular routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas and Milan to Rome. The most expensive airports for landing a 767-400 are in Japan: Haneda Airport in Tokyo ($6,850), Narita International Airport in Tokyo ($5,600), and Kansai International Airport in Osaka ($5,400).  Other airports with high fees include Toronto Pearson ($5,200), Darwin International ($4,600), Bristol Airport ($4,400), Chūbu Centrair ($4,300), Dublin Airport ($4,100), LaGuardia ($3,950), and Salzburg ($3,800).  Major events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix increase demand and prices for private jet travel.

Cooper, a Labrador from Oregon, quickly devours an ice cream cone in one bite at a McDonald's drive-thru, while his companion, Daisy, eats more slowly.  Their owner, Katie Gallegos, often gives them these treats, noting Cooper's fast eating habits and Daisy's smaller portions. The video has garnered over seven million views, with some viewers expressing concern, while Gallegos assures them it's a harmless treat.  Another video shows the dogs enjoying "pup-uccinos" (whipped cream) at Starbucks.

Kilmarnock's interim manager, Gary Locke, has signed a three-year deal, securing the role permanently.  He joined the club last summer as assistant manager and took over in early February.  Since then, he has lost only one game in seven.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, claims a Seminole County elementary school threatened to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, for wearing Doterra essential oils.  Kemp says the oils, which she applies to Logan's head and neck, help him stay calm and focused.  The school reportedly stated the oils' smell distracted staff and students.  While Kemp maintains the oils positively impact her son, the Lake County school district has since stated they will not suspend Logan, calling it a "health issue."

A fire in Westhampton Beach destroyed a 90-unit condo complex on Wednesday afternoon.  The blaze, possibly started near a parked car, was so intense it melted paint on nearby buildings.  Twelve fire crews battled the flames, visible from three miles away, but were unable to enter the structure, which eventually collapsed.  The complex was used as a holiday home by residents between May and November.  One resident, whose partner was the building manager, reported losing everything.

At almost 89, Queen Elizabeth was seen riding her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park.  The Queen, who always wears a silk scarf instead of a helmet, has ridden horses since the age of four when she received a Shetland pony named Peggy.  Though she rides less now due to a knee injury, she remains an enthusiastic equestrian and breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court.  Fell ponies, one of the oldest breeds, originated in Cumbria and were used by the Carvetii, Romans, and Vikings.  The breed became popular riding horses in the 1950s.

A noise complaint between Brisbane neighbors escalated into a fatal altercation.  55-year-old Leon Yeaman was allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old Phillip Pama.  Pama, a shift worker, was sleeping when Yeaman, known for loud music and yelling, made a commotion.  During a confrontation, Pama punched Yeaman, resulting in his death. Pama was granted bail with conditions. The case returns to court May 18.

José Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, prays every day and speaks with God, but never about football.  He keeps his professional and family life separate. Although he admits his professional life requires him to push people to behave in certain ways, he believes he is a good person, friend, and family man.  He and his family have worked with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger.

Bob Barker, former host of "The Price is Right", returned to the show for the first time in eight years on April 1st.  The 91-year-old hosted the first game, "Lucky Seven", before handing hosting duties back to Drew Carey.

Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin was arrested Friday at 12:30 am in Southeast D.C. for attempted burglary and destruction of property.  His security clearance was revoked, and he was put on leave.  This incident follows another agent being put on leave two days prior due to misconduct allegations, and a March 4th incident involving two high-ranking officials driving into a secure White House area after drinking.

Atif Saeed, a photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, exited his vehicle at a safari park and approached a male lion to take a picture.  Lying on the ground within 10 feet of the lion, he captured a few photos. The shutter's click alerted the lion, who then aggressively lunged at Mr. Saeed, forcing him to quickly retreat to his car.  Although he laughed at the time, he now doubts he would repeat the risky encounter.

NYPD seeks public assistance in identifying a woman found deceased on March 22nd near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend, Brooklyn.  The woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old, had a distinctive heart-shaped tattoo with the name "Monique" on her right leg.  The cause of death is still pending a medical examiner's report. Anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck.  Unable to afford traditional housing, they spent a year and a half constructing the wood and steel structure, which is now located on their property in Nelson, New Zealand. The home is largely self-sufficient, powered by solar panels with gas used for the stove and hot water, and water sourced from a nearby spring.  The total cost of the project was approximately $25,000.

Research suggests that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class scored 30 points higher on literacy tests than students who used iPads individually or had no iPads.  The collaborative learning facilitated by shared technology, rather than just collaboration itself, seems to be the key factor.

A piglet born without back legs in Qionglai City, Sichuan Province, China, has become an internet sensation.  A video shows the piglet balancing and walking on its front legs, foraging for food, and interacting with its littermates.  Ms. Duan, the piglet's owner, noticed its missing hind legs shortly after birth.  This piglet isn't the first two-legged animal to gain popularity in China; a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also achieved fame for walking on its front paws.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, tire changer Todd Phillips was injured when Francesco Dracone spun his car while exiting the pit box on lap 25. Phillips received stitches for a leg cut and was released from the infield care center. Dracone did not finish the race. Many cars struggled with traction due to rain.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, four days after their wedding.  Severiano dragged Sena's body into their garden, smashed her head into the concrete 11 times, punched her in the face 10 times, then shot her five times. He confessed to the murder, claiming jealousy of men looking at his wife.  Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car after he crashed it during his getaway.  He faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author, revealed her struggles with mental illness, including anxiety, which led her to contemplate taking her own life.  A combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family contributed to her feelings of isolation and despair.  Wilson now recognizes herself as "anxious" but struggled in her younger years, feeling as though she'd missed a "guidebook to life."  She believes anxiety is becoming the "new depression" and emphasizes the link between anxiety and depression.  Wilson encourages those struggling to reach out to Beyond Blue (1300 224 636) or Lifeline (13 11 14).

Elena Curtin, a pregnant Portland woman, will no longer face prosecution for assaulting her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar.  Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom in November 2014. After asking her to leave and being refused, Curtin attacked her. Oregon law permits physical force against intruders refusing to leave a residence. The charges were dropped because Curtin's outrage was deemed justified.  The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing Curtin, and the boyfriend, who is the father of Curtin's child, struggled with heroin in the past, and has not been a part of his new child's life. Curtin now lives with her parents.

Gemma, a pit bull living in California with two children, was filmed rejecting a piece of broccoli given to her amongst treats.  She showed immediate disgust, spitting the vegetable onto the floor.  Other videos show Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her family.

HSBC apologized after a link on its official website redirected visitors to a pornographic page.  The bank's page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, inactive since 2011, was replaced by the porn site after the URL registration lapsed.  HSBC removed the link and stated they have no association with the external site.  They apologized for any inconvenience.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in a second-floor bedroom during a house fire. Marcus called 911, calmly providing directions to firefighters and reassuring his sister. Firefighters rescued the children through a window. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other three family members escaped and were taken to Medstar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae lit up Jervis Bay, located on the south coast of New South Wales, Australia. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured images of the neon glow.  The glow is caused by *Noctiluca scintillans*, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in the spring and autumn.  A similar event occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. According to Iain Suthers of the University of New South Wales, the algae is typically naturally occurring and uses the glow as a defense mechanism.

New genetic marker tests can determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer tumors and predict the risk of recurrence. This allows some patients, particularly those with a low recurrence risk (e.g., 5%), to forgo chemotherapy, sparing them from harsh side effects. While these tests are currently expensive and often privately available, experts believe their use could lead to cost savings for healthcare systems by reducing unnecessary chemotherapy treatments.  One patient, Becca Cornford, used the Endopredict test to determine her low risk and avoid chemotherapy after a double mastectomy.

Over 25 pregnant women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships in the last nine years, including five from HMS Ocean and one from HMS Illustrious.  Eighteen other ships also had pregnancy-related evacuations.  A "no touching" rule is in place at sea, suggesting conception occurred before deployment or during leave.  This follows an incident where Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK amidst claims of a relationship with a crew member.  Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, comprising 9% of personnel in 2014.  Additionally, nearly 100 female soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan between 2006 and 2013 due to pregnancy, with a further 102 evacuated from Iraq.  Pregnant servicewomen are prohibited from serving in war zones.

A drone containing trace amounts of radioactive cesium was discovered on the roof of the Japanese Prime Minister’s residence.  The drone was also equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle.  Although the amount of cesium discovered on the drone is not harmful to humans, the incident raises concerns about the potential for terrorism at future events such as the Olympics and G7 Summit.  Currently, Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports, but there are no flight restrictions for most of Tokyo, including government buildings.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in China, takes his 84-year-old mother to work with him every day.  She has Alzheimer's and he fears she'll get lost if left alone, especially after his father passed away.  He secures her to his motorbike with a sash and drives slowly to work. His employers provide a room for her while he works. He feels it's his duty to care for her as she cared for him.

A study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, primarily due to increased rates among women.  Researchers found that changing social norms are driving the increase in women’s drinking habits.  While the percentage of overall drinkers has remained relatively unchanged, in 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers.  Experts attribute the rise in excessive drinking to several factors, including changing social norms around women’s drinking, the affordability of alcohol, increased advertising, and relaxed alcohol control policies.

UN officials warn that too many caesarean sections are being performed when not medically necessary, endangering women and babies.  While the procedure can be lifesaving, it carries risks such as infections, complications, disability, or death.  England's rate of C-sections is over 25%, more than double that of the early 1990s, and exceeding the WHO's ideal rate of 10-15%.  Current NHS guidelines, contradicting WHO recommendations, allow C-sections for women with childbirth anxiety, previous birth complications, age over 40, or conditions like asthma, diabetes, or depression.  C-sections also cost the NHS more (£2,369) than natural births (£1,665).

44-year-old Michelle Filkins from West Wareham was arrested on April 17th and charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property.  The homeowner, Mark Conklin, discovered Filkins in his Martha's Vineyard summer home, which is estimated to be worth $800,000. Filkins had allegedly been living in the home for at least a week and sold the owner's belongings in a yard sale.  Police ask that anyone who received items from the home return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

Melbourne resident Bella Crooke lost her phone at a party Saturday night.  A security guard found it and left it at the Albury police station.  Police accessed her Facebook account and posted selfies, photos of the phone in the station, and humorous status updates to find her.  Bella retrieved her phone Sunday afternoon, amused by the officers' posts and interactions with her friends via text.  She has since added a password to her phone.

A five-day-old hippo calf was killed in South Africa's iSimangaliso Wetland Park after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos.  The calf's mother kept her distance from the fight, believing her herd to be safer, but a sub-adult hippo grabbed the calf. The mother hippo's attempts to retrieve her baby resulted in the sub-adult throwing the calf into the air. The calf died hours later from its injuries.

A three-bedroom maisonette in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for £575,000. The catch is the lease has only three years left.  Extending the lease could cost £3.35-£4.5 million, but the property could then be worth upwards of £6 million.  The property needs modernization and is described as "bright and well-proportioned," boasting 1,990 sq/ft, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and communal garden.  Similar properties in the area with longer leases cost significantly more, with the next cheapest three-bedroom costing £1.5 million with a 28-year lease.  While the price is low, extending the lease will be expensive, making it a quirky purchase opportunity.

A computer outage at 8,000 Starbucks stores in the US and Canada caused registers to malfunction, prompting baristas to give away free drinks.  The outage, caused by a failed system refresh, affected US and Canadian stores, as well as Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. While some customers received free drinks, many Starbucks locations closed early to avoid further product giveaways.  The issue was resolved and stores reopened for normal business the following day. This incident occurred after Starbucks posted record quarterly earnings.

Terrorist training and radicalization of Muslims is occurring in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire.  DC Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit revealed this activity, noting that those involved often engage in seemingly normal activities as a cover.  The area has a history of such activity, dating back to 1998 when Abu Hamza allegedly sent extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons.  In 2005, two 7/7 bombers were photographed in Bala, and in 2010, three Cardiff men were arrested for plotting UK attacks.  Michael Adebowale, convicted in the murder of Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder.  DC Jones emphasized the importance of community intelligence in addressing this issue.

A juvenile female Omura's whale washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This is the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and the second in Australia.  DNA profiling confirmed the whale's identity. Very little is known about the species, which was first described in 2003 and is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale's skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and possible museum display.  Omura's whales have sleek bodies, 53 vertebrae, and four digits on each pectoral fin.

Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, stated that women should not be president due to hormones influencing their decisions.  Rios suggested that female hormones would cause a woman president to start a war, citing this as a reason Hillary Clinton shouldn't be president. However, historical data indicates male leaders have been impacted by hormones, taking unnecessary risks, and engaging in extramarital affairs.  Furthermore, studies show women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. While some argue Clinton's post-menopausal state makes her an ideal candidate, others believe gender bias is the real issue women face in leadership roles.  Evidence of this bias is prevalent in corporate settings and academia.  Despite qualifications and numbers, women face an uphill battle in leadership due to societal perceptions.  Ultimately, equality benefits everyone, from companies and families to marriages and teams.  Rios stated she would move to Canada if Clinton were elected because a woman shouldn't be president, seemingly unaware that Canada elected its first female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

89-year-old actor Robert Hardy, known for his roles in *All Creatures Great and Small* and his portrayals of Winston Churchill, is auctioning over 200 items from his antique collection.  The collection includes a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, commissioned by Hardy in the 1960s, a longbow with mother-of-pearl handle, paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and books dating back to the 17th century.  The auction will take place this Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire.  Hardy, a military historian and longbow expert, expressed sadness at downsizing his collection.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted for the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, in Winter Garden, Florida.  He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son the day his mother's body was discovered. Shemansky has a history of battery on law enforcement, bipolar disorder, and an attempted suicide.  He was on parole and going through a divorce. Neighbors speculate that Sandra prevented Shemansky from seeing his son due to the divorce proceedings and that he received upsetting paperwork the day before the murder.  Shemansky is on foot without provisions or medication. The murder weapon has been recovered, but the cause of death is not yet public.  His estranged wife is taking precautions in case he attempts to contact her. Anyone with information is urged to contact authorities.

Eugene, Oregon will host the 2021 IAAF World Championships.  The IAAF Council bypassed the usual bidding process due to a unique opportunity presented by the city.  While Eugene lost its bid for the 2019 event to Doha, Qatar, a new presentation persuaded the IAAF. This marks the first time the USA will host this event.  The decision was also influenced by combined support from public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and the public.  The 2007 championships in Osaka, Japan were also awarded without bidding.

Leonie Granger, 25, befriended and targeted professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, after seeing him with a large sum of cash at a London casino.  Granger left Hassan's flat door unlocked so her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and Nicholas Chandler could rob him. Jackson and Chandler tied up and killed Hassan. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to 16 years. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years.  All three were convicted of robbing Hassan and conspiracy to falsely imprison him. Jackson and Chandler were also found guilty of other robbery and firearm charges.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, is known for his declining performance in the latter half of the season.  After a strong start, his form has dipped considerably, impacting his assist numbers which, at one point, seemed likely to surpass Thierry Henry's Premier League record.  His struggles were evident in a recent international match for Spain.  Although his performance has waned, crucial upcoming matches against teams he has previously assisted or scored against could offer opportunities for a resurgence and contribute to Chelsea's title hopes.  Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho hopes this will be the case.

17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, currently playing for Montego Bay United, has impressed West Ham coaches after a two-week trial with the club’s academy.  Beckford also has offers from Belgian clubs.  West Ham season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will start at £289, the cheapest in the Barclays Premier League.

Mike Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was assaulted by balaclava-clad protestors, suffering concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss.  Despite video footage, names of suspects, and car registration numbers being provided to Wiltshire police, the investigation has been dropped due to insufficient evidence.  Hunt supporters are dismayed by the decision, citing the clear evidence provided, including a photograph of the suspect.  The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban face coverings for saboteurs to aid in prosecutions.  Wiltshire police stated the case is currently undetected but will be reopened if further evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, 36, an American-born al Qaeda spokesman, was killed in a January 2015 U.S. counterterrorism operation.  Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, converted to Islam in 1995, left for Pakistan in 1998, joined al Qaeda, and became its chief English-language propagandist.  He appeared in numerous videos threatening attacks, criticizing U.S. presidents, and urging lone-wolf attacks within the United States.  He was indicted in 2006 for treason and providing material support to al Qaeda. Another U.S. citizen and al Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, was killed in a separate operation, and U.S. hostage Warren Weinstein was killed in the same operation that killed Farouq.

A 5-year-old Chinese boy, Mai Zizhuo, is captivating audiences with his impressive basketball skills showcased in a viral video.  He has been playing since the age of two and a half.  The video displays his ability to score consecutive hoops and dribble two basketballs simultaneously while maintaining eye contact with the camera.  His talent has garnered him numerous fans throughout China, with many netizens expressing astonishment and praise for his abilities.

Tom O’Carroll, a former key activist for PIE (Paedophile Information Exchange), attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25th.  He was there to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation.  O’Carroll’s presence is an embarrassment to Hacked Off, a group campaigning for statutory press regulation.  PIE, which O’Carroll was a leading member of, campaigned to legalize sex with children.  O’Carroll was jailed in 1981 for “corrupting public morals.”  The Hacked Off meeting was chaired by John Cleese and open to the public.

Icebergs club pool at Bondi Beach was drained to host a fashion show for Ten Pieces, a unisex clothing brand, during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia.  The show featured monochrome designs, modeled in the empty pool and along the break wall. The brand, led by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini, produces collections of ten pieces designed to be worn in twenty different ways. Guests enjoyed refreshments and sunshine during the show.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent Friday at a safari park in Northern California with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa.  He posed with and fed a white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions.  Khan recently announced his upcoming welterweight fight against Chris Algieri on May 30th, despite pressure to fight Kell Brook.

Sixteen-year-old Palestinian, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was added to Israel’s memorial wall for fallen soldiers and terror victims. His family and Almagor, an organization for terror victims, objected to his inclusion.  His father, Hussein Abu Khdeir, stated he was not asked permission and refuses to have his son listed among “soldiers of the occupation.” Almagor described the teen’s death as a rogue attack, not a terror attack.  Following complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel removed Abu Khdeir’s name from the memorial wall and website.  Three suspects are currently on trial for the teen’s murder.

A young boy repeatedly attempts to use his family cat as a pillow.  He follows the cat around the garden, plopping his head on the cat's belly each time the cat settles down.  After several attempts, the cat goes inside. A later video shows the boy and cat reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past as a marijuana dealer.  He testified against officers accused of stealing from him during a 2007 arrest.  Kushner’s past arrests, including a 2011 arrest and a 2008 DUI, came to light after his testimony, leading to his dismissal.  He maintains his innocence in the 2011 case.  The defense lawyers in the corruption trial claim the government’s case relies on dishonest drug dealers and a corrupt ex-officer.

An explosion at a paraxylene (px) chemical plant in Zhangzhou, China, injured six people. The blast, caused by an oil leak at an oil storage facility, ignited a large fire.  Over 600 firefighters contained the blaze. Though no toxic chemical spill was reported, five of the injured were hospitalized due to broken glass.  This same plant experienced a similar explosion in 2013.  The plant’s initial proposed location in Xiamen was changed after 2007 protests over pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, Aston Villa teenager, wears his socks low due to superstition and will continue to do so despite referees telling him to pull them up.  He wears children's shin guards and hasn't received a kick to his shins yet.  His first premier league start was in a 3-3 draw against QPR.  He was pleased to finally get his first start and hopes to start in more games this season.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive, according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston.  A source confirmed Brown's unchanging neurological state, noting her lack of responsiveness and a tracheostomy. While Bobby Brown recently stated his daughter was awake and watching him, his attorney clarified that her long-term prognosis remains uncertain, though doctors anticipate a long life.  She has left ICU and begun rehabilitation.

Russia leads Germany 2-0 in the Fed Cup after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, saving a match point in the second set.  Svetlana Kuznetsova also won her match against Julia Goerges in straight sets.  Russia needs one more win to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are bracing for more floods and damage as another storm system, similar to the one that occurred last week, is predicted to hit later this week, bringing heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday.  The State Emergency Service (SES), still working through over 4,000 unresolved jobs from the previous storm, is concerned about further hampering clean-up efforts, particularly in the Hunter region, which was significantly impacted.  While the upcoming storm is expected to be quicker than the last, with potentially two days of rain, the SES urges residents to prepare their homes and families.  The heaviest rainfall is anticipated in the far northern parts of the state and southeast Queensland, with coastal areas in the northeast also expected to be impacted. The Bureau of Meteorology notes it's too early to determine the severity of the system.  The SES is working to complete outstanding tasks and has over 1,000 personnel in the field, including 200 from other states.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, denied Italian media reports that she attempted suicide.  Ms. Moric stated on Instagram that she collapsed at home due to low blood pressure, hitting her head and bruising her arms.  She was treated at a hospital and is now recovering at home.  Her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, who was in Naples at the time, was quoted by the media saying she had attempted suicide.  Ms. Moric was previously married to Fabrizio Corona, and they have a son together.

A poll by the Sunday Times reveals that the public favors traditional names for Kate and William’s second child.  Diana is the most popular choice (12%) if the baby is a girl, followed by Alice and Charlotte (9% each).  If it’s a boy, James (13%) and Alexander are favored.  Many hope for a girl, echoing similar sentiments on social media.  Additionally, the poll shows 68% support William’s six-week paternity leave.

A suicide bomber in Khost, Afghanistan killed 17 people and wounded 64 others near a protest against the provincial governor.  The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other group has claimed it.

Dani Alves will leave Barcelona this summer after 7 years with the club.  His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, confirmed Alves rejected Barcelona’s final contract offer of a 3-year extension contingent on him playing 60% of the club’s matches.  Santana stated that negotiations are over.

Pablo Osvaldo has implored Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors.  He believes the two Italian legends would be a perfect fit for the Argentinian club and the fans would adore them.

18-year-old jockey Lewis Ferguson fell from his horse, Merrion Square, at Wincanton.  The fall, which involved a double somersault, has been viewed online hundreds of thousands of times.  Despite the dramatic incident, Ferguson only suffered a cut on his nose, was back working at the stables the next day, and plans to continue racing.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, celebrated the release of Avengers: Age of Ultron by posting a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram.  Haskell, who rejoined Wasps in 2012 after stints with Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders, first joined the club in 2002.  Since his return, he's made over 100 appearances for Wasps and earned 57 caps playing for England.

Wide-leg trousers are a key Spring/Summer 2015 trend.  They offer a welcome alternative to skinny jeans, though proper proportion is crucial for pulling off the look.  Heels, especially those with an exposed top of foot, create a lengthening effect and are a must, particularly with cropped styles.  Keep tops simple, such as a knit, shirt, or tee.  Denim is an easy entry point, as seen on the Gucci runway.  For other options, Topshop's Miller jean offers a high-street version, while Celine and Stella McCartney offer dressier styles.  Finery London provides similar looks at lower price points.

The University of Michigan reversed its decision to cancel a screening of “American Sniper” after more than 200 students signed a petition objecting to the film and a counter-petition urged the university to reconsider.  The university cited its commitment to freedom of expression and will also offer a screening of “Paddington” for students who prefer not to watch “American Sniper.”

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, attempted to set a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island, Western Australia on April 3rd.  The quokka survived with minor burns. The men were charged with animal cruelty and will appear in court on April 17th.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer at iconic New York nightclubs like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar, had never seen herself dancing due to lost memorabilia and footage. Filmmakers and volunteers compiled "soundies" (early music videos) featuring Barker, allowing her to finally watch herself perform.  She was delighted by the experience.

A recent survey indicates that washing one's car, previously a common Sunday activity, is declining in Britain.  One-third of men and three-quarters of women never wash their own cars, opting instead for professional car washes.  Several factors contribute to this trend, including Sunday shopping, televised sports, readily available hand car washes, and the larger size of modern vehicles.  Although more cars are washed by owners during holiday breaks, one in four admit to doing so merely as an excuse to leave the house.  Regional and brand-based variations exist regarding car washing frequency.

Liverpool’s Martin Skrtel has commended Steven Gerrard's influence on him since joining Anfield in 2008.  Skrtel feels that Gerrard remains a top player, synonymous with Liverpool,  and that his departure will change the club.  He credits Gerrard for helping him acclimate to Liverpool. While acknowledging the difficulty of replacing Gerrard, Skrtel believes Liverpool has players capable of filling the void and plans to support them. Both players may return to the lineup for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after serving three-match bans.

75-year-old Jack Nicklaus hit a hole-in-one on the fourth hole during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National.  Playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw, this was his first ace at Augusta.  While Camilo Villegas also hit two holes-in-one (on the fourth and eighth holes), Kevin Streelman won the contest.  Nicklaus won his first Masters in 1963 and his sixth in 1986.

Wednesday night, Kansas faced several tornado-producing storms. One was spotted near Goddard, while others were reported in southwestern Kansas, including three near Aetna.  Nighttime tornadoes, according to CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers, are the most dangerous.  Storms also impacted Missouri, with a possible tornado touchdown in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and hail. More storms are expected Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a reserve sheriff’s deputy in Oklahoma, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, claiming he mistook his gun for a taser.  A judge granted Bates permission to vacation in the Bahamas, upsetting Harris’s family. Bates’s preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.  His lawyer says the training records prove Bates’s qualifications, despite allegations of preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff. Two deputies involved in the arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor, who will challenge José Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11, has added a tiger tattoo to his stomach.  McGregor stated, "If you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." He claims to have more motivation than Aldo, who will be making his eighth title defense.  McGregor previously snatched Aldo's belt at a Dublin promotional event.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott "skolled" a beer in six seconds at an Australian Rules event, sparking criticism from anti-drinking campaigners who say he is glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with alcohol consumption.  Critics argue that such actions promote a culture of rapid and excessive drinking rather than socializing.  While some, including Health Minister Sussan Ley, defended Abbott's actions, others point to the changing attitudes towards binge drinking and the prime minister's responsibility to set a positive example.  This is not the first time an Australian prime minister has publicly skolled a beer, with former Prime Minister Bob Hawke being a notable example.

Indiana's short-term needle exchange program, approved by Governor Mike Pence, has seen a rise in HIV cases in Scott County, increasing from 106 to 120 confirmed cases with 10 preliminary positives.  While the program has distributed 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected 1,400 used ones, the future of the program and similar legislation is uncertain.  Pence is reviewing the program's effectiveness and will decide on an extension next week.  Although the program has seen increased participation with a mobile unit, Pence opposes needle exchanges as anti-drug policy, and some lawmakers share his concerns.  Funding is also a concern, as the federal government bans public funding for these programs.

A devoted Arsenal fan created a 50-point test for his girlfriend about the club.  She scored 43.5/50 (87%), earning an 'A' grade and praise from her boyfriend, who jokingly stated he wouldn't dump her due to her passing grade.  The test included multiple-choice, fill-in-the-blank, and short answer questions about Arsenal players, history, and important matches.  Although impressed, her boyfriend pointed out areas for improvement, such as learning player positions.  Social media users reacted with amusement, labeling the boyfriend a "legend" and Saskia "proper gf material." Some criticized the boyfriend for his actions, while others were inspired to test their own partners' football knowledge.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked undercover for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia. He was promised US citizenship in exchange for his service, during which he helped take down cartel leaders and dictators. Now retired, Toro faces deportation and fears for his life if sent back to Colombia. The DEA refused to help with his citizenship after he publicized his situation.  A former colleague gave Toro $5,000 for an operation after the DEA declined to help. Toro's visa expired January 1, and he is now in legal limbo, unable to collect social security.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after being allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village and being told by her family to keep quiet.  She is currently in critical condition at Safdarjung Hospital in Delhi. The accused men have been arrested.  This incident follows a heightened sensitivity around sexual assault in India after officials banned the documentary *India's Daughter*, about the 2012 Delhi gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh.  Recent attacks have fueled protests and calls for greater protection of women.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal hopes to defeat Manchester City in Sunday’s derby at Old Trafford.  Van Gaal believes a win will improve United’s chances of finishing in the top three, exceeding their preseason goal. He acknowledges the difficulty of the challenge and the need to control aggression. Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw will not play due to injuries. Van Gaal is looking forward to experiencing the Old Trafford atmosphere for his first home derby.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested high ticket prices during the first 10 minutes of their match.  With the Premier League's new £5.14 billion TV deal, fans find the £64 minimum ticket price unreasonable.  Banners reading, "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket," highlighted the issue.  Fan groups like Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly organized the protest, citing the increasing costs of following their teams. They believe the focus on money is hurting the working class fans and future generations of supporters.

Baby Star was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth.  After an unsuccessful surgery, a liver transplant was necessary.  Neither parent was a match, but the mother's twin sister, Shanell, donated part of her liver. Star underwent the transplant in November and has since recovered.  She requires ongoing blood tests and anti-rejection medication.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's football challenge. Hazard and Ake teamed up against Remy and Willian.  In round one, Hazard and Ake won 5-3, kicking balls into a car boot. Next, they played tennis over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus, winning 6-0.  The final challenge involved long-range shots into a convertible Audi. Remy and Willian won this round, but Willian accidentally broke a wing mirror.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, stated he was not suicidal when he crashed his truck into an SUV, killing Amanda Murphy, Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby.  Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault. He faces 12-24 years in prison and a wrongful death lawsuit.  Dellinger's lawyers claim he suffered from Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac usage, and advanced MS symptoms. Prosecutors say he intentionally drove over the median at 100 mph. Dellinger's wife testified to his good character and health problems.  He took a $1 million severance package in 2011 for health reasons.

Lacey Spears, convicted of murdering her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul Spears by salt poisoning, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed outrage on Facebook, hoping she would die in prison. Spears' lawyer plans to appeal, claiming her innocence and blaming the hospital. Prosecutors argued that Spears, driven by a need for attention, caused her son's illnesses and death.  Spears' social media posts about Garnett-Paul's medical problems were used as evidence against her.

An improved flu vaccine is arriving in Australia one month later than expected due to the inclusion of two new strains, H3N2 and B/Phuket.  These strains caused increased deaths in Europe and the US because the previous vaccine did not protect against them.  The new vaccine will be available to high-risk groups starting April 20th.  Experts recommend everyone get the vaccine, which also protects against the H1N1 strain.

Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois, faces criticism from National Geographic for its appearance and struggles with budget cuts threatening its management.  Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner's proposal to restructure the state historic preservation agency coincides with the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination.  Reduced hours, staffing, and a locked tomb door illustrate the impact of budget cuts.  Despite recent renovations exceeding $2.5 million, including interior and lighting upgrades, and ongoing waterproofing projects, National Geographic's critique describes the tomb as lacking historical character.  While some visitors agree with the criticism, others find the site impressive.

Nineties and noughties fashion trends are back. JNCO jeans, bucket hats, camouflage print, maximalist styling, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corset tops, and harem pants are discussed as trends that should stay in the past, along with examples of celebrities who wore them then and now.  Many celebrities who wore these trends in the nineties and noughties are mentioned, including Christina Aguilera, Rihanna, Beyoncé, Jourdan Dunn, Victoria Beckham, Britney Spears, Justin Timberlake, Kylie Jenner, Paris Hilton, Kristen Bell, Jessica Simpson, Miley Cyrus, Nicole Richie, Nicki Minaj, Cara Delevingne, Selena Gomez, Kim Kardashian, and Elle Macpherson.

Trending this week: A quadruple rainbow over New York City; China bans strippers from funerals; Robert Downey Jr. walks out of interview; the #KylieJennerChallenge goes viral; 102-year-old woman revisits her past; prom proposal rejected over bomb reference; Ewan McGregor cast in “Beauty and the Beast”; Johnny Depp’s transformation for “Black Mass” revealed; creative pregnancy announcements, including one referencing “The Fresh Prince”; and a military dad photobombs his son.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory with a giant cake at the Miami Open, after beating Sabine Lisicki 7-6, 1-6, 6-3.  Williams will play Simona Halep in the semi-final.  Andy Murray also celebrated his 500th win with cake at the same tournament.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist known for her outspokenness and promotion of free speech, was shot and killed in Karachi.  She hosted discussions on controversial topics, including the disappearances in Balochistan, a subject often silenced in mainstream media.  Mahmud's cafe, known as T2F or the Second Floor, was a haven for those seeking secular wisdom and open dialogue.  Her death sparked widespread grief and tributes celebrating her bravery and commitment to human rights.

Mangu Ram is an 82-year-old refugee who fled to Indian Kashmir 70 years ago during the partition of India. He, along with thousands of other West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs), are considered second-class citizens, unable to own property or vote.  With the recent rise of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) to power in Kashmir, there is hope for change in their status.  The WPRs, primarily Hindu,  have been denied full citizenship rights due to concerns about upsetting the demographic balance in the Muslim-majority state.  Although Kashmir is prosperous, the approximately 18,000 WPR families live in poverty.  WPRs cannot access state-run training or government jobs.  While the BJP's presence in the governing coalition offers hope, activists like Labha Ram Gandhi warn they are prepared to fight for their rights if necessary.

Yoshinori Muto, forward for FC Tokyo, is considering an offer from Chelsea.  Muto wants to play regularly to reach his full potential, and is unsure if Chelsea is the right fit.  While Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho acknowledges Muto's talent, he also stated that Chelsea's transfer policy is influenced by financial and commercial interests, such as their sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber.  Former coach Ranko Popovic believes Muto has the potential to succeed at Chelsea due to his intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence.

Australia has revoked its policy of not selecting overseas players for the national team, allowing them to choose top talent like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell.  England should follow suit, enabling coach Stuart Lancaster to select the best players regardless of where they play, including those like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon who have improved since moving to France.  Just as Jonny Wilkinson excelled in France,  players should be supported if they are happier and healthier abroad.  Winning the World Cup requires fielding the strongest team possible, and excluding overseas players weakens England's chances.  The RFU and Premier Rugby should not restrict selection.  South Africa and Wales select players from Toulon, demonstrating the importance of prioritizing the best talent.

Open Garden developers created Greenstone, a device that strengthens off-the-grid networks for their app, FireChat.  FireChat allows users to communicate without internet or mobile signal via Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) or Android's similar Bluetooth feature.  MCF creates a wireless mesh network, connecting phones within a limited range. Greenstone acts as a beacon/booster, extending the network's range and storing up to 1,000 messages until other FireChat users are within range.  Currently, Greenstone is under development, with a limited range and compatibility only with FireChat.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle advocates for body positivity by embracing the word “fat” as a simple descriptor.  In a 2014 TED Talk, she explained that “fat” doesn’t have to be synonymous with “ugly” and that we should be more accepting of diverse body types.  Lillian’s performance allows her to present a “fat” body in a positive, glamorous light.  Studies show increased exposure to body diversity increases acceptance of different body types.  Lillian’s first burlesque performance in 2012 was empowering and helped her embrace her 240lb body.  The TED Talk, posted on YouTube in 2014, has garnered nearly 38,000 views and overwhelmingly positive feedback, further demonstrating a shift towards body positivity.

Theo Walcott and six of his Arsenal teammates: Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, posed for an official portrait for Lanvin, the club’s official tailor.  Walcott has spent much of the season on the bench but came on for the last six minutes of Arsenal’s goalless draw with Chelsea.  He hopes to make his first start since March 14th when the Gunners face Hull.  The Arsenal team will wear similar attire at the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30th.

A collection of over 400 props and puppets from legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned off, both online and in person at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California on May 29, 2024.  Items include pieces from *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, *Gremlins 2*, *Mighty Joe Young*, *Planet of the Apes*, and Michael Jackson's *Moonwalker* and *Thriller* music video.  Many items are estimated to sell for thousands of dollars, with some exceeding $40,000.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell died in a skiing accident in the French Alps after getting separated from his family.  He fell 164ft into dense woodland.  His footprints in the snow led to the discovery of his body.  His family describes him as a daring and outgoing boy who loved skiing and the outdoors.  They are devastated by his death.

Fifteen-year-old Laura Scurr developed anorexia after being bullied about her weight.  At her lowest point, she ate only 100 calories a day, hiding food from her mother.  Her starvation led to heart problems and hospitalization.  With support from eating disorder organizations and mental health services, Laura recovered. Now, with improved body image and confidence, she is a Miss Teen GB semi-finalist, a competition promoting positive body image for young girls.

Liverpool unveiled their new home kit, designed by New Balance,  at Anfield.  Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet modeled the new strip. Sterling, who recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract with Liverpool, was urged by fans to stay with the club next season.  The players expressed excitement about the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.  The new kit features all-white branding and a new collar style. Liverpool's new kit deal with New Balance is a record-breaking £300 million for four years.

University of Manchester researchers created a high-definition map of dark matter, showing clumps of the mystery particles across 0.4% of the sky, using data from the Dark Energy Camera.  The map, the largest of its kind, is part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES), which aims to map 12.5% of the sky and create a 3D view of dark matter and dark energy. Though dark matter is invisible, its gravitational effects on galaxies allow scientists to predict its location.  The map supports theories stating galaxies form near large concentrations of dark matter.  The DES team will continue to expand the map to test cosmological theories by comparing amounts of dark and visible matter.

Manchester United has made an official offer to PSV Eindhoven for 21-year-old Memphis Depay.  United manager Louis van Gaal, who coached Depay in the 2014 World Cup, is eager to sign the young star.  PSV technical director Marcel Brands confirmed contact with Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another large European club, stating that offers are significantly higher than Tottenham’s rejected £15 million bid last summer.  Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helping PSV win their first Eredivisie title in seven years.  Depay’s career began at age six with VV Moordrecht, followed by Sparta Rotterdam and then PSV at age 12.  He is a fast, skilled player with a powerful right foot, often playing on the left wing.  Some believe Depay’s talent rivals a young Cristiano Ronaldo, while others compare him to Arjen Robben.  Depay has also achieved international success, scoring key goals for the Netherlands in the 2014 World Cup.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City 3-1 in a commanding performance. Tammy Abraham scored twice, and Dominic Solanke added a late goal to secure the victory.  Chelsea's midfield controlled the game, and their defense effectively neutralized City's attack.  Standout players for Chelsea included Abraham, Solanke, Charlie Colkett, Jake Clarke-Salter, and Ola Aina.  For City, Brandon Barker showed flashes of brilliance, and Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored their lone goal. Despite some individual bright spots, City struggled to create consistent chances against a strong Chelsea side.

Marco Rubio believes that sexual preference is something people are born with, but that marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman.  He stated that the legality of same-sex marriage should be determined by state legislatures rather than the courts. While personally disagreeing with same-sex marriage, Rubio said he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staff member.  Rubio announced his presidential candidacy last week and has reportedly received substantial financial backing.

Pablo and Ilze, a couple who met in 2011, quit their jobs to cycle the world.  They’ve spent about a year cycling through 16 countries, covering almost 7,000 miles.  To keep costs down, they primarily camp, using websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers.  They spend less than three euros a day each, mostly on food. Their route started in London, went through Western and Southern Europe, then into Eastern Europe and Turkey, and they plan to continue through Asia and the Americas.

A Texas couple is suing Premiere Photos owner James Evans for allegedly printing a racial slur on photo booth pictures from their 2012 wedding.  The bride's sister informed the couple months later.  Evans denies the allegations and reportedly told the couple to "sue me."  The couple's attorney, Cathy Hale, says they pursued legal action after Evans failed to address the issue.  The lawsuit, filed under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claims negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies responsibility, citing lack of evidence. The couple seeks an apology. Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if needed.

Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion, sustained after the France game.  Although there was no single incident, he experienced headaches and didn't feel right. He withdrew from Harlequins' match against Saracens and is unsure when he will return.  Brown's caution stems from awareness of the long-term dangers of concussion, highlighted by cases like Johnny Sexton and Geoff Parling, and reinforced by World Rugby's online modules. He previously withdrew from the Ireland match due to concussion symptoms after being knocked out against Italy.  Brown believes increased awareness is crucial and encourages others to prioritize their health.

A Cambridge statistician suggests that increased smartphone use may be causing couples to have sex less often.  Research shows Britons are having sex less frequently since the rise of the internet, down from five times a month in 1990, to four in 2000, and now three.  The blending of work and private life, constant email checking, and competing demands for time are cited as possible reasons for prioritizing sex less.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once highly valued status symbols in China, fetching prices up to £1.2 million, are now being sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather.  This is due to China's anti-corruption crackdown, which stopped the practice of gifting these dogs to officials, and city bans on large dogs.  Overbreeding led to lower quality dogs, and urbanization made city living unsuitable for them.  Rescued dogs were found in poor conditions, some dead from starvation and injuries, highlighting the cruel fate of these animals.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every woman had experienced sexual harassment or assault on public transport.  Half of the women polled experienced this before age 18.  The harassment ranged from insults and unwanted attention to sexual assault and rape.  This has led to fear and altered behavior for women using public transport.  The High Council for Gender Equality has called for a public awareness campaign to address the issue and educate people that these actions are punishable offenses.

Direct Line's #everydayfix competition tasked design groups with creating products to address common everyday emergencies.  Three finalists were chosen: Snooze, an alarm clock silencing phone notifications; Forget Me Lock, a key fob indicating whether a door is locked; and Nipper, a small phone charger powered by household batteries. The public can vote for their favorite on Twitter using retweets, and the winner will receive Kickstarter funding.  Other designs included a helmet with bone conduction headphones for directions, a parking spot finder, and an app relaying messages when a phone's battery dies.

Vera Baird, Northumbria's Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC), awarded £500,000 to Victims First Northumbria, a charity where she is a director alongside Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim.  This has led to a Ministry of Justice probe, as critics cite a conflict of interest.  Baird maintains proper procedure was followed, while critics like Keith Vaz, Home Affairs Committee Chairman, call the situation inappropriate and question PCCs' power to allocate public funds to charities.  Sim, who will retire in June, was previously investigated for bullying by Baird.  The Ministry of Justice will investigate potential conflicts of interest and may cease funding if any are found. Victims First Northumbria was created after a decline in Victim Support participation, but some are hesitant to engage with a service partly run by Sim.

In Philadelphia, 21-year-old Corry Campbell, believing Greg Valecce, 53, hurt his cat, led a group in a three-day assault.  Valecce was beaten, tied to a chair, and tattooed with offensive images by Campbell and Carl Halin, 18.  Campbell’s girlfriend, Sandra Ng, 19, also participated in the assault.  Valecce suffered broken bones and psychological trauma.  Campbell and Halin received 20-year sentences, Ng received 23 months, and two other individuals await sentencing or trial.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign 21-year-old Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven.  United manager Louis van Gaal, who coached Depay in the 2014 World Cup, is eager to sign the player.  PSV technical director Marcel Brands confirmed contact with Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and another large European club, stating the offers are much higher than Tottenham’s rejected £15 million bid last summer.  Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helping PSV win their first Eredivise title in seven years.  Depay is considered a highly talented young player with comparisons to Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo. He has also had international success, scoring goals for the Netherlands in the 2014 World Cup.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City 3-1 in a commanding performance. Tammy Abraham scored two goals, and Dominic Solanke added a third.  Despite a goal from Isaac Buckley-Ricketts, Manchester City struggled against Chelsea's strong defense and vibrant attack.  Standout players for Chelsea included Abraham, Solanke, Charlie Colkett, Jake Clarke-Salter, and Ola Aina.  Brandon Barker was Manchester City's best player, though he may have overextended himself at times. Other notable players for City included Tosin Adarabioyo and Cameron Humphreys-Grant.

Marco Rubio believes that sexual preference is something people are born with, but that marriage should be between a man and a woman.  While he personally disagrees with same-sex marriage, he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staff member.  He stated that states should regulate marriage and that legalizing same-sex marriage is not a constitutional right. Also, he announced his candidacy for president and has received strong financial backing.

Pablo and Ilze, a couple who met in 2011, quit their jobs to cycle the world.  They travel astonishingly cheaply, spending less than three euros a day each over the first 356 days of their trip.  They've covered almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries, primarily camping or using hosting websites. Food is their main expense, costing 2.74 euros per day. Their route began in London, went through Western and Southern Europe, then into the Balkans, Greece, and Turkey.  They plan to continue through Asia, across the Pacific, and down the length of the Americas.

Mike Brown is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion, sustained after the France game.  Although there was no single incident, he experienced headaches and didn't feel right. He withdrew from Harlequins' match against Saracens and is unsure when he will return.  Brown's caution stems from awareness of the long-term dangers of concussion, highlighted by cases like Johnny Sexton and Geoff Parling, and reinforced by World Rugby's online modules. He previously withdrew from the Ireland match due to concussion symptoms after being knocked out against Italy.  Brown believes increased awareness is crucial and encourages others to prioritize their health.

A Cambridge statistician suggests that increased smartphone use may be causing couples to have sex less often.  Research indicates Britons are having sex less frequently since the rise of the internet, down from five times a month in 1990, to four in 2000, and now three.  This decrease is possibly due to the blurring of lines between public and private life as people constantly check emails, reducing couple’s quiet time together.  Increased connectivity and a busier lifestyle also contribute to this decline, pushing sex lower on people’s priority lists.

Tibetan Mastiffs, previously prized and costing up to £1.2 million, are now being sent to slaughterhouses for hotpot meat and leather in China. This is due to China's anti-corruption crackdown, which stopped officials from accepting them as gifts, and city bans on dogs over 50kg.  Cross-breeding and urbanisation also contributed to their decline. Rescued dogs were found in poor condition, some dead from starvation and injuries.  Breeders and gangs are selling the dogs to slaughterhouses.

Direct Line's #everydayfix competition tasked design groups with creating products to address common everyday emergencies.  Three finalists were chosen: Snooze, an alarm clock silencing phone notifications; Forget Me Lock, a key fob indicating whether a door is locked; and Nipper, a tiny charger powered by household batteries. The public can vote for their favorite on Twitter using retweets, and the winner will receive Kickstarter funding.  Other designs included a helmet with directional audio, a parking space finder, and a message relay app for dead phones.

More than 512 guests and musical performers attended the 2009 convention, including Patrick Stewart, William Shatner, Leonard Nimoy, Terry Gilliam, Bruce Boxleitner, James Marsters, and Mary McDonnell.

As of March 12th, Italy has the world's highest per capita rate of positive coronavirus cases (206.1 per million people) among nations with at least one million citizens.  This is 3.6 times China's rate.  Italy also has the second-highest number of total positive cases and deaths, after China.

It has more confirmed cases than all of mainland China (excluding Hubei province) and the second-highest number of positive cases and deaths, second only to mainland China.
